questions.text: On average, how long does sperm maintain fertility within the female genital tract?
questions.solution:
Option C: 24-48 hours

  • Spermatozoa remain fertile for 24-48 hours after ejaculation but can survive for 5 -10 days in the female reproductive tract.
  • The ovum remains viable for 12-24 hours after ovulation.
  • Fertilization during this time frame maximizes the chances of conception.
  • The window period for fertilization in females is 24 hours and in males is 48 hours.
  • Only 1% of sperm deposited in the vagina enter the cervix.
  • The movement of sperms from the cervix to the fallopian tube occurs by muscular contractions of the uterus and the fallopian tube (very little role in their propulsion).

Option A: 6-8 hours

  • Spermatozoa remain fertile for 24-48 hours after ejaculation.

Option B: 12-24 hours

  • Spermatozoa remain fertile for 24-48 hours after ejaculation.
  • Ovum remains viable for 12-24 hours.

Option D: 72-96 hours

  • Spermatozoa remain fertile for 24-48 hours after ejaculation

questions.text: A 46-year-old male was involved in a car accident. CT brain of the patient was done, which revealed a counter - coup injury and a nerve exiting dorsally from the brainstem had been compressed against the tentorium. Which of the following nerves is being referred to in this case?
questions.solution:
Options D: CN IV

  • This is a cerebellar tumor in which the patient presents with postural instability, headache, nausea, and diplopia.
  • Due to this tumor, the trochlear nerve is compressed, further aggravating the symptoms.
  • The trochlear nerve exits from the posterior surface of the midbrain and is the only cranial nerve to exit posteriorly.
  • It is a motor nerve with its nucleus located in the midline of the brainstem, also in the anterior portion of the periaqueductal grey, but inferior to the oculomotor nucleus.

Options A: CN I

  • The cranial nerve I am the olfactory nerve.
  • It is a purely sensory nerve.
  • It originates from the cerebrum and exists through the cribriform plate.

Options B: CN II

  • The cranial nerve II is the optic nerve.
  • It is also a sensory nerve.
  • It originates from the cerebrum and exists through the superior orbital fissure.

Options C: CN III

  • The cranial nerve III is the oculomotor nerve.
  • It originates from the midbrain.
  • The trochlear nerve exits from the posterior surface of the midbrain and is the only cranial nerve to exit posteriorly.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents with symptoms including visual loss, nausea, vomiting, weakness, menstrual changes, sexual dysfunction, increased urine, and unintended weight changes. MRI shows an enlarged pituitary gland located in the sella turcica, immediately posterior and superior to which structure?
questions.solution:
Option B: Sphenoid sinus

  • The pituitary gland lies in the hypophyseal fossa of sella turcica of the sphenoid bone, which lies immediately superior and posterior to the sphenoid sinus and medial to the cavernous sinus.
  • The sphenoidal sinus is an air cavity within the body of the sphenoid bone. It is a midline structure located anterior to the clivus and posterior to the superior meatus of the nasal cavity.

Option A: Frontal sinus

  • The frontal sinus lies in the frontal bone.
  • Frontal sinuses are a pair of small, air-filled cavities located just behind your eyes in the brow region. Along with three other pairs of paranasal sinuses, these cavities produce a thin mucus that drains through your nasal passages.
  • The maxillary sinus lies in the maxilla lateral to the lateral wall of the nasal cavity.

Option C: Ethmoid air cells

  • Ethmoid sinus (composed of air cells) lies between the orbit and nasal cavity.
  • The ethmoid sinuses are within the ethmoid bone and are divided into two compartments, the anterior and posterior.
  • The anterior ethmoid sinus drains into the middle meatus, and the posterior ethmoids drain into the sphenoethmoidal recess.

Option D: Mastoid air cells

  • Mastoid air cells lie in the mastoid process of the temporal bone
  • At the superior and anterior part of the mastoid process, the air cells are large and irregular and contain air, but toward the inferior part, they diminish in size. In contrast, those at the apex of the process are frequently quite small and contain marrow. Occasionally, they are absent.
  • Mastoid air cells communicate with the middle ear via the mastoid antrum and the aditus ad antrum.

questions.text: Which muscle would not be affected in a 15-year-old boy who suffered an arrow injury in the suboccipital triangle?
questions.solution:
Option C: Splenius capitis

  • The splenius capitis is innervated by the dorsal primary rami of the middle and lower cervical nerves.
  • So, injuring the suboccipital nerve between the vertebral artery and the posterior arch of the atlas won't affect the splenius capitis.
  • Splenius capitis and splenius cervicis together form the spinotransversales muscles.
  • The two spinotransversales muscles run from the spinous processes and ligamentum nuchae upward and laterally.
  • The splenius capitis is a broad muscle.
  • It is attached to the mastoid process of the temporal bone.
  • It is also attached to the transverse process of the upper cervical vertebrae.
  • Together, both of these muscles draw the head backward, extending the neck. Individually, each muscle rotates its head to one side- the same side as the contracting muscle.

Option A: Rectus capitis posterior major

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve (primary dorsal ramus of the C1) supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

Option B: Semispinalis capitis

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

Option D: Obliquus capitis superior

  • This muscle will be affected due to the injury to the suboccipital nerve.
  • The suboccipital nerve supplies muscles of the suboccipital area, including
    • The rectus capitis posterior major
    • Obliquus capitis superior
    • The semispinalis capitis

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy complains of numbness and tingling in both feet. The examination reveals no pulse in the femoral artery, increased blood pressure in the arteries of the upper extremities, and enlarged arteries. Which of the following abnormalities would you suspect?
questions.solution:
Option C: Postductal coarctation of the Aorta

  • Upper extremity pulses are normal or increased, but absent or non-palpable lower extremity pulses indicate post-ductal narrowing
  • No pulse in the femoral artery.
  • Increased blood pressure in the upper extremity arteries, enlarged intercostal veins, and numbness and tingling in both feet are clinical symptoms suggestive of post-ductal coarctation of the Aorta.
  • The narrowing of the Aorta affects the blood supply to the lower extremities.

Option A: Double aortic arch

  • The double aortic arch may press on the trachea and oesophagus, leading to trouble breathing and swallowing.
  • Stridor and repeated pulmonary infections are some of the symptoms.

Option B: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • TOF is cyanotic heart disease.
  • Tetralogy of Fallot is most often diagnosed in the first few weeks of life due to either a loud murmur or cyanosis.
  • VSD, overriding Aorta, RVH and infundibular pulmonary stenosis are the features of TOF.

Option D: Right aortic arch

  • Right aortic arch anomalies occur in approximately 0.01 to 0.1 per cent of the general population.
  • In general, these anomalies do not directly cause any cardiovascular problems.
  • However, right aortic arches can be associated with other congenital heart defects, vascular rings, and chromosomal abnormalities such as DiGeorge syndrome in some patients.

questions.text: A 24-year-old graduate student presents in the emergency department 10 days after sustaining a blunt force injury to the fifth finger of her non-dominant hand during a volleyball game. On examination, there's an inability to actively extend the distal joint, with slight tenderness and swelling on the dorsum. Suspected diagnosis: mallet finger. What causes a mallet finger?

choices.text: Rupture of collateral slips of the extensor expansion
Rupture of the central slip of extensor expansion

questions.solution:
Option B: Rupture of collateral slips of the extensor expansion

  • The mallet finger (also known as the baseball finger) is a flexion deformity of the distal phalanx.
  • It is due to injury to the extensor digitorum.
  • The extensor digitorum is a superficial extensor muscle located in the posterior compartment of the forearm.
  • It originates from the anterior aspect of the lateral epicondyle of the humerus and gets inserted on to middle and distal phalanges on the posterior surface; extensor expansions of digits 2-5.
  • The extensor digitorum tendon at its insertion is avulsed from the proximal end of the distal phalanx.
  • Sometimes the bone also chips off with the tendon avulsion.

Option A: Avulsion fracture of middle phalanx

  • Avulsion fracture of the middle phalanx of the hand finger does not cause a mallet (hammer-like) finger.
  • There is no flexion deformity as presented by the patient.

Option C: Rupture of the central slip of extensor expansion

  • If the middle slip of the digital expansion ruptured, there would be minimal deformity if the transverse ﬁbers of the expansion remain intact.
  • Again, there is no flexion deformity of the finger, as presented by the patient.

Option D: Dislocation of distal interphalangeal joint

  • Dislocation of the distal interphalangeal joint does not cause the deformity of the mallet finger of the hand.
  • Depending on the severity of the dislocation, the displaced distal interphalangeal joint can cause damage to the surrounding tissues.

questions.text: Which nerve structure is involved in innervation of the first part of the duodenum?
questions.solution:
Option A: Greater splanchnic nerve

  • This patient has presented with dyspepsia and severe epigastric pain relieving mostly after meals or with antacids suggestive of duodenal ulcers.
  • The suggestive symptoms of the pain of duodenal ulcers are relief with a meal resulting in weight gain, nocturnal pain, prolonged use of NSAIDs and a history of treatment for H. pylori.
  • Duodenal ulcers commonly occur in the duodenum's first part or at the duodenal bulb.
  • Both sympathetic and parasympathetic nerves supply the first part of the duodenum.
  • The sympathetic supply is mainly by the greater splanchnic nerve (T5-T9) that also carries pain sensations, while the parasympathetic is via the Vagus nerve.
  • The sympathetic nerve fibres travelling via the greater splanchnic nerve are the branches of the celiac plexus that originate from the fifth to the twelfth thoracic spinal segments.
  • These pre-synaptic fibres synapse in the celiac and superior mesenteric ganglia.
  • The post-synaptic sympathetic nerve fibres are distributed to the duodenal wall by following the branches of the celiac trunk
  • Pain arising from the first part of the duodenum cannot be localised well. Therefore, it is referred to as epigastrium.
  • Hence, the pain of duodenal ulcers is mediated by afferent fibres accompanying the sympathetic nerve fibres, mainly the greater splanchnic nerve.

 

Option B: Ventral roots of the spinal nerve

  • The ventral or anterior roots of spinal nerves contain efferent nerve fibres that carry stimuli away from the central nervous system towards the target structures. Motor neurons mostly control skeletal muscles. It does not carry pain sensation from the viscera to the brain.

 

Option C: Lower intercostal nerve

  • Lower intercostal nerves (T7-T11) course through corresponding intercostal spaces and supply the parietal peritoneum, abdominal wall muscles, and the skin of the anterior abdomen.

 

Option D: Lesser splanchnic nerve

  • The lesser splanchnic nerve is formed by the 9th and 10th rami (sometimes the 10th and 11th) thoracic ganglia.
  • It courses lateral and parallel to the greater splanchnic nerves, anteriorly to the spine, pierces the diaphragm and enters the abdomen.
  • The post-synaptic fibres of the lesser splanchnic nerve modulate the activity of the mid-gut and the enteric nervous system.

questions.text: A 2-day-old newborn baby presents to the physician with complaints of complete loss of breath and turning blue on several occasions. His breathing improves if the baby is placed in an upright or sitting position. Physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the baby is lying down. On auscultation, there are no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: Congenital diaphragmatic hernia

  • Clinical history indicates congenital diaphragmatic hernia because physical examination reveals an unusually flat stomach when the newborn is lying down; auscultation demonstrates no breath sounds on the left side of the thorax.
  • A congenital diaphragmatic hernia is a congenital defect in the diaphragm.
  • An abnormally developed diaphragm results in an abnormal opening (hernia) that allows the intestine and stomach to move into the chest cavity and fill the heart and lungs.
  • This overcrowding can lead to underdevelopment of the lungs (pulmonary hypoplasia), which can lead to life-threatening breathing difficulties that are recognizable from birth.
  • Loss of breath and cyanosis result from pulmonary hypoplasia associated with congenital diaphragmatic hernia.
  • Placing the child in an upright position will reduce the hernia somewhat and ease the pressure on the lungs, thereby increasing the baby's comfort.
  • The baby’s stomach is flat (instead of the plump belly of a normal newborn) because the abdominal viscera have herniated into the thorax.
  • Auscultation reveals no breath sounds on the left side because of pulmonary hypoplasia.

Option A: Physiological umbilical herniation

  • A physiological umbilical herniation is a self-limiting condition not associated with cyanosis.

Option B: Esophageal hiatal hernia

  • Esophageal hiatal hernia doesn't present with abdominal defects.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot

  • Tetralogy of Fallot also presents with cyanosis, but the patient improves in a squatting position, not in an upright position.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the origin of the fibers of the internal anal sphincter?

choices.text: Internal longitudinal muscle fibers of the rectum
Internal circular muscle fibers of the rectum

questions.solution:
Option B: Internal circular muscle fibres of the rectum

  • The internal anal sphincter is formed by thickened circular muscle coat of the anal canal (which is continuous with the rectum) and surrounds the upper two-thirds of the canal.

Option A: Internal longitudinal muscle fibres of the rectum

  • The internal anal sphincter is formed by thickened circular muscle fibres of the rectum, not the longitudinal fibres.

Option C: Puborectalis muscle

  • The puborectalis muscle forms a part of the pelvic diaphragm.
  • The internal anal sphincter does not arise from the fibres of this muscle.

Option D: Deep perineal muscles

  • These muscles support the perineal structures.
  • The internal anal sphincter does not arise from these muscles.

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 30 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetric clinic with rectal bleeding and severe pain while defecating for 4 days. According to her, the blood appears bright red when wiped with a tissue. She has complained of constipation on and off since the start of pregnancy. On physical examination, a bluish, tender perianal mass is seen. Which of the following nerve supply is responsible for the pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Inferior rectal nerve

  • The inferior rectal nerve is a branch of the pudendal nerve originating from the ventral rami of the second, third and fourth sacral nerve roots. It crosses the ischiorectal fossa along with the inferior rectal artery and veins towards the anal canal and lower end of the rectum.
  • It is responsible for cutaneous innervation below the pectinate line and external anal sphincter.
  • In the clinical scenario above, the patient presents with external haemorrhoids.
  • These are varicosities of the tributaries of the inferior rectal vein as they run laterally from the anal margin. They are present distal to the dentate line.
  • They are covered by the mucous membrane of the lower half of the anal canal or the skin and innervated by inferior rectal nerves.
  • These are sensitive to pain, temperature, touch, and pressure.
  • Thrombosis of an external haemorrhoid is common. The presence of a small, acutely tender, and bluish swelling at the anal margin is a physical diagnostic finding.
  • Risk factors include age, pregnancy, prolonged sitting, straining, chronic constipation, and pelvic tumours. Symptoms include pain, hematochezia, and perianal pruritis.

Option A: Hypogastric nerve

  • The superior hypogastric plexus is in front of the sacral promontory and divides to form the right and left hypogastric nerves.
  • The inferior hypogastric plexus is formed from the hypogastric nerve, the superior hypogastric plexus, and the pelvic splanchnic nerve.
  • It contains postganglionic sympathetic fibres, preganglionic and postganglionic parasympathetic fibres, and visceral afferent fibres.
  • The hypogastric nerve is responsible for semen ejaculation in males.

Option C: Pelvic splanchnic nerve

  • They arise in the pelvis from the anterior rami of spinal nerves S2-S4 of the sacral plexus.
  • They convey presynaptic parasympathetic fibres from these spinal cord segments to the hypogastric plexus, where they synapse and then innervate the pelvic viscera.
  • These fibres stimulate the rectum and bladder contraction for defecation and urination, producing an erection on reaching the prostatic plexus.

Option D: Sympathetic plexus

  • It is an autonomic plexus that is composed of sympathetic axons. It conveys preganglionic sympathetic fibres.
  • The pelvic nerves from the sympathetic plexus run down behind the rectum on the front of the sacrum, medial to the anterior sacral foramina.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to weakness of knee extension for the last 2 months. On physical examination, paralysis of a muscle that originates from the femur was found. The muscle is also responsible for the stability of the knee joint. Which of the following muscles is most likely affected?
questions.solution:
Option A: Vastus Lateralis

  • All the muscles mentioned above contribute to the stability of the knee joint.
  • The vastus lateralis muscles arise from the femur, while all the other muscles originate from the hip (coxal) bone.
  • The vastus lateralis muscle is located on the lateral side of the thigh.
  • This muscle is the largest of the quadriceps muscles, including rectus femoris, vastus intermedius, and vastus medialis.
  • It originates from the greater trochanter, intertrochanteric line, and linea aspera of the femur and attaches to the patella as the quadriceps tendon.
  • It is responsible for extending and stabilizing the knee.
  • The femoral nerve innervates it.
  • Together, the quadriceps act on the knee and hip to promote movement, strength, and stability.

Option B: Semimembranosus

  • The semimembranosus muscle is situated at the back and medial side of the thigh.
  • It originates from the ischial tuberosity and inserts into the tibia’s medial condyle.
  • It does not originate from the femur.

Option C: Sartorius

  • The sartorius muscle is a thin, long, superficial muscle in the anterior compartment of the thigh.
  • It is the longest muscle in the human body.
  • It originates from the anterior superior iliac spine of the hip bone.

Option D: Bicep femoris (long head)​​​​​​​

  • The biceps femoris is a long muscle of the posterior aspect of the thigh.
  • It has two heads, long and short heads.
  • The long head of the biceps femoris originates from the ischial tuberosity and sacrotuberous ligament and inserts into the head of the fibula.

questions.text: Which of the following signs, if present, will confirm an injury of the common peroneal nerve?
questions.solution:
Option B: Foot drop

  • The common peroneal nerve is the most typical nerve to be paralysed in lower limb injuries as it located at the neck of the fibula
  • Common peroneal divides into terminal branches, the superficial peroneal nerve  and the deep peroneal nerve.
  • Motor dysfunction of the common peroneal nerve will cause a Foot drop peroneal nerve, a branch of the common peroneal nerve, innervates the muscles responsible for dorsiflexion.
  • There will also be a sensation loss over the foot's dorsum and lateral side of the leg. Innervation is preserved on the medial side of the leg (supplied by the saphenous nerve, a branch of the femoral), and the heel and sole (supplied by the tibial nerve, a branch of the sciatic nerve).
  • It can be injured due to a fractured neck or fibula, lathi injury on the lateral side of the knee joint, or plaster on the leg.

Option A: Loss of plantar flexion

  • The tibial nerve supplies the muscles innervating the popliteus muscle responsible for plantar flexion, So if the tibial nerve is damaged, we will see a loss of plantar flexion

Option C: Loss of sensation over sole

  • The tibial nerve innervates the skin of the sole, so if there was damage to the tibial nerve, then only there will be a loss of sensation in sole

Option D: Inversion of the foot affected

  • Inversion of the foot is affected by tibial nerve damage as it innervates the muscles responsible for inversion and plantar flexion

questions.text: Which of the following best defines the basis for sensory inputs being converted into nerve impulses?
questions.solution:
Option D: Increased ion permeability

  • All sensory receptors share one characteristic.
  • No matter what kind of stimulus activates the receptor, it immediately changes the membrane's electrical potential. A receptor potential is a name given to this change in potential.
  • Receptor Potential Mechanisms: Different receptors can be stimulated in a variety of ways to produce receptor potentials, including:
    • Mechanical deformation of the receptor stretches the receptor membrane and opens ion channels.
    • Application of a chemical to the membrane, which also opens ion channels.
    • Change of membrane temperature, which alters the membrane's permeability.
    • The effects of electromagnetic radiation, such as light on a retinal visual receptor, open or close ion channels.
  • These four distinct ways to stimulate receptors correlate to the many types of sensory receptors. In every case, a change in the receptor's membrane permeability (usually sodium) is the primary factor in changing the transmembrane potential by allowing ions to permeate the membrane more or less readily.

Option A: Activation of G protein

  • G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) have important functions in inflammation, cell development, and differentiation. They are crucial for translating visual, olfactory, and gustatory inputs and main messengers, such as hormones and neurotransmitters, into cellular signals.
  • They are not primarily mechanoreceptors, but recent studies have shown they have a potential for mechanosensation.

Option B: Decreased ion permeability

  • Ion permeability is increased, not decreased, for transduction of the sensory stimuli into nerve impulses.

Option C: Decreased transmitter release

  • Neurotransmitter release does not occur at the level of the mechanoreceptor. However, if the mechanoreceptor is activated, afferent nerve impulses stimulate transmitter release at the nerve terminal in the central nervous system.

questions.text: If a patient has a creatinine clearance of 90 ml/min, a urine flow rate of 1 ml/min, a plasma K+ concentration of 4 mEq/L, and a urine K+ concentration of 60 mEq/L, what is the approximate rate of K+ excretion?
questions.solution:
Option A: 0.06 mEq/min

  • K+ excretion rate = (urine K+ concentration) × (urine flow rate)

                                            = (60 mEq/L) × (0.001 L/min)

                                            = 0.06 mEq/ min.

  • Urinary potassium excretion over 24 hours should be sufficient to assess whether the kidney is responding appropriately to the prevailing level of plasma potassium and dietary K+ intake.
  • Renal potassium excretion decreases when the glomerular filtration rate (GFR) is decreased or when there is a defect in tubular potassium excretion resulting from a lack of aldosterone, medications, or a primary defect in tubular potassium excretion.
  • Potassium excretion is decreased in both acute and chronic renal failure. Severe hyperkalemia occurs more commonly in acute renal failure. In contrast, in patients with chronic renal failure, hyperkalemia does not occur unless the GFR is lower than 10 mL/min or some other factor predisposing to hyperkalemia is present.

Option B: 0.30 mEq/min

  • Excretion rate is the multiplication of urine concentration of a substance and urine flow rate. If urine concentration of K+ is 60 mEq/L and urine flow rate is 0.001 L/min, the excretion rate would be 0.06 mEq/min. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Option C: 0.36 mEq/min

  • Excretion rate is the multiplication of urine concentration of a substance and urine flow rate. If urine concentration of K+ is 60 mEq/L and urine flow rate is 0.001 L/min, the excretion rate would be 0.06 mEq/min. Hence, this option is incorrect.

Option D: 3.6 mEq/min

  • Excretion rate is the multiplication of urine concentration of a substance and urine flow rate. If urine concentration of K+ is 60 mEq/L and urine flow rate is 0.001 L/min, the excretion rate would be 0.06 mEq/min. Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male amateur mountain climber has started climbing Mount Everest. Before his climb, he takes acetazolamide. What response is expected with this drug before the climb?
questions.solution:
Option C: Elevated ventilation

  • Mountain climbing faces the hyperbaric hyperventilation condition. This hyperventilation causes respiratory alkalosis due to hyperbaric hypoxia.  
  • To compensate for high respiratory alkalosis, acetazolamide is taken by mountaineers.
  • This is a Carbonic Anhydrase inhibitor
  • Forces kidneys to excrete bicarbonate, the base form of CO2.
  • This excretion re-acidifies the blood, balancing the effects of the hyperventilation that occurs at altitude in an attempt to get O2.
  • Such re-acidification acts as a respiratory stimulant, particularly at night, reducing the periodic breathing pattern common at altitude.
  • This would increase ventilation, resulting in a decrease in pCO2

Option A: Alkaline blood

  • Blood becomes acidic, not alkaline.

Option B: Normal ventilation

  • Hyperventilation occurs instead of normal respiration.

Option D: Normal arterial blood gases

  • Arterial blood gases are not normal.

questions.text: A group of pharmacists is trying to study the pharmacokinetics of a new drug. They want to calculate the extracellular volume of a test subject. 5g of mannitol has been injected intravenously. After equilibrium, 40% of mannitol is excreted and the plasma concentration of mannitol is 30 mg/dl. What is the volume of the fluid in which this substance is distributed?
questions.solution:
Option A: 10 L is the correct answer.

  • The volume of water in different compartments can be measured by the volume of distribution principle (indicator dilution principle).

Where

  • v: Volume of fluid
  • Q: Quantity of indicator given
  • C: Concentration of the indicator
  • e: The amount of indicator which has either been lost or metabolized

30 mg% = 30 mg/100 mL

              = 300 mg/ L

              = 0.3g/L

Quantity of mannitol excreted = 5 * 40/100 = 2 g

ECF volume = 5 – 2/0.3

                     = 3 / 0.3

                     = 10 L

questions.text: Which neurotransmitter inhibits GnRH neurons before puberty?
questions.solution:
Option C: Gamma amino butyric acid (GABA)

  • Transitioning to a reproductive state (during puberty) requires maturation of the entire hypothalamic-pituitary-gonadal axis.
  • Before this maturation occurs, plasma LH and FSH levels are diminished despite low gonadal steroids and inhibin concentrations.
  • GnRH neurons are said to be under the inhibitory influence of GABAergic neurons.
  • Additional inhibition comes from NPY, endorphins, and nocturnal melatonin secretion.

Option A: Glycine

This is false because:

  • GnRH neurons are said to be under the inhibitory influence of GABAergic neurons, not glycine.

Option B: Glutamate

This is false because:

  • GnRH neurons are said to be under the inhibitory influence of GABAergic neurons, not glutamate.

Option D: Beta-endorphin

This is false because:

  • GnRH neurons are said to be under the inhibitory influence of GABAergic neurons, not beta-endorphin.

questions.text: A physiology demonstration is being held on fluid compartments. The professor explains that to measure the volume of any fluid compartment within the body, you must inject or infuse a marker substance that will equilibrate (diffuse freely to a uniform concentration) throughout this compartment. To be a perfect marker, a substance must also not be metabolized. Furthermore, it must be possible to measure the concentration of the marker once the equilibration is complete. The most accurate extracellular fluid volume (ECF) measurement can be done by using?
questions.solution:
Option C: Inulin

  • No ideal marker for extracellular fluid (ECF) measurement is available. Among the given options, the most accurate measurement of ECF volume is obtained by using Inulin.

Measurement of Extracellular Fluid Volume

  • Substances that pass through the capillary membrane but do not enter the cells are used to measure ECF volume.
  • These substances remain in ECF and do not enter the cell (ICF). When one of these substances is injected into the blood, it mixes with the fluid of all sub-compartments of ECF within 30 minutes to 1 hour.
  • The indicator dilution method is applied to calculate ECF volume.
  • Since ECF includes plasma, the concentration of marker substance can be obtained in the sample of plasma.
  • Some marker substances like sodium, chloride, Inulin, and sucrose diffuse more evenly throughout all sub-compartments of ECF. Hence, the measured volume of ECF by using these substances is referred to as sodium space, chloride space, inulin space and sucrose space.

Option A: Sucrose

  • Since sucrose has a much smaller molecular weight than Inulin, and also the most accurate measurement of ECF volume is obtained by using Inulin.

Option B: Mannitol

  • Inulin and mannitol measure ECF volume.
  • Among the given options, the most accurate measurement of ECF volume is obtained by using Inulin.

Option D: Aminopyrin

  • Antipyrine or Aminopyrine is used for total body water (TBW) measurement. Hence, option D is ruled out.

questions.text: A 50-year-old elderly patient came to the emergency department with shortness of breath and generalized oedema, especially in his legs, for the last two days. On examination, he had basal crepitations and a rapid heart rate. The doctor suspects congestive cardiac failure. When capillary and interstitial hydrostatic pressures are 30 mm Hg and 10 mm Hg, respectively, colloid oncotic pressure in capillaries and interstitium are 22 mm Hg and 5 mm Hg, respectively. What will be the net filtration pressure of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: +3mm Hg

  • The net filtration pressure of this patient will be + 3 mm Hg.
  • The Starling equation describes the net flow of fluid across a semipermeable membrane.
  • It describes the balance between capillary, interstitial, and osmotic pressure.
  • Forces favoring filtration out of the capillaries:
    • Capillary hydrostatic pressure (30 mm Hg).
    • Interstitial fluid colloid oncotic pressure (5 mm Hg).
  • Thus, total force that favors filtration = 30 + 5 = 35 mm Hg.
  • Forces that pull the fluid back into the capillaries:
    • Plasma colloid oncotic pressure (22 mm Hg).
    • Interstitial fluid hydrostatic pressure (10 mm Hg).
  • Thus, total force that opposes filtration = 22 + 10 = 32 mm Hg.
  • Hence, net filtration pressure = 35 – 33 = + 3 mm Hg.

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is not involved in regulating food intake?
questions.solution:
Option B: Gastrin

  • Gastrin has no role in the regulation of food intake.
  • It is secreted by the G cells of the stomach.
  • Its triggers include
    • Small peptides and amino acids
    • Distention of the stomach
    • Vagal stimulation via gastrin-releasing peptide
  • Its function is to increase gastric acid secretion and gastric motility.

The following hormones play a role in food regulation:

  • Ghrelin (increase appetite)
  • Leptin (decrease appetite)
  • Peptide YY (decrease appetite)
  • Cholecystokinin (decrease appetite)

Option A: Ghrelin

  • Ghrelin is secreted by the stomach.
  • Its function is to increase appetite.
  • Its levels are increased in the fasting state, while intake of food causes its level to drop.
  • Its levels are particularly high in Prader-Willi syndrome.

Option C: Peptide YY

  • Peptide YY is produced by L cells of the small and large intestine.
  • It is produced in response to protein-rich chyme.
  • Its function is to decrease appetite and gastric emptying.

Option D: Leptin

  • It is produced by adipose tissue.
  • Its role is to decrease appetite.
  • The levels of leptin increase in obesity, and they decrease in starvation.

questions.text: One of your friends visits your clinic with his spouse and 3-year-old daughter. His blood type is A, Rh-positive, while his spouse has B, Rh-positive. The blood type of his daughter is O, Rh-negative. What is your comment about the relation between the three individuals, based on the given information?

choices.text: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father
The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother
Neither adult can be the natural parent of this child
This couple can be the natural parents of this child

questions.solution:
Option D: This couple can be the natural parents of this child

  • For the expression of blood type in the newborn, the parents, either the father or mother, need only a single allele like the A or B antigen or the Rh(D) antigen.
  • If the parents carry an allele for blood type O and a null allele for the Rh(D), the child can be homozygous for the recessive O allele and the Rh(D) negative allele.
  • Rh factors are genetically determined. A baby may have either parent’s blood type and Rh factor or a combination of both parents. Rh factors follow a common pattern of genetic inheritance. The Rh-positive gene is dominant (stronger), and the positive gene takes over even when paired with an Rh-negative gene.

Option A: The woman can be the child’s natural mother, but the man cannot be the natural father

  • Both Mother and father can be the natural parents of this child.

Option B: The man can be the child’s natural father, but the woman cannot be the natural mother

  • Both Mother and father can be the natural parents of this child.

Option C: Neither adult can be the natural parent of this child

  • They both can be the natural parents of this child.

questions.text: A 27-year-old rugby player sustained a fracture to the right tibia after a collision injury. After his lower leg had been in a cast for 8 weeks, he found that the right gastrocnemius muscle was significantly smaller in circumference than it was before the fracture. This is due to:

choices.text: Decrease in the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle.
Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast.
Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis.

questions.solution:
Option C: Temporary reduction in actin and myosin protein synthesis

Disuse atrophy:

  • The skeletal muscle continuously remodels in response to the level of its use.
  • For an extensive time, and the muscle is inactive, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.
  • When a muscle remains unused for many weeks, the rate of degradation of the contractile proteins is more rapid than the replacement rate. Therefore, muscle atrophy occurs.
  • The pathway that appears to account for much of the protein degradation in a muscle undergoing atrophy is the ATP-dependent ubiquitin-proteosome pathway. Proteosomes are large protein complexes that degrade damaged or unneeded proteins by proteolysis, a chemical reaction that breaks peptide bonds.
  • Ubiquitin is a regulatory protein that labels which cells will be targeted for proteasomal degradation.

Option A: Decrease the number of individual muscle fibers in the muscle

  • A decrease in blood flow caused by constriction from a cast will result in signs of ischemia well before 8 weeks, e.g., pain, change in color to pale, skin changes, etc.
  • When a muscle loses its nerve supply, it no longer receives the contractile signals required to maintain normal muscle size.

Option B: Decrease in blood flow to the muscle caused by constriction from the cast

  • If a muscle is inactive for an extended time, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.

Option D: Progressive denervation

  • Denervation is any loss of nerve supply regardless of the cause.
  • When a muscle loses its nerve supply, it no longer receives the contractile signals required to maintain normal muscle size. Therefore, atrophy begins almost immediately.
  • After about 2 months, degenerative changes also appear in the muscle fibers. If the nerve supply to the muscle grows rapidly, the full function return can occur in as little as 3 months.
  • The denervation atrophy is followed by the destruction of muscle fibers and replacement by fibrous and fatty tissue leading to contractures.
  • However, in this case, his lower leg has been in a cast for 8 weeks, and his right gastrocnemius muscle is significantly smaller in circumference. If it is for an extended time and the muscle is inactive, the rate of synthesis of the contractile proteins in individual muscle fibers decreases, which results in an overall reduction in muscle mass.

questions.text: A pharmacist is trying to study the pharmacokinetics of a novel drug. He wants to calculate the plasma volume to study the drug distribution volume. He injected 1.5 mL of a solution containing 20 mg/mL of Evans blue dye into plasma; the final concentration of the dye was 0.015 mg/mL. Which of the following is the calculated volume of the plasma?
questions.solution:
Option B: 2L 

  • The volume of plasma = Quantity of dye injected/final concentration of the dye
  • V = Q/c
  • Volume of dye injected = 1.5 * 20 = 30 mg
  • Volume of plasma = 30/0.015 = 2000 mL

questions.text: Which of the following is the basis for referred pain?

choices.text: Visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin synapse with separate populations of neurons in the dorsal horn
Visceral pain transmission and pain transmission from the skin are received by a common set of neurons in the thalamus
Visceral pain signals are rarely of sufficient magnitude to exceed the threshold of activation of dorsal horn neurons
Some visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin provide convergent input to a common set of neurons in the dorsal horn

questions.solution:
Option D: Some visceral pain signals and pain signals from the skin provide convergent input to a common set of neurons in the dorsal horn

  • The convergence of these two types of pain signals onto single spinal cord neurons is the basis for referred pain.

Learning Objective

Referred Pain

  • Definition: Referred pain is the pain that is perceived at a site adjacent to or away from the site of origin. Deep pain and some visceral pain are referred to other areas. But, superficial pain is not referred.
  • Examples of Referred Pain
    • Cardiac pain is felt at inner part of left arm and left shoulder.
    • Pain in ovary is referred to umbilicus.
    • Pain from testis is felt in abdomen.
    • Pain in diaphragm is referred to shoulder.
    • Pain in gallbladder is referred to epigastric region.
    • Renal pain is referred to loin.
  • Causes of Visceral Pain
    • Ischemia: Substances released during ischemic reactions such as bradykinin and proteolytic enzymes stimulate the pain receptors of viscera.
    • Chemical Stimuli: Chemical substances like acidic gastric juice, leak from ruptured ulcers into peritoneal cavity and produce pain.
    • Spasm and Overdistention of Hollow Organs: Spastic contraction of smooth muscles in gastrointestinal tract and other hollow organs of viscera cause pain by stimulating the free nerve endings. Overdistention of hollow organs also causes pain.
  • Visceral pain fibers provide input to anterolateral tract cells that also receive somatic pain from the skin surface.
  • The convergence of these two types of pain signals onto single spinal cord neurons is the basis for referred pain.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man presents with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, and grayish skin pigmentation. A highly elevated level of iron is observed in his liver biopsy report. Which of the following conditions will be most likely found in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: High Serum Ferritin

  • This patient with mild liver disease, arthritis, fatigue, grayish skin pigmentation, and a highly elevated iron level on liver biopsy likely has hemochromatosis.
  • It is an autosomal recessive disorder due to mutation in the histocompatibility region of chromosome 6.
  • Iron absorption is increased from the small intestine resulting in increased serum iron and iron-ferritin complex.

Option A: Low serum Iron

  • A high serum iron will be expected in a patient with hemochromatosis.

Option B: High Serum Copper

  • It is a characteristic finding of Wilson's disease and has no association with hemochromatosis.
  • Wilson's disease presents with Keyser Fleischer ring, neurological symptoms, and liver-related disorders.

Option C: Low saturation of transferrin

  • Hemochromatosis is characterized by high serum iron; as transferrin carries iron in the blood, higher transferrin saturation will also be observed.

questions.text: A newborn presents with severe respiratory distress and has not gained proper weight during the past several weeks. Examination revealed muscle hypotonia and neurological problems and an extremely low level of acetyl CoA carboxylase in liver. The most likely reason for an infant's respiratory problems is:
questions.solution:
• Acetyl CoA carboxylase forms malonyl CoA, in the first step of fatty acid synthesis. The deficiency of this enzyme severely affects the fatty acid synthesis in the patient. In utero, the fetus utilized fatty acids provided from mother. Growth retardation, muscle and neurological problems later occurred due to demand of fatty acid requiring processes
  • In particular, the lungs require surfactant to function properly. Surfactants are lipoproteinaceous substances synthesized in alveolar cells, and are required for gas exchange as they lower alveolar surface tension. It contains significant amounts of dipalmitoyl phosphatidylcholine, the most common surfactant which requires palmitate formed mainly by de novo fatty acid synthesis.
  • None of the other answers listed would result in all of the symptoms given.

questions.text: An enzyme catalyzing the reaction A + E → EA → E + P was mixed with 5 mM substrate concentration (compound A). The initial rate of formation of the product was 25% of Vmax. What is the Km value for the enzyme?
questions.solution:
Option D: 15 mM

  • This problem can be solved using the Michaelis–Menten equation.
  • Michaelis–Menten equation: V= (Vmax x [S]) / ([S] + Km)

Where,

V = velocity of the reaction

Vmax = Maximum velocity

S = Substrate concentration

Km= Michaelis constant

Given that, the velocity (v) = 25% of Vmax, and substrate concentration [S] = 5 mM

So, 25% Vmax = (Vmax × 5)/ (Km + 5)

Or, ¼ = 5/(Km + 5)                                   [as 25% = ¼]

Or, Km + 5 = 20

Or, Km = 20-5

 So, Km = 15mM

The Michaelis-Menten kinetic equation is one of the best-known formulas of enzyme kinetics.

It can determine the kinetics of enzyme-controlled reactions, where the biochemical reaction is supposed to be including a single substrate.

Option A, B and C: Refer to explanation of D

questions.text: Which of the following constitutes the most suitable diagnostic test for confirming the presence of sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
Option D: DNA amplification

  • DNA from the patient's leukocytes can be amplified using polymerase chain reaction (PCR) to obtain sufficient amounts of DNA for hemoglobin genes. The portion of the β-globin gene that harbors the sickle cell anemia mutation can be amplified using specific primers complementary to flanking region of the β-globin gene.
  • After PCR, the product is fixed on a support. Allele-specific hybridization uses two allele-specific oligonucleotides (ASO) probes, one for the normal hemoglobin and defective hemoglobin A mutation (S mutation), will be used. These can reveal the presence of normal (AA alleles), sickle trait (AS alleles), or sickle cell anemia (SS alleles).

Option A: Hemoglobin antibodies

  • These are antibodies that react with hemoglobin.
  • These antibodies are used to detect hemoglobin and used in various scientific applications.
  • They have no relation to sickle cell disease diagnosis.

Option B: DNA restriction

  • A DNA restriction system is used to prevent the introduction of foreign DNA.
  • It is a very useful technique in molecular biology and genetic engineering.
  • It has no use for diagnostic purposes in sickle cell disease.

Option C: DNA Fingerprinting

  • It is a technique to identify a person using the DNA sequence of a particular region unique to every individual.
  • It has no diagnostic value in sickle cell disease.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents to the physician office with a history of arrested developmental growth since age 2, along with impaired cognition and poor vision. On physical examination, he has coarse facial features and a waddling gait. His mother states that he has a history of frequent respiratory infections. Laboratory examination of the child shows increased levels of glycosaminoglycans in urine. All of the following are functions of GAGs except
questions.solution:
Option D: Transport of lipids

  • Glycosaminoglycans are not responsible for the transport of lipids. The lipids are transported in the blood by lipoproteins, e.g., VLDL, LDL, and chylomicrons.
  • Lipoproteins have a lipid core with proteins in the periphery to provide a hydrophilic surface that makes it easy for them to pass through the aqueous blood medium.
  • VLDL and Chylomicrons transport endogenous and dietary TG to the peripheral tissues.
  • HDL and LDL transport cholesterol between peripheral tissues and liver.

Option A: Anticoagulant

  • Heparin is a glycosaminoglycan and is an intracellular component of mast cells that line arteries. It acts as a natural anticoagulant in the body.
  • So, anticoagulation is one of the functions of glycosaminoglycans.

Option B: Wound healing

  • The early phase of wound healing involves the secretion of glycosaminoglycans by fibroblasts. They are responsible for the assembly and stabilization of extracellular matrix. Hyaluronic acid plays a major role in inducing clot formation and facilitating cell migration.
  • HA is commonly used as a therapeutic in a wide range of applications, including osteoarthritis, ophthalmic surgery, cosmetic application and tissue engineering.
  • It may be injected intradermally or it may be used topically. 
  • HA extracts are safe and efficacious products to be used in skin repair

Option C: Lubrication

  • Glycosaminoglycans are negatively charged molecules and tend to repel each other. A shell of water molecules surrounds them, slipping past each other when they are brought closer. This property is responsible for the slippery consistency of mucous membranes and synovial fluid. Hence they act as a lubricant.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents in the emergency with the complaint of watery diarrhea and abdominal pain associated with flatulence after having a banana milkshake 4 hours ago. She has a medical history of undergoing chemotherapy for breast cancer diagnosed 3 months ago. Which enzyme deficiency is the most probable cause of the symptoms described?
questions.solution:
Option B: Beta-galactosidase

  • Beta-galactosidase, aka lactase, is the enzyme located in the brush border of the intestinal cells to digest lactose (in milk and dairy products) into glucose and galactose, which is further absorbed in the blood. The deficiency of beta-galactosidase results in lactose intolerance.
  • Primary lactase deficiency has an absent lactase-persistent allele, and its activity mostly declines after weaning.
  • Secondary lactase deficiency involves the loss of intestinal brush border due to gastroenteritis, autoimmune disease, celiac disease, chemotherapy, inflammatory bowel disease, or secondary intestinal bacterial growth.
  • Undigested lactose causes an osmotic load that pulls water and electrolytes into the bowel resulting in watery diarrhea. Lactose undergoes bacterial fermentation in the colon that produces gas, resulting in excessive bloating, flatulence, and abdominal pain. Nausea and vomiting are also seen.
  • Diagnosis is made primarily on clinical presentation. However, studies involve the following three investigations:
    • The stool demonstrates decreased pH.
    • The lactose hydrogen breath test shows increased hydrogen content. It is the best confirmatory test.
    • The intestinal biopsy will show normal intestinal mucosa in patients with hereditary lactose intolerance. However, cellular damage is imminent in the secondary form of the disease. It is rarely performed due to its invasive nature. It only helps to distinguish between primary and secondary lactase deficiency.
  • The management plan mainly includes a lactose-free diet. Enzyme replacement therapy is also commercially available.

Option A: Alpha-amylase

  • Alpha-amylase catalyzes the hydrolysis of starch into smaller carbohydrate units like maltose. The salivary glands and the pancreas produce it. Salivary amylase is mixed with food in the mouth, where it acts on starch and its function continues for up to several hours in the stomach until the acidic pH of the stomach destroys it. When the food passes the intestines, the pancreatic amylase in the duodenum digests the remaining starch molecules.
  • Alpha amylase deficiency is a sign of disorders in the pancreas or salivary glands. It mostly involves pancreatic insufficiency due to cystic fibrosis or chronic pancreatitis with presentation as malabsorption.

Option C: Alpha-glucosidase

  • Alpha-glucosidase, aka acid maltase, is a lysosomal enzyme breaking glycogen into glucose. Deficiency of this enzyme results in one of the glycogen storage diseases called Pompe's disease (type II GSD).
  • It appears in infants who often die and majorly affects the heart, liver, and muscles. The serum levels of glucose remain normal.
  • Findings include cardiomegaly, enlarged tongue, hypotonia, and liver enlargement. Patients with this disease usually die from hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.
  • Muscle biopsy shows an accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes.

Option D: Sucrase

  • Sucrase is a digestive enzyme responsible for the hydrolysis of sucrose to its subunits, fructose and glucose. It is present on the surface of the intestinal epithelial cells.
  • Deficiency of sucrase is a congenital disorder. The most common symptoms in infants are chronic, watery diarrhea and failure to thrive. Other signs include colic, abdominal swelling, irritability, indigestion, vomiting, and severe diaper rash.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents to the emergency department in an altered state of consciousness. After an extensive workup, blood biochemistry analysis shows a high lactate level and a reduced activity of α- ketoglutarate dehydrogenase. The most likely single enzymatic mutation that leads to these changes would be in which one of the following proteins?

choices.text: The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase
The E1 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase
The E2 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

questions.solution:
Option A: The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

  • The E3 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase, the dihydrolipoyl dehydrogenase activity (with bound FAD), is identical to α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
  • Mutation in this subunit would lead to an accumulation of pyruvate (because pyruvate dehydrogenase activity is reduced), and the accumulated pyruvate is converted to lactate.

Option B and C: The E1 and E2 subunit of pyruvate dehydrogenase

  • The E1 and E2 subunits of pyruvate dehydrogenase are unique to pyruvate dehydrogenase, and are not shared with any other enzymes,
  • So defects in these subunits will lead to lactic acidemia but would not affect α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.

Option D: Lactate dehydrogenase

  • A defect in lactate dehydrogenase would result in an inability to produce lactate, So will not cause lactic acidemia.

questions.text: A 42-year-man presents to the office for a follow-up visit. He was diagnosed with a urea cycle defect with very high blood glutamine and ammonium ion concentrations. The physician advises him to undergo phenylbutyrate treatment. Phenylbutyrate has which of the following effect on the patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Scavenges nitrogen

In all urea cycle disorders, there is the accumulation of NH3 (hyperammonemia) which is very toxic and has to be removed. Urea cycle disorders can be treated using:

1. Scavenging agents: 

  • One of the treatments for urea cycle disorder is using NH3 scavenging agents.
  • These are Phenylbutyrate and Sodium benzoate.
  • Phenylbutyrate reacts with glutamine to convert into phenyl acetyl glutamine which can be excreted.
  • Sodium benzoate provides an alternate path for elimination of NH3 a it combines with glycine to form hippuric acid which can be excreted by kidneys.

 

Other methods to treat urea cycle disorders:

  • Give Arginine (1st line Treatment):  Arg is an essential amino acid that provides ornithine (required in 2nd step of the urea cycle). It is also an activator of NAGS (which activate urea cycle). But it is contraindicated in Arginase deficiency.
  • Restrict protein intake to 50% of normal

Option B: Activates enzymes

  • Phenylbutyrate acts as a nitrogen scavenger and is not involved in the activation of enzymes.

Option C: Maintains renal output

  • Phenylbutyrate has no role in maintaining renal output in the body.

Option D: Maintains energy production

  • The maintenance of energy production is not controlled by phenylbutyrate.

questions.text: A patient who is diagnosed with a deficiency of acetyl-CoA carboxylase will not be able to produce which of the following is an essential building block for fatty acid synthesis.
questions.solution:
Option C: Malonyl-coenzyme A

The above given is a case disorder of acetyl Co-A carboxylase deficiency

  • Acetyl-CoA carboxylase deficiency will result in decreased fatty acid synthesis leading to growth delay, myopathy, and muscular hypotonia. Fatty acid synthesis requires malonyl-coenzyme A (CoA), a 3-carbon unit, as the active donor of carbons. In the first step of the fatty acid synthesis, malonyl-CoA is formed by carboxylation of acetyl-CoA by the enzyme acetyl-CoA carboxylase, using biotin as a cofactor.

  • One molecule of acetyl-CoA is joined with one molecule of carbon dioxide aided by ATP. Malonyl-CoA is utilized in fatty acid biosynthesis by the enzyme MCAT (malonyl-CoA: acyl carrier protein trans acylase), which transfers malonate from malonyl-CoA to the terminal thioester on the acyl carrier protein.
  • Malonyl-CoA is also an important Regulatory factors in the fatty acid synthesis/degradation pathway.

Option A: Ketone bodies

  • Ketone bodies are used for providing energy to the extrahepatic tissue such as the brain, skeletal muscles, and heart.
  • Ketone bodies are extrahepatically converted into acetyl CoA, which produces energy through Kreb’s cycle.

Option B: Glycerol-3-phosphate

  • It is used glycolysis or gluconeogenesis and lipid synthesis.
  • It is not essential for the building block of fatty acids.

Option D: 5-Adenosylmethionine

  • It is used for the transfer of methyl group, aminopropylation, and transsulfuration.
  • It helps to catalyze or produce serotonin, dopamine, and melatonin.

questions.text: Among the following options, which serves as the indirect estimate of Lipoprotein-X?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cholestasis

Lipoprotein 'x' is an abnormal lipoprotein found in the sera of the patient in two conditions:

  1. LCAT deficiency.
  2. Cholestatic states, e.g., 1o biliary cirrhosis and 1o sclerosing cholangitis.
  • Sclerosing cholangitis patient is mostly middle-aged women with severe itching on the body and elevated GGTP, alkaline phosphate, and elevated bilirubin liver. MRCP is the most accurate test and is treated with cholestyramine.

  • A case of primary sclerosing cholangitis with lipoproteinemia.

Characteristics of Lipoprotein "x."

  • Rich in amphipathic lipids (PL & Cholesterol) ·
  • Poor in neutral lipids (TG & cholesterol ester).
  • Density lies between LDLD and VLDL.
  • Protein present is albumin (major) + variable apoproteins (small amount).
  • In an electron microscope, it gives an onion-like vesicular appearance.

Option A: Hepatitis

  • Hepatitis is caused by the hepatitis B virus, and it is an inflammation of the liver.
  • The other causes include alcohol use, fatty liver disease, and toxicity.

Option B: Myocardial infarction

  • Myocardial infarction can be caused by atherosclerosis.
  • Coronary artery occlusion can lead to a decreased oxygen supply to the myocardium.

Option D: Atherosclerosis

  • Atherosclerosis is a disease in which fat or cholesterol plaques form in arteries which can block the blood flow.
  • Rupture of blocked arteries can cause cardiac disease such as cardiac stroke.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the outpatient department due to fatigue, paroxysmal dyspnea, and orthopnea. His past medical history is significant for hypertension for 15 years, for which he takes amlodipine. His family history is insignificant. An ECG reveals left axis deviation, and echocardiogram shows left ventricular hypertrophy. Hypertrophy can occur in cardiac, skeletal and smooth muscles. Which of the following does not represent the example of smooth muscle hypertrophy as an adaptive response to the relevant situation?

choices.text: Urinary bladder in urine outflow obstruction

questions.solution:
Option C: Triceps in body-builders

  • Hypertrophy means excessive growth of the size of individual cells due to over synthesis of structural protein.
  • It can be both physiological and pathological.
  • Examples of physiological hypertrophy include:
  • Uterus during pregnancy
  • Breast during puberty, pregnancy, and lactation
  • Skeletal muscles during exercise
  • Examples of pathological hypertrophy include:
  • Cardiac hypertrophy in hypertensive patients
  • Intestinal hypertrophy before stricture/narrowing.
  • Skeletal, smooth, and cardiac muscles can undergo hypertrophy.
  • The enlargement of the triceps is an example of skeletal muscle hypertrophy (not smooth muscle hypertrophy).

Option A: Urinary bladder in urine outflow obstruction

  • The urinary bladder has a smooth muscle that undergoes smooth muscle hypertrophy due to volume overload, secondary to obstruction.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

Option B: Gall bladder in chronic cholecystitis

  • The gall bladder is lined by smooth muscle, which undergoes hypertrophy in response to chronic cholecystitis.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

Option D: Uterus enlargement during pregnancy

  • During pregnancy, uterine smooth muscles undergo hypertrophy resulting in a 20-fold increase in the size of the uterus.
  • The question is regarding skeletal muscle therefore this is an incorrect option

questions.text:
An autopsy of the heart of an 85-year-old male who died of congestive heart failure 3 years ago has been performed, which shows the following findings as shown below:



What is the predominant type of collagen found in the specimen of the heart?
questions.solution:
Option A: Type I

  • Type I collagen predominates in the mature scar tissue.

Maturation phase of remodelling:

  • Collagen is remodelled from type III to type I, and the wound fully closes.
  • The cells used to repair the wound but no longer needed are removed by apoptosis or programmed cell death.
  • The collagen laid down during the proliferative Phase is disorganised, and the wound is thick.
  • Collagen is remodelled into a more organised structure along the lines of stress, thereby increasing the tensile strength of the healing tissues. Fibroblasts secrete matrix metalloproteinases.
  • The enzymes facilitate the remodelling of type III collagen to type I collagen.
  • Generally, remodelling begins about 21 days after an injury and can continue for a year or more.
  • Even with cross-linking, healed wound areas continue to be weaker than uninjured skin, generally only having 80% of the tensile strength of unwounded skin

Option B: Type II

  • Type II collagen is found in the cartilage.
  • The heart, after the injury, either contains type III or type I collagen.
  • Early in the repair, the dominant collagen is type III, which is gradually replaced by type I collagen as the repair continues.

Option C: Type IV

  • Type IV collagen is found in the basement membrane of the lungs and the kidney.
  • It is affected by disorders such as thin membrane disease, Alport syndrome and Good Pasteur syndrome.

Option D: Type V

  • Type V collagen is present in the vessels.
  • It is usually affected by Ehler-Danlos syndrome.

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with motor-dominant sensorimotor polyneuropathy, erectile dysfunction, and urinary incontinence. Transthyretin gene mutation was noted in genetic evaluation. The sural nerve biopsy specimen showed focal oedema and an amyloid deposit in the sub-perineural tissue, associated with moderate loss of myelinated and unmyelinated fibres. Which of the following disease is being described here?
questions.solution:
Option B: Familial amyloidosis polyneuropathy

  • Transthyretin (TTR) is a normal serum protein that binds and transports thyroxine and retinol.
  • Several distinct mutant forms of TTR (and its fragments) are deposited in a group of genetically determined disorders referred to as Familial Amyloid Polyneuropathies.
  • Normal TTR is also deposited (due to overproduction) in the heart of aged individuals (Senile Systemic Amyloidosis).

Option A: Familial Mediterranean fever

  • Familial Mediterranean fever is a genetic disorder that causes recurrent episodes of fever with
    • Abdominal pain
    • Chest discomfort
    • Joint pains.

Option C: Dialysis-associated amyloidosis

  • Age-related amyloidosis is mainly seen in chronic kidney disease and dialysis patients.
  • This patient has no chronic kidney disease, so this option is eliminated.
  • It is the main type of systemic amyloidosis.

Option D: Prion protein-associated amyloidosis

  • Prion diseases are our group of infectious, fatal, sporadic and genetically determined diseases in which prion protein PrP is accumulated in the nervous system of humans and mammals.

questions.text: A 14-year-old tall man has been presented to the clinic to get vaccinated for tetanus after falling in the park. Upon physical examination, the physician notices that he has long arms and legs with huge hands and feet. On further examination, sparse pubic and facial hair are noted along with gynecomastia. The size of his testes was also small. His mother reveals that he also has some learning disabilities. Which of the following chromosomal complement is most likely present in this male?
questions.solution:
Option C: 47, XXY

  • Klinefelter syndrome has an Extra X chromosome, so they are 47 XXY.
  • It mainly affects the male population
  • Some clinical features are:
    • Sparse pubic and facial hairs
    • Hypogonadism [rudimentary testes]
    • Disproportionately long arms and legs.
    • Gynecomastia
    • Small testes
    • Low Intelligence quotient

Option A: Trisomy 21

  • Trisomy 21 (often known as Down's syndrome) is the most frequent chromosomal abnormality.
  • Some clinical features are:
    • A flattened face, especially the bridge of the nose
    • Almond-shaped eyes that slant up
    • Low set ears
    • Small hands and feet
    • A single line across the palm (palmar crease)
    • Short stature
  • Intellectual impairment

Option B: 46, XY

  • In Swyer syndrome, individuals have one X chromosome and one Y chromosome in each cell, which is the pattern typically found in boys and men; however, they have female reproductive structures. 
  • People with Swyer syndrome have female external genitalia and some female internal reproductive structures.
  • These individuals usually have a uterus and fallopian tubes, but their gonads (ovaries or testes) are not functional.
  • Instead, the gonads are small and underdeveloped and contain little gonadal tissue.

Option D: 45, XO

  • Turner's syndrome results from a chromosomal anomaly (45, XO). 
  • In older children and adults with Turner syndrome, short stature and webbing of the neck are commonly seen.
  • The thorax is broad, with increased distance between the nipples.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient is brought by her mother with complaints of fever and cough for the last two days. She has been mentally disabled since birth. She is morbidly obese and has narrow shoulders. Upon further tests, maternal disomy of chromosome 15 is seen. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Prader-Willi syndrome

  • The case mentioned above is about a mentally disabled child whose clinical features of obesity and narrow shoulders suggest Prader-Willi syndrome.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome is an example of genetic imprinting where the phenotype depends on whether the deletion occurs on a gene inherited from the mother or father.
  • Prader-Willi syndrome: if gene deleted from father.
  • Angelman syndrome: if gene deleted from mother.
  • PWS (Prader-Willi syndrome) could be present because of the following:
    • Deletion of paternal chromosome 15
    • Uniparental disomy of maternal chromosome15
    • SNORP mutation
  • Prader-Willi syndrome (PWS) is a genetic disorder occurring in 1 of 10,000–16,000 live births. It is characterised by excessive appetite, massive progressive obesity, short stature, and mental retardation.
  • The majority of individuals have hypogonadotropic hypogonadism and GH deficiency.
  • The cause of obesity is thought to be increased levels of ghrelin

Option B: Klinefelter syndrome

  • Extra X chromosome = Klinefelter syndrome( 47 XXY).
  • Klinefelter syndrome is a condition in which male hypogonadism occurs when there are two or more X chromosomes and one or more Y-chromosomes.
  • It is one of the most common genetic causes of infertility.

Option C: Angelman syndrome

  • When a child receives duplicate copies of chromosome #15 from the father, Angelman syndrome may develop(rather than one from the mother and one from the father).
  • It is not the common genetic cause of infertility.
  • Angelman syndrome occurs if the gene is deleted from the mother.

Option D: Turner syndrome

  • Turner syndrome is the most common cause of primary amenorrhea.
  • Its Karyotype is XO.

questions.text: A 9-year-old girl who is a known case of thalassemia visits to undergo a blood transfusion. Post transfusion, the patient has mildly elevated body temperature and generalized pruritis. Ideally, which of the following should be transfused in children suffering from thalassemia?
questions.solution:
Option C: Saline washed packed RBC

  • Saline-washed RBCs are specially indicated in conditions requiring repeated transfusion.
  • It is advised that washed, leukocyte-poor red blood cells (RBCs) be transfused over 1-2 hours at a rate of 8-15 mL RBCs per kg of body weight.
  • It is preferred in the management of babies suffering from thalassemia and paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria.

Option A: Packed RBC

  • It is generally indicated in patients with very low blood haemoglobin levels, but for those requiring repeated transfusion, the saline-washed form is far safer.

Option B: Platelet-rich plasma

  • Transfusing platelets to a patient with a very low haemoglobin level secondary to thalassemia is not an appropriate option and would not yield any benefit.

Option D: Whole blood

  • It is indicated in the following cases:
    • Massive haemorrhage
    • Coagulopathy
    • Rapid correction of anaemia

questions.text: A 37-year-old male, who works as a coolie, complains of easy fatigability and recurrent Upper respiratory tract infections for the past 2 months. Physical examination reveals numerous petechiae over his body and mouth. The patient is a known case of Gouty Arthritis on medications. He also claims the usage of over-the-counter drugs for his body malaise. Abnormal laboratory findings include haemoglobin of 5.8 g/dL, WBC of 1,200/mL, and platelets of 18,000/mL. On further investigations, a diagnosis of Aplastic anaemia was made. Which of the following drugs are associated with the condition described above?
questions.solution:
Option D: All of the above 

  • Chlorpromazine, Allopurinol, and diclofenac can cause drug-induced aplastic anaemia

Drugs

A. Dose-dependent action – Cytotoxic drugs

B. Idiosyncratic action
  • Antibacterials (Sulphonamides, Chloramphenicol)
  • Anti-inflammatory drugs (Phenylbutazone, Indomethacin, piroxicam, Diclofenac, Naproxen)
  • Antirheumatics (Gold, penicillamine)
  • Antiepileptics (Phenytoin, Carbamazepine)
  • Antithyroids
  • Tranquilizers (Chlorpromazine)
  • Others-Furosemide, Allopurinol

 Option A: Chlorpromazine

  • Tranquilizers (Chlorpromazine) can cause drug induced aplastic anemia

  • As the other options are also associated with aplastic anemia the answer should be option D

  Option B: Allopurinol

  • Allopurinol is used as a treatment for gout

  • Allopurinol can also cause drug induced aplastic anemia

  • As the other options are also associated with aplastic anemia the answer should be option D

  Option C:Diclofenac

  • Diclofenac is an Anti-inflammatory drug

  • It can also cause drug induced aplastic anemia

  • As the other options are also associated with aplastic anemia the answer should be option D

questions.text: Down syndrome is associated with?
questions.solution:
Option C: Promyelocytic leukaemia

  • The above clinical case scenario most likely suggests disseminated intravascular coagulation secondary to Promyelocytic leukaemia
  • The child presented with acute onset of bleeding, along with the following laboratory findings:
    • Thrombocytopenia (35000/mm3 vs. normal value of 1,50,000/mm3)
    • Increased prothrombin time (20s as opposed to 13s in the control)
    • A longer partial thromboplastin time (50s vs. normal 26-32s)
    • Reduced fibrinogen (10 mg/dL vs a normal range of 233-496 mg/dL)

AML:

  • Acute myeloid leukaemia (AML) is a tumour of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow.
  • Replacing the marrow with blasts produces marrow failure and complications related to anaemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia. AML occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age.
  • Most patients present within weeks or a few months of symptoms with complaints related to anaemia, neutropenia, and thrombocytopenia, most notably fatigue, fever, and spontaneous mucosal and cutaneous bleeding.
  • Thrombocytopenia results in abnormal bleeding, which often is prominent.
  • Cutaneous petechiae and ecchymoses, serosal haemorrhages into the linings of the body cavities and viscera, and mucosal haemorrhages into the gingivae and urinary tract are common.
  • Procoagulants and fibrinolytic factors released by leukemic cells, especially in AML with the t(15;17), exacerbate the bleeding tendency. Infections are frequent, particularly in the oral cavity, skin, lungs, kidneys, urinary bladder, and colon, and are often caused by opportunists such as fungi, Pseudomonas, and commensals.
  • Signs and symptoms related to the involvement of tissues other than the marrow are usually less striking in AML than in ALL, but tumours with monocytic differentiation often infiltrate the skin (leukaemia cutis) and the gingiva; this probably reflects the normal tendency of monocytes to extravasate into tissues. Central nervous system spread is less common than in ALL.
  • AML occasionally presents as a localized soft tissue mass known as myeloblastoma, myeloid sarcoma, or chloroma.
  • Without systemic treatment, such tumours inevitably progress to full-blown AML over time.

Option A: Myeloblastic leukaemia without maturation

  • The prognosis of this variant of AML is intermediate.
  • >3% of blasts positive for myeloperoxidase
  • No gums infiltration is seen

Option B: Myeloblastic leukaemia with maturation

  • In this variant, a Full range of myelocytic maturation is seen.
  • However, gums infiltration is absent.

Option D: AML with megakaryocytic maturation

  • In this variant of AML, blasts of megakaryocytic lineage predominate
  • Detected with antibodies against megakaryocyte-specific markers (GPIIb/IIIa or vWF)
  • Often associated with marrow fibrosis
  • Most common AML in Down syndrome

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a medical history of hypertension for ten years presented to the hospital with a three-week history of non-bilious vomiting, fatigue, and weakness. Upon further review of symptoms, it was revealed that he had lost significant weight and had a fever on and off with decreased appetite. Further lab investigations, EGD, and colonoscopy were carried out, which revealed diffuse hemorrhagic gastritis and severe colitis. CT scan abdomen and pelvis showed a cecal mass with localized lymphadenopathy. Histology and immunohistochemistry of biopsied specimens showed mantle cell lymphoma. Which of the following B-cell markers is expressed in mantle cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Option C: Cyclin D1

  • Symptomatic diffuse hemorrhagic gastritis and colitis along with cervical mass and localized lymphadenopathy on CT scan highly suggests mantle cell lymphoma with raised cyclin D1, a B-cell marker.
  • Mantle cell lymphoma is a moderately aggressive NHL that presents in the fifth to sixth decade of life and shows a male predominance.
  • Mantle cell lymphomas have an (11; 14) translocation involving the IGH locus on chromosome 14 and the cyclin D1 locus on chromosome 11 that leads to overexpression of cyclin D1.
  • These lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1, CD19, and CD20 with moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or λ light chain).
  • It is usually CD5 positive and CD23 negative, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL.
  • It most commonly presents with painless lymphadenopathy. Symptoms related to the involvement of the spleen and gut also are common.

Option A: CD23

  • CD23 is primarily B-cell associated antigen and is expressed on activated mature B-cells.
  • Mantle cell lymphoma (MCL) is CD23 negative.
  • CD23 is characteristically expressed in chronic lymphocytic leukaemia (CLL) and small lymphocytic lymphoma (SLL).

Option B: BCL6

  • BCL6 is a transcription factor required for the generation of germinal centre B-cells.
  • The neoplastic cells of follicular lymphoma closely resemble normal germinal centre B-cells, expressing BCL6 along with CD19, CD20, and CD10.
  • About one-third of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma has mutations in BCL6 promoter sequences.

Option D: MYC gene

  • MYC oncogene is a master transcription regulator that increases the expression of genes required for aerobic glycolysis.
  • All forms of Burkitt lymphomas are associated with translocations of the MYC gene on chromosome 8, leading to increased MYC protein levels.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl has been brought to the pediatric clinic by her parents. She has been suffering from tiny cutaneous haemorrhages spread all over her body. She has been recovering for a week from a flu-like condition. Her Physical examination is unremarkable, and she is vitally stable. Her Laboratory investigations revealed a platelet count of 20,000/mL. The number of megakaryocytes in her bone marrow has increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this girl?
questions.solution:
Option D: Idiopathic thrombocytopenic purpura

  • It is a quantitative disorder of platelets caused by antibodies directed against platelet or megakaryocytic antigens.
  • Related to antibody-mediated immune destruction of platelets or their precursors.
  • The peripheral blood smear in ITP exhibits numerous large platelets, and the bone marrow shows a compensatory increase in megakaryocytes.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Petechia
    • Purpura
    • Hemorrhagic bullae
    • Gum bleeding
    • Hematuria
    • Melena
  • Thrombocytopenia may be observed in the other choices but is usually associated with other systemic signs and symptoms.

Option A: Anti-Phospholipid Antibody Syndrome

  • The antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is the most common form of acquired thrombophilia. 
  • Antiphospholipid antibodies include lupus anticoagulant antibodies and anticardiolipin antibodies. 
  • They can occur as a manifestation of various conditions, such as systemic lupus erythematosus and other  rheumatic disease, infections, and drug reactions.
  • Women who sustain recurrent spontaneous abortions or a thromboembolic event during pregnancy should also undergo evaluation for the disorder

Option B: Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation is a rare but serious condition that causes abnormal blood clotting throughout the body's blood vessels.
  • An infection usually follows it.
  • It can present with any of the following:
    • Bleeding at wound sites or from the nose, gums, or mouth
    • Blood in the stool or urine
