    • Bruising in small dots or larger patches on the body
    • Chest pain
    • Pain, redness, warmth, and swelling of the leg

Option C: Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome

  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) is a condition that affects the blood and blood vessels. It results in: 
    • destruction of blood platelets (cells involved in clotting)
    • a low red blood cell count (Anemia)
    • kidney failure due to damage to the tiny blood vessels of the kidneys
  • However, in this case, the triad is not present

questions.text: A 67-year-old male patient was brought to the emergency with complaints of blood and mucus mixed stools and tenesmus. The patient was pale and hemodynamically unstable. A colonoscopy was done, and a biopsy was taken. HPE showed a signet ring appearance. The barium meal study is shown in the image. Based on epidemiological studies, which of the following is most protective against the given disease?
questions.solution:
Option A: High-fiber diet

ENVIRONMENTAL FACTORS & THEIR ASSOCIATED RISK TO CAUSE COLON CANCER:  
INCREASED RISK PROTECTIVE FACTORS
  • High intake of dietary lipids
  • Pelvic irradiation
  • Streptococcus bovis endocarditis
  • Ureterosigmoidostomy
  • High-fibre diet [Most protective]
  • NSAIDs
  • Hormone Replacement Therapy [HRT]

Option B: Low-fat diet

  • A low-fat dietary pattern does not reduce the risk of colorectal cancer.

Option C: Low selenium diet

  • One dietary element that may improve colon cancer risk is selenium.
  • Selenium is a trace element abundant in grains, wheat, dairy products, meat, and fish. The RDA for selenium is 55 micrograms per day for women and 70 micrograms per day for males.
  • Therefore, a high selenium diet can improve the risk of colorectal cancer.

Option D: Low protein diet

  • To meet their caloric demands, colon cancer patients should keep hydrated and consume healthful meals high in proteins, vitamins, antioxidants, and electrolytes.
  • Therefore, a high-protein diet is recommended for colon cancer patients.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the OPD with complaints of joint pain, rash on face, palm and shin, and weight loss. There is radiographic evidence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and interstitial lung disease. A lung biopsy gives findings similar to those shown in the figure. Which of the following is a major characteristic of this disorder?

choices.text: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

questions.solution:
Option C: Hypercalcemia

  • The presence of asteroid bodies in the large cell, which can be seen in the image, and the clinical presentation of the patient are both necessary components in making a diagnosis of sarcoidosis.
  • Around sixty per cent of the granulomas have laminar concretions within their giant cells. These concretions are called Schumann bodies and are made up of calcium and proteins. Stellate inclusions, also called Asteroid bodies, can also be seen within giant cells.
  • Both polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia and hypercalcemia are common abnormal laboratory findings in this condition. Hypercalcemia is caused by increased calcium absorption as a secondary effect of the production of active vitamin D by the macrophages that form the granulomas.
  • Polyclonal hypergammaglobulinemia is caused by increased levels of polyclonal hypergammaglobulin.
  • Granulomas are often connected with high levels of calcium in the blood.
  • People of African descent have a substantially higher prevalence of the illness than people of any other origin.

Option A: A positive test for tuberculin

  • A positive test for tuberculin is indicative of tuberculosis infection.
  • It has a poor sensitivity for sarcoidosis.

Option B: Highest incidence in persons of Asian lineage

  • The highest incidence of sarcoidosis is in persons of African lineage.

Option D: Hypogammaglobulinemia

  • There are increased levels of polyclonal hyper gamma globulin in sarcoidosis.
  • Hypogammaglobulinemia is seen in patients with immunodeficiency, nephrotic syndrome, and hematologic malignancy.

questions.text: A female, age 27, came to the hospital for a routine checkup. She has a history of smoking 20 cigarettes a day. Which of the following conditions is she maximally predisposed to?
questions.solution:
Option D: Squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts

  • Squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts (ZUSKA DISEASE)
  • Smoking is responsible for causing squamous metaplasia of lactiferous ducts.
  • The key feature is keratinizing squamous metaplasia of the nipple ducts.
  • Keratin shed from these cells plugs the ductal system, causing dilation and, eventually, rupturing the duct.
  • An intense chronic granulomatous inflammatory response develops once keratin spills into the surrounding periductal tissue.

Option A: Acute mastitis

  • Mastitis is an infection-related inflammation of the breast tissue that causes pain, swelling, warmth, and redness in the breasts.
  • You might also have a fever and chills. Mastitis most commonly affects women who are breastfeeding (lactation mastitis).
  • Symptoms:
    • They include a swollen area on the breast that may feel hot and painful to touch – the area may become red but then be harder to see if the patient has darker skin. A wedge-shaped breast lump or a hard area on the breast. Burning pain in the breast might be constant or only when breastfed.
  • Mastitis treatment might involve:
  1. Antibiotics: Antibiotics are typically prescribed for a 10-day treatment if you have an infection.
  2. Pain relievers. The doctor may recommend an over-the-counter pain reliever, such as acetaminophen (Tylenol, others) or ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin IB, others).

Option B: Granulomatous mastitis

  • Granulomatous lobular mastitis (GM) is a persistent, inflammatory, and frequently idiopathic breast disease. Because it can resemble cancer, it is important, is often difficult to diagnose, and, despite being a benign condition, its locally aggressive nature causes long-term pain and distress for affected patients.
  • Granulomatous mastitis can be divided into idiopathic and granulomatous mastitis, occurring as a rare secondary complication of a great variety of other conditions such as tuberculosis and other infections, sarcoidosis, and granulomatosis with polyangiitis.
  • The etiology of idiopathic granulomatous mastitis is still obscure. Its treatment remains controversial. The cause may be the autoimmune process, infection, a chemical reaction associated with oral contraceptive pills, or even lactation.
  • All GM treatment is symptomatic like it is for the common cold. There is no cure, and surgery is rarely indicated.

Option C: Fat necrosis

  • The death of tissue is fat necrosis; it can be due to injury and loss of blood supply. It can occur from trauma or as a complication of surgery. It can cause hard lumps to form under the skin, resembling tumours. However, it is harmless and usually goes away on its own.
  • A benign (noncancerous) disorder called fat necrosis most frequently appears after trauma or injury to the breast tissue.
  • A lump may develop when fatty breast tissue is injured, such as during a biopsy or surgery. A medical term for damaged or dead tissue is necrosis.
  • Fat necrosis usually does not need treatment and will go away on its own in time. If you have pain or tenderness around the lump, over-the-counter anti-inflammatory medications like ibuprofen (Advil, Motrin) can help.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient complained of an oral tumour. His chief complaint was painful swelling in the anterior gingiva, which made eating difficult. He noticed the swelling 6 months back in the upper anterior gingiva, which progressively increased in size and gradually involved the entire gingiva of both arches. The patient visited a local dentist, and oral prophylaxis was performed. No clinical changes were evident post-prophylaxis, and the lesion attained the present size within 7 days. For the previous 7-8 years, he chewed tobacco and lime 5-6 times a day, occasionally drinking alcohol. Microscopic and Immunohistochemical findings lead to the diagnosis of Lymphoma. Which of the following gene is associated with the pathology of the disease discussed here?
questions.solution:
Option D: C-myc

Burkitt lymphoma

  • Thus EBV alone does not cause Burkitt lymphoma. However, in patients with subtle or overt immune dysregulation (e.g., due to chronic malaria), unchecked B cell proliferation may lead to additional mutations (including the t[8;14] translocation) to replicate autonomously.
  • B-cell lymphomas in immunosuppressed patients (e.g., AIDS patients and transplant recipients) can be associated with EBV.
  • These patients have polyclonal B-cell proliferation that transforms into monoclonal lymphomas.
  • In transplant recipients, withdrawal of immunosuppressive drugs can cause regression of such EBV-induced proliferation.
  • Hodgkin lymphoma is associated with EBV.
  • Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is endemic in southern China and some other locales; the EBV genome is found in all such tumours, and LMP-1 is implicated in driving cell proliferation. As in Burkitt lymphoma, EBV probably acts in concert with other factors to induce malignant transformation.

Option A: APC

  • The APC protein functions as a tumour suppressor, preventing excessive or uncontrolled cell growth and division.
  • It aids in regulating a cell's capacity to divide, its relationship to other cells within a tissue, and whether or not it moves close to or far from the tissue.
  • Adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) is a gene that suppresses tumour growth. If the APC gene is defective, it becomes unstable and more susceptible to additional changes that may lead to colon and rectal cancers.
  • Tumour suppressor genes stop cells from growing out of control, which could lead to malignant tumours. The APC gene produces a protein essential for various cellular processes that control a cell's potential to become a tumour.

Option B: p53

  • Cancer protein P53 refers to any isoform of a protein encoded by homologous genes in different organisms, such as TP53 (humans) and Trp53 (animals). It is also known as the Guardian of the Genome, cellular cancer antigen p53 (UniProt name), the phosphoprotein p53, tumour suppressor p53, antigen NY-CO-13, and P53 (mice).
  • The p53 proteins, once believed to be a single protein and frequently referred to as such, are essential in vertebrates because they inhibit cancer development.
  • The p53 gene is typically altered, producing a stable mutant protein whose accumulation is thought to be a characteristic of cancer cells.
  • Mutant p53 proteins not only lose their tumour-suppressive activities but often gain additional oncogenic functions that endow cells with growth and survival advantages.

 

Option C: Rb

  • The RB1 gene contains the information needed to produce the pRB protein. This protein controls cell growth and prevents cells from dividing too quickly or uncontrolled, acting as a tumour suppressor.
  • Consistent with its diverse functions, Rb inactivation can lead to increased cell proliferation or cell death.
  • Therefore, while Rb inactivation often promotes cancer development, this may also open up certain vulnerabilities of such cancers to certain drug interventions.
  • As a result, retinal cells devoid of a functional pRB can proliferate uncontrolled and develop into malignant tumours.

questions.text: Macrophage activation occurs in 2 different pathways; Classical and Alternative pathways. According to different pathogens causing the disease, the pathways differ. Among the given options, which of the following leads to the activation of macrophages via the classical pathway?
questions.solution:
Option A: IFN-ϒ

  • Gamma interferon activates macrophages via the classical pathway.

IFN- ϒ

  • Classically activated macrophages arise in response to interferon-γ (IFNγ), which can be produced during an adaptive immune response by T helper 1 (TH1) cells or CD8+ T cells (not shown) or during an innate immune response by natural killer (NK) cells, and tumour-necrosis factor (TNF), which is produced by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).
  • Wound-healing (alternatively activated) macrophages arise in response to interleukin-4 (IL-4), which can be produced during an adaptive immune response by TH2 cells or during an innate immune response by granulocytes.
  • Regulatory macrophages are generated in response to various stimuli, including immune complexes, prostaglandins, G-protein coupled receptor (GPCR) ligands, glucocorticoids, apoptotic cells, or IL-10.
  • Each of these three populations has a distinct physiology. Classically activated macrophages have microbicidal activity, whereas regulatory macrophages produce high levels of IL-10 to suppress immune responses.
  • Wound-healing macrophages are similar to the previously described alternatively activated macrophages and have a role in tissue repair. TLR, Toll-like receptor.

Option B: IL-4

  • IL4 is involved in the activation of macrophages via an alternative pathway.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: IL-13

  • IL13 is involved in the activation of macrophages via the alternative pathway
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option D: IL-1

  • IL1 does not activate macrophages.
  • Rather it is an osteoclast activation factor and plays a major role in the fever.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A forty-three-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of a lesion on his left hand. Examination of the dorsal surface of his left-hand shows a scaly erythematous lesion. A skin sample of the lesion shows abnormal keratinocytes covering the entire epidermis thickness. The arrows indicate apoptotic bodies in the image below. In this patient's skin cancer, which of the following proteins plays the most critical role in mediating programmed cell death?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cytochrome C

  • This patient has squamous cell carcinoma of the skin.
  • Cytochrome C is a critical regulator of apoptosis present in the mitochondrial membrane.
  • It seeps out of mitochondrial pores and activates apoptotic protease activating factor-1 (APAF-1).
  • APAF-1 converts procaspase-9 to caspase-9, causing downstream caspases to be activated (cysteine proteases).
  • These effector caspases break various target proteins, such as endonucleases, nuclear proteins, and cytoskeletal proteins, to orchestrate the morphological and biochemical changes that occur during apoptosis.

Option A: Catalase

  • Catalases through reactive oxygen species can cause cell death but do not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

Option C: Cytokeratin

  • Cytokeratin is a protein found in epithelial cells.
  • It is not associated with apoptosis.

Option D: Myeloperoxidase

  • Myeloperoxidase, through reactive oxygen species, can cause cell death but does not cause planned cell death.
  • Therefore this option is incorrect

questions.text: A 53-year-old man complains of cough, weakness, and fever for four days. Pneumonia is diagnosed, and gentamicin is part of the treatment plan. Gentamicin has a half-life of 2-3 hours but can accumulate in the kidney with prolonged dosing, leading to a prolonged half-life of 53 hours. What type of half-life is this?
questions.solution:
Option B: Terminal half-life

  • In the case given, the older man presents with fever, cough and fatigue. He is diagnosed with pneumonia and given gentamicin, an aminoglycoside antibiotic, for its treatment.
  • Gentamicin is an antibiotic with bactericidal activity against gram-negative bacteria.
  • Generally speaking, with prolonged dosing, a drug may penetrate beyond the central compartment into secondary body compartments that equilibrate only slowly with the plasma.
  • The drug will then be cleared from the plasma. Still, it will eventually drop to a point at which net diffusion from the secondary compartments begins, and this slow pseudo-equilibration will produce a prolongation of the half-life, referred to as the terminal half-life.
  • Terminal half-life is the time required for a drug to reach half its concentration after reaching pseudo-equilibrium.

Option A: Secondary half-life

  • If the half-life increases with decreasing concentration, it is called the secondary half-life.

Option C: Zero-order half-life

  • If the half-life decreases linearly with the concentration, then it is known as a zero-order half-life.

Option D: First-order half-life

  • It is the time needed to reach half of the concentration of the drug.

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman with a history of recreational oxycodone use presents with irritability, nausea, and diarrhea, 48 hours after her last dose. Physical examination reveals mydriasis, rhinorrhea, and piloerection. Why does a drug similar to oxycodone, but without euphoria, provide different effects?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lower efficacy

  • Drug efficacy (correlates with Emax) is the maximum degree to which a drug activates receptors after binding and triggers a cellular response.
  • On an efficacy graph, the difference in efficacy of the two drugs is determined by the difference in the maximal effect exerted by each of them (shown on the y-axis); drugs with different efficacy will have different heights, with the difference in efficacy represented on the y-axis. 
  • Not related to potency (drugs with a high efficacy can have a low potency).
  • Partial agonists are less efficacious than full agonists.
  • A drug that acts as a partial agonist acts at the same site as a full agonist but has lower efficacy.
  • Administration of a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine, which has lower efficacy than a full opioid μ-receptor agonist (e.g., morphine), can help alleviate the unpleasant side effects of opioid withdrawal without causing euphoria.

Option A: Lower bioavailability

  • Bioavailability is the ratio of a given drug reaching systemic circulation.
  • Regarding oral drugs, bioavailability depends on the first-pass effect (in the liver) and individual absorption rates. Intravenously administered drugs have a bioavailability of 1.
  • Orally administered drugs are not fully absorbed from the GI tract and undergo first-pass metabolism, which results in lower bioavailability than medications administered intravenously.
  • However, lower bioavailability would not explain why a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine does not produce the same euphoric effect as a full opioid μ-receptor agonist.

  • The blue line shows the concentration of a substance administered intravenously (IV) over time, and the red line shows the concentration of a substance taken orally.
  • The ratio of the area under the curve (AUC) of the orally administered substance to the AUC of the IV substance yields a substance's bioavailability (F).

Option B: Lower potency

Potency (EC50):

  • The potency of a drug is measured as the concentration required to produce a pharmacological response of a specified intensity. 
  • Not related to efficacy (drugs with a high potency can have a low efficacy) but dependent on affinity.
  • EC50 = the effective concentration required to produce 50% of the maximum possible response (Emax).
  • A left shift of the curve is a sign of decreased EC50 and increased potency, meaning a lower concentration of the drug is needed.
  • EC50 is not to be confused with ED50; ED50 is the median effective dose that produces a desired beneficial effect in 50% of the population.
  • ED50 = 5 mg implies that the administration of 5 mg of the drug achieves the desired effect in 50% of the studied population

  • The same drug may have different ED50 values based on the indication (e.g., aspirin has different ED50 values for headache and for thromboembolism prophylaxis).

Option D: Lower affinity

Drug affinity:

  • Drug affinity is a measure of the tendency of a drug to bind to its receptor.
  • Most drug-receptor bonds are reversible.
  • Covalent drug-receptor bonds, which are less common, are almost always irreversible (e.g., the binding of aspirin to cyclooxygenase enzyme)
  • Affinity describes how well a drug is capable of binding to its receptor. A drug with low affinity for its receptor would require a higher dose to exert the same effect as a pharmacodynamically similar, high-affinity drug.
  • Lower affinity would not explain why a partial opioid μ-receptor agonist like buprenorphine does not produce the same euphoria as a full opioid μ-receptor agonist. Buprenorphine has an extremely high receptor affinity (higher than morphine), which causes it to displace other opioids.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency with vomiting, dizziness, and abdominal cramps for 8 days. His relatives also told the doctor that he has been going for urination very infrequently and has had frequent loose, watery stools for 4 days. On examination, his BP is 80/50, and his lips and eyes are dry. The doctor prescribes a medicine to the patient. What was the medicine, and what is its dose in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Dopamine 15mcg/kg/min

  • This scenario indicates that the patient has oliguria due to hypovolemic shock.
  • Hypovolemic shock is an urgent medical condition in which severe loss of blood or fluids can cause multiple organ failure. Hypovolemic shock leads to inadequate circulating volume and subsequent inadequate perfusion.
  • Oliguria is a condition which presents with low urine output due to various reasons. In this case, the patient is in hypovolemic shock due to diarrhoea and dehydration, which is causing oliguria.
  • Dopamine is an endogenous catecholamine with neurotransmitter activity. If given in a dose of 15mcg/kg/min, it will act on alpha receptors of the smooth muscle of blood vessels, causing vasoconstriction, which helps in oliguria and hypovolemic shock. It is the first line of medicine in patients with shock.

Option A: Dopamine 1mcg/kg/min

  • Dopamine is a neuromodulatory molecule which can help in oliguria in low doses.
  • If dopamine is given in a concentration of less than 2mcg/kg/min will cause vasodilation of renal, cerebral, and splanchnic blood vessels due to stimulation of dopaminergic receptors on their smooth muscle.

Option C: Nor epinephrine 2mcg/kg/min

  • Nor epinephrine is an endogenous neurotransmitter which stimulates alpha 1, 2, and beta 1 adrenoreceptors.
  • 2-4mcg/kg/min is the maintenance dose in case of acute hypotension and cardiac arrest. It induces vasoconstriction and a decrease in renal and visceral blood flow.

Option D: Nor epinephrine 10 mcg/kg/min

  • In the case of cardiogenic shock, 8-12 mcg/kg/min is the initial dose given.
  • It is used to treat shock because it increases vascular resistance and therefore increases blood pressure. Other actions of norepinephrine are not significant.

questions.text: What centrally acting pro-drug converted to its active form in the brain might be prescribed for a patient discharged after experiencing fluctuating blood pressure following delivery?
questions.solution:
Option B: Methyldopa

  • Clinical signs: headache, fever, vomiting, four episodes of convulsions, and high blood pressure on admission suggest eclampsia, which is a medical emergency to deal with immediate effects, and after that, methyl dopa is only the pro-drug which gets converted in the brain.
  • The centrally acting anti-hypertensive drugs in the scenario are methyldopa and clonidine.
  • Only methyl dopa is the centrally acting pro-drug, and conversion of methyl dopa to α-methyl norepinephrine takes place in the brain.
  • Methyldopa is a drug for controlling mild to moderate hypertension in pregnancy.
  • Methyldopa may lower blood pressure by causing central inhibition of alpha-adrenergic receptors, false neurotransmission, and reduced plasma renin activity.
  • It is used in both hypertension and hypertensive crisis.
  • Other centrally acting anti-hypertensives are
    • Guanfacine
    • Guanabenz

Option A: Clonidine

  • Clonidine is a centrally-acting anti-hypertensive drug.
  • Its action stimulates central alpha receptors, causing reduced sympathetic outflow and decreased peripheral vascular resistance, heart rate, and blood pressure.

Option C: Minoxidil

  • Minoxidil is also a prodrug.
  • Minoxidil is activated to minoxidil sulfate (by phase II reaction) in the periphery and not in the brain.

Option D: Nitroprusside

  • Nitroprusside relaxes the smooth muscle vasculature to reduce afterload and preload by producing nitric oxide.
  • Sodium nitroprusside is used in the following conditions.
    • Hypertensive crisis
    • Acute heart failure
    • Controlled hypotension during surgery

questions.text: A 45-year-old presents to the ER with nausea, lethargy, weakness, anorexia, tremors, abnormal breathing, and confusion over six weeks. The basic workup shows significant hyponatremia. Further tests confirm the Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone (SIADH). What's the optimal next management step?
questions.solution:
Option C: Restriction of free water intake

  • Restriction of free water intake is the first step in the management of SIADH.

 

Option A: Conivaptans

  • Conivaptan is not the best next step in the management of SIADH.
  • It can be given in patients when SIADH is not controlled by water restriction.

Option B: Desmopressin

  • Desmopressin is an antidiuretic hormone (ADH) and will exacerbate the symptoms of SIADH.
  • Demeclocycline decreases the release of ADH.

 

Option D: 3% NaCl

  • Hypertonic saline is not the first step in the management of SIADH
  • Hypertonic saline (3%NaCl) is used for severely symptomatic patients with hyponatremia or serum Na<120 meq/L

questions.text: A 59-year-old woman comes to the physician because of a 1-month history of episodic cough and shortness of breath. The cough is nonproductive and worsens when she climbs stairs and at night. She has not had chest pain or palpitations. Eight weeks ago, she had an episode of fever, sore throat, and nasal congestion. She has a 10-year history of hypertension. She has smoked half a pack of cigarettes daily for 16 years. Her only medication is enalapril. Her pulse is 78/min, respirations are 18/min, and her blood pressure is 145/95 mmHg. Pulse oximetry on room air shows an oxygen saturation of 96%. Diffuse end-expiratory wheezes are heard on pulmonary auscultation. An x-ray of the chest shows no abnormalities. Spirometry shows a FEV1:FVC ratio of 65% and an FEV1 of 60%. The patient is given a salbutamol inhaler.. Which of the following is NOT a likely adverse effect of salbutamol in this woman?
questions.solution:
Option C: Hypoglycemia

  • This patient with a 1-month history of episodic dyspnea, coughing and wheezing that worsens during exertion and at night likely has new-onset asthma.
  • Spirometry showing an obstructive lung pattern (↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio) supports this diagnosis.
  • Unlike COPD, asthma is characterized by an obstruction that is reversible with the administration of bronchodilators. A post-bronchodilator test showing an increase of FEV1 of ≥ 12% (or 200 mL) confirms the diagnosis of asthma.
  • The treatment of asthma involves the use of beta-agonist drugs such as salbutamol.

Option A: Tremor

  • Tremor is the commonly observed side effect of beta-agonist drugs.

Option B: Tachycardia

  • Tachycardia is the commonly observed side effect of the beta-agonist drugs

Option D: Hypokalemia

  • Hypokalemia is also a well-established adverse effect of salbutamol.

questions.text: A 44-year-old male presents to the clinic complaining of loose, watery stools and vomiting for the past two days. There were eight episodes for the past two days. The stool was watery and yellowish, and did not contain blood or mucus content. There was no history of abdominal pain, fever, or jaundice. On examination, the patient was lethargic. His blood pressure measured 100/60 mmHg, and his pulse rate was 80 beats per minute. Abdominal examination was unremarkable. The patient was given intravenous fluid and was prescribed diphenoxylate and atropine. Which of the following is the mechanism of atropine in this particular case?

choices.text: Augment the anti-motility action of diphenoxylate
Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

questions.solution:
Option D: Discourage overdose and abuse of diphenoxylate

  • This is a case of diarrhoea in which the patient presents with complaints of loose, watery stools and vomiting for 2 days.
  • Diphenoxylate/atropine combination is used in the management and treatment of diarrhoea. Diphenoxylate is an anti-motility drug. Large doses of diphenoxylate cause euphoria.
  • Diphenoxylate is an opioid agonist that acts on presynaptic opioid receptors (mu receptors) in the enteric nervous system.
  • It acts on presynaptic opioid receptors resulting in blockage in the release of acetylcholine. This results in the inhibition of peristaltic contractions and the secretory action of enteric cells.
  • The drug does not have analgesic effects at standard doses, but at higher doses, it can lead to euphoria-like states. Therefore, the drug can be misused.
  •  Atropine is added in combination with diphenoxylate to discourage overdosage.
  • Atropine is a competitive inhibitor of acetylcholine receptors, thus, preventing diphenoxylate overuse.
  • Atropine, when given in high doses, causes nausea, bloating, tachycardia, and dryness of mouth and eyes. These adverse effects are unpleasant and intolerable to the patient.

Option A: Suppress associated vomiting of gastroenteritis

  •  Drugs used for suppression of vomiting are:
    • Dopamine antagonists – metoclopramide, prochlorperazine
    • Serotonin antagonists – ondansetron
    • Corticosteroids – dexamethasone
    • Anticholinergics – hyoscine
    • Benzodiazepines – lorazepam
    • Antihistamines – doxylamine

Option B: Augment the anti-motility action of diphenoxylate

  • Drugs used for decreasing the motility of the gut are as follows;
    • Loperamide
    • Bismuth subsalicylate
    • Probiotics
    • Diphenoxylate/atropine

Option C: Block side effects of diphenoxylate

  • The adverse effects of diphenoxylate are;
    • Respiratory and CNS depression
    • Worsens dehydration and electrolyte imbalance in patients with pre-existing electrolyte imbalance.
    • Precipitates toxic megacolon in patients with ulcerative colitis.
    • Causes allergic reactions – anaphylaxis. Urticarial.

questions.text: A 67-year-old female patient seeks evaluation at the clinic for her debilitating symptoms.. She has had hot flashes and urinary incontinence for the past few months. Her last menstrual cycle was 13 years ago. She is obese. After careful evaluation, a diagnosis of postmenopausal changes has been made. The attending doctor adds progestin to estrogen replacement therapy for 10-12 days each month. Which of the following is the primary reason for adding a progestin component to this patient's regimen?

choices.text: Blocks the increased risk of myocardial infarction due to estrogen
Blocks the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to estrogen
Reverses vulval atrophy occurring in post menopausal women
Enhances the metabolic benefits of estrogen treatment

questions.solution:
Option B: Blocks the increased risk of endometrial carcinoma due to estrogen

  • The addition of progesterone is usually recommended for postmenopausal women to decrease the stimulatory effect of estrogen on the endometrium.
  • Estrogen increases the risk of endometrial carcinoma by stimulating the growth of the endometrium. 
  • Health benefits of combining estrogen with progesterone:
  • Lower risk of developing endometrial and ovarian carcinoma; probably colorectal cancer.
  • Reduced menstrual blood loss and associated anaemia; cycles, if irregular, become regular; premenstrual tension, dysmenorrhoea and menorrhagia are ameliorated.  
  • Endometriosis and pelvic inflammatory disease are improved. 
  • Reduced incidence as well as symptomatic relief of fibrocystic breast disease and ovarian cysts

Option A: Blocks the increased risk of myocardial infarction due to estrogen

  • Progestin does not prevent the increased risk of myocardial infarction associated with estrogen.

Option C: Reverses vulval atrophy occurring in postmenopausal women

  • The estrogen component is very important in reducing the risk of vulvar atrophy.
  • However, progestin does not affect vulvar atrophy reversal.

Option D: Enhances the metabolic benefits of estrogen treatment

  • The metabolic effect of estrogen is countered by progesterone
  • While estrogen replacement therapy can have metabolic benefits, such as improving lipid profiles and bone health, the primary reason for adding a progestin component is not to enhance the metabolic benefits of estrogen treatment.

questions.text: A 7-year-old female child was watching the TV and suddenly, for 5-6 seconds, gave a blank stare at the television. The mother noticed her taring oddly and tried to call out her name, to which she responded after a few seconds. Which of the following medications should be prescribed?
questions.solution:
Option D: Valproate

  • The occurrence of absence seizures characterises Petit mal epilepsy.
  • These show characteristic 3Hz spike-and-wave patterns on electroencephalography.
  • Valproate is the first-line drug for absence seizures in India.
  • Other drugs effective against absence seizures are ethosuximide, clonazepam and lamotrigine.
  • Valproate is the drug of choice for
    • Generalised tonic-clonic seizures
    • Myoclonic seizures
    • Atonic seizures
    • Absence seizures
    • Clonic seizures
    • Tonic seizures
    • Lennox Gastaut syndrome

Option A: Ethosuximide

  • Ethosuximide is an anti-epileptic drug that works by blocking thalamic T-type Ca2+ channels.
  • It is commonly used for absence seizures or petit mal epilepsy, but it is not the first-line drug in India.

Option B: Carbamazepine

  • Carbamazepine is an anticonvulsant drug primarily used to treat epilepsy and neuropathic pain.
  • Carbamazepine treats trigeminal neuralgia and can also benefit peripheral neuropathy of diabetic origin.
  • It is also used as adjunctive therapy in schizophrenia and a second-line drug in bipolar disorder.

Option C: Phenytoin

  • Phenytoin is an anti-epileptic drug which functions by blocking Na+ channels.
  • It is mainly used in the treatment of focal (partial) seizures.
  • It is also used as the 1st line drug for prophylaxis of recurrent status epilepticus.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman, known for breast carcinoma, presents with epistaxis, hematuria, and easy bruising after completing her first cycle of chemotherapy. What's the recommended drug for her next cycle?
questions.solution:
Option D: Oprelvekin (IL-11)

  • In this case, a 65 years old woman presented with signs and symptoms of chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia. Complaints of epistaxis, hematuria and easy bruising with multiple petechiae all over the body pointing towards thrombotic disorder. She is a known case of breast carcinoma and has already received the first cycle.
  • Oprelvekin can be used to treat and prevent chemotherapy-induced thrombocytopenia.
  • Oprelvekin acts like a megakaryocyte colony-stimulating factor and promotes thrombopoiesis.
  • It also promotes the development of neurons and the synthesis of acute-phase proteins from the liver.

Option A: Darbopoietin alpha

  • It is a re-engineered form of erythropoietin.
  • Kidneys produce erythropoietin.
  • In chronic renal failure, erythropoietin production is reduced and needs to be supplemented from the outside.

Option B: Filgrastim

  • Filgrastim (G-CSF) and sargramostim (GM-CSF) are used to prevent leucopenia.
  • It has been used with antibiotics for treating chemotherapy-induced febrile neutropenia.

Option C: Iron dextran

  • Iron dextran (i/v or i/m) is used in iron deficiency anaemia.
  • In chronic kidney disease patients, IV iron is superior to oral iron for increasing haemoglobin concentration.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is associated with a high risk of pseudomembranous colitis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Clindamycin

  • Clindamycin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis (via inhibition of translocation).
  • It is effective against anaerobic organisms.
  •  .
  • It is secreted in bile, therefore, can be used safely in patients with renal dysfunction.

Option A: Clarithromycin

  • The risk of pseudomembranous colitis with clarithromycin is very less as compared to clindamycin.

Option C: Minocycline

  • The risk of pseudomembranous colitis with minocycline is very less as compared to clindamycin.

Option D: Fidaxomicin

  • The risk of pseudomembranous colitis with fidaxomicin is very less as compared to clindamycin.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male undergoing Whipple’s procedure suddenly becomes rigid. His temperature rises to 104º F. The anaesthetist identifies it as a case of malignant hyperthermia. He starts the treatment with a skeletal muscle relaxant. Which of the following describes the correct mechanism of action for the skeletal muscle relaxant?

choices.text: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings
Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential
Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

questions.solution:
Option D: Reduces calcium release from the sarcoplasmic reticulum in the muscle fibre

  • Dantrolene is a skeletal muscle relaxant which resembles centrally acting muscle relaxants.
  • It acts by uncoupling muscle contractions from membrane depolarization.
  • It acts on the ryanodine receptor (RyR1) receptor located on the sarcoplasmic reticulum to reduce calcium release through these channels in the skeletal muscles.
  • As calcium ions are not released into the cytoplasm, the excitation-contraction coupling does not occur.
  • Fast-contracting muscles are more affected than slow-contracting muscles.
  • It is the preferred drug for malignant hyperthermia, which occurs due to the persistent release of calcium ions from the sarcoplasmic reticulum initiated by fluorinated anaesthetics.
  • Adverse effects include muscle weakness, sedation, malaise, light-headedness, and dose-dependent liver toxicity.

Option A: Reduces acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings

  • Hemicholinium, botulinum toxin, aminoglycosides, magnesium, and calcium ions reduce acetylcholine release from motor nerve endings.

Option B: Suppresses spinal polysynaptic reflexes

  • NMDA antagonists and tizanidine inhibit spinal polysynaptic reflexes.

Option C: Inhibits the generation of muscle action potential

  • Neuromuscular blocking drugs (muscle relaxants) such as tubocurarine, pancuronium, doxacurium, succinylcholine, and suxamethonium block and inhibit the generation of the muscle action potential.

questions.text: A 33-year-old woman has been admitted to the hospital with a history of feeling lethargic and unwell for the last 2 days. She has 3 episodes of vomiting and diarrhea. She has noticed that her lips and tongue are swollen, and she feels shortness of breath. She was given IM adrenaline by the ambulance staff for a threatened airway and transferred to the hospital. Which of the following is the virulence factor for this given condition?
questions.solution:
Option B: Pyrogenic exotoxin

  • The above condition is called as Streptococcal Toxic shock syndrome, which is due to Pyrogenic exotoxin.

Virulence factors of Streptococcus:

  • M protein
  • Lipoteichoic acid: Helps in adhesion
  • Polysaccharide capsule
  • Toxins:
    • Hemolysins (Streptolysin O, Streptolysin S)
    • Erythrogenic toxin
  • Enzymes
    • Streptokinase: Facilitate spread of infection
    • DNA: Serous nature of exudate
  • M protein: Basis of Griffith typing inhibits phagocytosis.
  • Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome:
    • Caused by S. pyogenes.
    • Caused by SPE (Streptococcal pyrogenic exotoxin)/ Erythrogenic toxin/Dick/ Scarlet toxin.
    • 3 Types: A, B, C.
      • Type A and C: Super-antigens
      • Type A and C: Bacteriophage coded.
      • B toxin: Chromosomal mediated.
  • The erythrogenic toxin is responsible for-
    • Scarlet fever
    • Necrotizing fasciitis. (Refer to the image below)
    • Streptococcal toxic shock syndrome.

 

Option A: M protein

  • M protein: Basis of Griffith typing inhibits phagocytosis
  • M protein is a significant virulence factor that is expressed on the surface of S. pyogenes and is involved in a variety of streptococcal infections, including:
  • the invasion of epithelial cells
  • resistance to phagocytosis
  • adhesion to epidermal keratinocytes
  • microcolony formation.

Option C: Streptolysin O

  • Streptolysin O:
  • Streptolysin-O: Oxygen labile.
  • Antistreptolysin-O antibodies (ASO): a standard marker for retrospective diagnosis of Streptococcal infections (except in glomerulonephritis and pyoderma, where ASO titer is low).

Option D: Carbohydrate cell wall

  • Lancefield’s grouping (for β hemolytic streptococci):- Based on carbohydrate antigen in the cell wall in Streptococcus.
  • β hemolytic Streptococci are further divided into 20 serogroups: Group A to V except for I and J.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents to the ENT outpatient department with complaints of sore throat and swelling of the neck for one week. The patient has no history of any chronic illness. The patient is vitally stable. On examination, there is pseudo membrane and bull neck formation. On culture examination, Gram-positive bacilli were seen in a cuneiform pattern of the arrangement. The toxigenicity of the causative organism of this condition is due to:
questions.solution:
Option A: Beta phage

  • This is a case of diphtheria in which the patient presents with complaints of sore throat and swelling of the neck.
  • The toxigenicity of Corynebacterium diphtheriae is due to beta phage.
  • Diphtheria Toxin production depends on:
    • Phage code: Diphtheria Toxin is coded by β corynephage carrying tox gene → toxigenic.
    • Iron concentration: Toxin production depends on optimum iron concentration (0.1 mg per litre).
    • Mechanism of Action of diphtheria toxin:
      • Strong exotoxin.
      • Has two fragments:
        • Fragment A (active unit)
          • Fragment A is internalized into the host cells and then causes→ ADP ribosylation of elongation factor 2(EF2) → Inhibition of EF2 → Irreversible inhibition of translation step of protein synthesis→ cell death.
        • Fragment B (binding unit)
          • Binds to the host cell receptors (such as epidermal growth factor)
          • Helps in the entry of fragment A.
  • DT repressor gene (DtxR)
    • Iron-dependent negative regulator of Diphtheria Toxin production and iron uptake in C. diphtheriae.

 

Mcleod's classification​​​​​​​

  • Based on colony morphology on Tellurite medium and properties like biochemical reactions and severity of disease, C. diphtheriae is divided into three biotypes with their toxigenicity as follows:
    • All strains of gravis
    • 95–99% strains of intermediate
    • 80–85% of mitis strains are toxigenic
    • Best Selective media of C. diphtheriae: Blood tellurite agar
    • However, toxins produced by different biotypes are antigenically similar.

Option B: Lambda phage

  • Lambda phage also causes toxicity.
  • It is the reason for E.coli toxicity.

Option C: Gamma phage

  • Gamma phage specifically lyses vegetative cells of Bacillus anthracis and serves as part of the basis for the identification of isolates from agar cultures.

Option D: Delta phage

  • The toxicity of C. Diphtheria is not due to delta phage.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female patient comes to the physician complaining of fever and chills for the past 3 weeks. He also complains of loss of appetite, back pain, headache, excessive sweating, weakness, and fatigue. After investigation, the doctor diagnosed her with a case of Malta fever. Which of the following is associated with the causative agent of Malta fever?

choices.text: Migratory arthralgia and myalgia can be present
A nasopharyngeal or an oropharynx swab is sent for Gram stain

questions.solution:
Option B: Migratory arthralgia and myalgia can be present

Malta fever:

  • This patient is a case of Malta fever.
  • Its causative agent is Brucella melitensis.
  • Gram-negative, non-motile, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped (coccobacillus) bacteria.
  • Its clinical features are
    •  The classical triad of undulant fevers
    •  Sweating often with a characteristic foul, mouldy smell, sometimes like wet hay.
    • Migratory arthralgia and myalgia.

Option A: Gram-positive, motile, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped (coccobacilli) bacteria

  • Brucella is a Gram-negative, non-motile, non-spore-forming, rod-shaped (coccobacillus) bacteria.

Option C: A nasopharyngeal or an oropharynx swab is sent for Gram stain

Confirmatory test:

  • Blood culture in biphasic blood culture media.
  • Biphasic media [Solid & liquid culture media]
  • It is used to minimize contamination in Subcultures.
  • The ratio of blood & culture fluid → 1:10
  • Glucose Broth is taken as Culture Fluid
  • Add ERYTHRITOL → Stimulates Brucella growth
  • Catalase, Oxidase and Urease Positive
  • Serological Test:
    • SAT → Standard Agglutination Test → Detects IgM Ab
    • 2 Mercaptoethanol Test → Done for IgM Ab
    • PCR for Brucella species

Option D: Treated by macrolides

  • For the treatment of brucellosis Drug of Choice is:

    • Rifampicin + Doxycycline (WHO)
    • Streptomycin + Doxycycline

questions.text: A 26-year-old girl presents to the clinic with itching on her scalp hair. She explains that it seems like a gritty sensation and as if something is crawling. On examination, white to tan gelatinous, pearly nodules are seen surrounding the hair shaft. On further history taking, the girl reports that she ties the wet hair with a band. Which of the following is the causative agent of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: Trichosporum beigelli

  • In the clinical scenario above, the girl has presented with white piedra, a rare fungal infection caused by a yeast-like fungus called Trichosporum beigelli.
  • The piedra infection of the hair is characterized by firm, irregular nodules along the hair shaft. These nodules are composed of fungal elements cemented together on the hair.
  • There are two varieties of piedra:
  • Black piedra caused by Piedra hortae 
  • White piedra caused by Trichosporum beigelii
  • Clinical findings of white piedra include white to tan gelatinous pearly nodules surrounding the hair shaft.
  • These nodules may develop on any area of the body, such as scalp hair, mustaches, beard, eyelashes, eyebrows, armpit, and pubic hair.
  • Other findings are brittle hair, hair that feels gritty, and itching.
  • Trichosporum is found mainly in soil or dirty water.
  • Piedra is diagnosed by examining the hair shaft and the nodules.
  • The treatment is to shave off all infected hair completely. Other treatment options include antifungal creams, shampoos, and oral antifungal medications.
  • Practices that can lead to colonization and result in white piedra infection include infrequent bathing, poor personal hygiene, bathing in stagnant water, matted hair, covering wet hair, excessive sweating, and long hair.
  • The diagram below illustrates the white piedra.

Option A: Piedra hortae

  • It is a dermatophyte and causes a superficial fungal infection called black piedra.
  • It exists in soil and grows very slowly, forming dark hyphae.
  • Black piedra causes the formation of black nodules on the hair shaft and leads to the gradual weakening of the hair.
  • It usually infects the hair on the scalp and beard.

Option B: Aspergillus

  • It is an opportunist fungus that forms an aspergilloma in the lungs, especially in the cavities that have been affected by tuberculosis.
  • It can cause dissemination to other organs in immunocompromised individuals and is also responsible for allergic bronchi pulmonary aspergillosis.
  • Aspergillus exist only as moulds and have septate hyphae that form V-shaped dichotomous branches.

Option C: Candida

  • It is a yeast-like fungus resulting in candidiasis, an opportunistic mycosis.
  • Lesions (thrush) may occur in healthy individuals' oral and vaginal mucous membranes. However, in immunocompromised hosts, the disease can be widespread.
  • It can also result in endocarditis in IV drug abusers.
  • Candida is an oval yeast with a single bud, but it may appear as yeasts or pseudohyphae in tissues.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male soldier presents with complaints of being plagued by a painful, erosive lesion near his earlobe since his return from his duty in the desert area. The patient is otherwise vitally stable, and other general physical examinations reveal no abnormalities. The punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals macrophages distended with oval amastigotes. Which of the following is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
Option C: Leishmania donovani

  • This is a case of Leishmaniasis in which the patient presents with complaints of a painful, erosive lesion near his ear lobe since his return from his duty in the desert area.
  • Leishmania donovani is the causative organism for Leishmaniasis
  • Sandfly (Genus Phlebotomus) transmits Leishmaniasis (caused by Leishmania Donovani).

Leishmania:

  • L. donovani → Causes Kala Azar [Vector → Phlebotomus (Sand Fly)]
  • L. Tropica → Causes Oriental sore/ Delhi boil or Baghdad boil/ Aleppo button
  • L. Brasiliense → Causes Espundia [Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis]
  • Punch biopsy of the leading edge of the erosion reveals macrophages distended with flagellar amastigotes, also known as Leishman Donovan bodies. Refer to the image below.

Option A: T. brucei

  • Trypanosoma brucei leads to sleeping sickness.
  • It is transmitted by the tsetse fly (Glossina species).

Option B: T. Cruzi

  • Trypanosoma cruzi: Reduviid bugs (Triatomine).
  • It can cause Chagas disease.

Option D: Plasmodium vivax

  • Plasmodium vivax is transmitted by female anopheles.
  • It causes malaria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male presents with complaints of runny nose, headache, high-grade fever and chills to the outpatient department. He also complains of full body aches but more in the upper limb. On examination, there is a rash on his face too. The doctor suspected a viral infection and sent his blood sample to the laboratory to confirm the causative organism. The microbiologist used cell lines for isolation. Which of the following virus is not a cultivable virus?
questions.solution:
Option B: Parvovirus B-19

  • Parvovirus B-19 is not a cultivable virus.
  • Human B19 and human bocaviruses are difficult to grow.
  • The infection cannot be detected by virus isolation.
  • Laboratory diagnosis is made by demonstration of specific IgG and IgM antibodies in the serum.
  • Features of Parvoviruses (Human parvovirus B19):
  • Smallest of the DNA viruses belonging to the family Parvoviridae.
  • Icosahedral, non-enveloped viruses.
  • It is a single-stranded DNA.
  • It Shows tropism for erythroid progenitor cells.
  • It causes an aplastic crisis in patients with sickle cell anemia.
  • It is associated with;
  • NIHF (Non-immune hydrops fetalis).
  • Polyarthralgia syndrome- pain is more in upper limb joints than in lower limb joints.
  • Erythema infectiosum /5th disease- slapped cheek appearance.

Option A: Papova

  • Papova virus can be isolated by using cell lines.
  • They are small enveloped double DNA viruses.

Option C: Herpes

  • HEP-2 cell line is used for isolation.

Option D: Adenovirus

  • The primary human embryonic kidney cell line and A 549 cell lines are the most susceptible cell lines for isolation.
  • HEp-2 and HeLa cell lines can also be used

questions.text: A patient visited the hospital with non-specific symptoms like high-grade fever, headache, muscle weakness, mild cough, rash, and joint pain. On further examination, his temperature is 100 degrees Fahrenheit, and maculopapular rash on the trunk and all limbs and tremors were noted. The patient gave a history of a recent trip to South Africa. The physician suspected it to be an arboviral infection, so he advised an antibody test, showing IgM positive and IgG negative, depicting a current infection. Which of the following is true regarding arboviral infections?

choices.text: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent faeces
The bite of a wild animal causes KFD
Yellow fever is transmitted by Anopheles mosquito

questions.solution:
Option A: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is caused by inhalation of rodent faeces

Hantaviruses:

  • It is found worldwide.
  • Cause two serious and often fatal human diseases: 
    • Hemorrhagic fever with renal syndrome
    • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome (HPS)
  • Rodents are the reservoirs for Hantaviruses.
  • The virus infections in rodents are lifelong and without deleterious effects.
  • Transmission to humans occurs by inhaling aerosols of rodent excreta (urine, faeces, and saliva).
  • Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome is generally severe, with reported mortality rates of 30% or greater.
  • The disease begins with fever, headache, and myalgia, followed by rapidly progressive pulmonary oedema, often leading to severe respiratory compromise.

Option B: The bite of a wild animal causes KFD

  • The bite of wild animals does not cause Kyasanur forest disease.
  • KFD is caused by the Kyasanur Forest Disease Virus (KFDV), which belongs to the family of Flaviviridae.
  • Hard ticks (Hemaphysalis Spinigera) are the reservoirs for KFDV, so tick bites spread the disease.
  • Rodents, shrews and monkeys are the hosts for this virus.
  • KFD appears suddenly after 3-8 days of exposure.
  • It is diagnosed by PCR.
  • Supportive treatment is usually enough to treat the disease.
  • The vaccine is available for KFDV.

Option C: Lyssavirus is transmitted by ticks

  • The bite of an infected animal transmits lyssaviruses.
  • These viruses contain two types; Rabies Virus and Australian Bat lyssavirus.
  • The viruses are potentially fatal. Symptoms start as flu-like, progressing to paralysis, delirium, convulsions and death.
  • In case of a bite with an infected animal, the patient is advised to wash the wounds immediately, apply antiseptic and seek medical help.
  • Unfortunately, there is no treatment once the symptoms appear.

Option D: Yellow fever is transmitted by Anopheles mosquito

  • Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes or Haemagogus mosquitoes.
  • Anopheles spreads malarial diseases.
  • Yellow fever starts with fever, chill, backache, and myalgias.
  • Serious illness includes jaundice, haemorrhage, shock, organ failure and death.
  • Travellers are advised to get the vaccination before going.

questions.text: A 46-year-old woman underwent orthotopic liver transplantation from a 57-year-old cadaveric donor for end-stage liver disease caused by biliary cirrhosis. The biliary anastomosis was accomplished with a choledochojejunostomy. The transplant operation was technically difficult, but after this procedure, the patient became quite stable. What is the role played by major histocompatibility complex proteins (MHC-1 and MHC-2)?

choices.text: Transduce the signals to T cells following antigen recognition
Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors

questions.solution:
Option C: Present antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors

  • MHC presents antigens for recognition by T cell antigen receptors.

Major histocompatibility Complex:

  • MHC molecules or human leukocyte antigens (HLA) serve as a unique identification marker for every individual, as the genetic sequence of MHC genes is different for every individual.
  • The genes on chromosome 6th (6p21) are clustered in three regions named MHC regions- I, II, and III.
  • MHC class I presents endogenous antigens, while MHC class II presents exogenous antigens.

Biologic Importance of MHC:

  • MHC molecules bind to peptide antigens and present them to T cells.
  • Thus, these transplantation antigens are responsible for antigen recognition by the TCR (T cell receptors).
  • The TCR only recognizes antigens presented by MHC molecules on the APC (antigen-presenting cells).
  • The TCR is also specific to the MHC molecule.

MHC restriction:

  • If the antigen is presented by another allelic form of the MHC molecule in vitro, there is no recognition by the TCR.
  • Peptide antigens associated with class I MHC molecules are recognized by CD8+ cytotoxic T lymphocytes, whereas class II-associated peptide antigens are recognized by CD4+ helper T cells.

  • Immunoglobulin class-switching is determined by the constant region of the H chain (CH).
  • Immunoglobulin class-switching is mediated by cytokines released from T cells, IL-4, IL-5, IFN-γ, and transforming growth factor-beta (TGF-β).

Option A: Transduce the signals to T cells following antigen recognition

  • This is regulated by the signal transduction pathway.
  • This pathway is initiated by antigen receptors and costimulatory molecules.

Option B: Mediate immunoglobulin class-switching

  • It is a biological mechanism that changes B cells' production of immunoglobulins from one type to another.

Option D: Enhance the secretion of cytokines

  • Lipopolysaccharides of bacteria enhance the secretion of cytokines.

questions.text: An 86-year-old male presents to the physician with a complaint of a non-healing foot ulcer for 1 month. He has been a known case of DM for 8 years. The patient also complained that he has been taking different antibiotics for a long time for his foot ulcer, but the medications had no results. The doctor suspected drug resistance. Which of the following statements is true regarding drug resistance in this case?

choices.text: In mutational drug resistance, one drug resistance at a time is seen
Virulence is decreased in transferable resistance
Drug combinations cannot prevent Mutational drug resistance
Low degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance

questions.solution:
Option A: In mutational drug resistance, one drug resistance at a time is seen

  • This is a case of diabetic foot in which the patient presents with complaints of a non-healing foot ulcer for 1 month.
  • The diabetic foot is a serious condition, if left untreated, can lead to amputation of the affected region.
  • The patient has used multiple drugs which are ineffective.
  • This is most likely due to drug resistance.

Transferable drug resistance:

  • Example of conjugational transfer
  • The r factor (or the resistance factor) is a plasmid that has two components.
    1. The resistance transfer factor (RTF):The plasmid responsible for conjugational transfer (similar to the F factor)
    2. Resistance determinant (r):Codes for resistance to one drug. An R factor can have several r determinants.
    • RTF + r = Resistance
    • Leads to MDR [Multidrug resistance] → Difficult to treat
    • Mutational drug resistance → Single drug resistance → Easy to Rx

Option B: Virulence is decreased in transferable resistance

  • Virulence is increased in transferable resistance and is decreased in mutational drug resistance.

Option C: Drug combinations cannot prevent mutational drug resistance

  • Mutational drug resistance can be prevented by drug combinations, while combinations of drugs can't prevent transferable drug resistance.

Option D: Low degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance

  • A high degree of resistance is seen in transferable drug resistance. A low degree of resistance is seen in mutational drug resistance.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male with acute intestinal obstruction was operated on in the emergency department. During surgery, blood spilt on the floor. The patient is a known case with a history of 20 pack years. The designated worker is asked to clean the floor. Before cleaning, the worker is asked to check the phenol coefficient of the disinfectant. What does the phenol coefficient indicate in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Efficiency of a disinfectant

  • The patient is most likely suffering from intestinal obstruction.
  • The phenol coefficient indicates the efficiency of a disinfectant.
  • Testing of disinfectants:
    • Phenol coefficient test/radial  walkers test:
      • Determined by dilution of disinfectant.
      • The efficiency of a disinfectant is compared with that of phenol.
      • Used to sterilise suspension of salmonella typhi in given time divided by dilution of phenol which fixes break in the same time.
      • If the phenol coefficient > 1 → disinfectant is better than phenol.
      • The greater the phenol coefficient, the more the disinfectant's efficiency.
      • Phenol coefficient test = highest dilution of test disinfectant that kills S. Typhi in a given time is divided by the highest dilution of phenol that kills salmonella typhi in a given time.
      • It doesn't assess the presence of organic waste.
    • Chick martin test:
      • Modification of ideal walker co-efficient test.
      • Checks whether disinfectant works in the presence of organic waste (faeces),  yeast to simulate natural conditions.
    • Capacity test [kelsey sykes test]:
      • The capacity of a disinfectant to retain its activity when repeatedly used microbiologically increases load.
    • In use test [kelsey & Maurer test]:
      • The disinfectant is microbiologically contaminated.
      • Routinely performed in hospitals once in 3 months.

Option B: Dilution of a disinfectant

  • It is the indication of the addition of another solution in phenol.

Option C: Quantity of a disinfectant

  • Quantity means how much disinfectant is used. Quantity is an important factor here for the process of disinfectant.

Option D: Purity of a disinfectant

  • Purity is the output results after its use. Purity is an important factor here for the process of disinfectant.

questions.text: The 25-year-old man was one of the victims of the recent hate crime. During the autopsy of the victim, the wound on the forehead was observed to have a patterned abrasion and a stellate laceration. What clue about the range of shots does that give to the examining doctor?
questions.solution:
Option A: Contact shot

  • The stellate wound is a characteristic of a contact wound.

Option B: Close shot

  • The body lies within the range of flame, smoke and powder blast, i.e. within 2–3 inches (5–8 cm).
  • The entry wound is small and circular in shape having inverted and contused lacerated margins.

Option C: Range within 60 cm

  • Tattooing becomes discrete as the range increases, no trace of powder marks will be found when the range is beyond 24 inches, i.e. normally beyond arm’s length.
  • For handguns, powder tattooing extends to a maximum distance of 18–24 inches (45–60 cm).

Option D: Distant shot

  • Gunshot entry wounds with no associated soot or gunpowder stippling are referred to as ‘distant’ wounds, i.e. range is beyond 2 feet.
  • The entry wound is usually circular in shape, smaller than the bullet, because of the elasticity of the skin, with lacerated, inverted skin margins, a bigger dirt collar and the usual zone of an abraded collar.

questions.text: While examining the body of a 35-year-old man, which was found by some trekkers in the dense center of the forest, the forensic pathologist noticed a finding that he documented as the first internal sign of putrefaction. Where in the body would the doctor have noticed the above-mentioned change?
questions.solution:
Option A: In mediastinum

Internally, the first site of reddish-brown discolouration is the aortic intima (located in medistinum)

The first external sign of putrefaction is the greenish discolouration in the right iliac fossa.

questions.text: Intermarriage between first cousins is actually not considered "incest" in Westeros society. A prominent example is that Tywin Lannister married his own first cousin Joanna Lannister, mother of all three of his children. But incest is a great cultural taboo both in the Seven kingdoms and the lands beyond the Wall. Alongside kinslaying and the violation of guest rights, incest is proscribed by every major religion in Westeros. Children born of incest are deemed abominations. What is the act, which is termed Incest?
questions.solution:
Option A: Intercourse with blood relation

  • Sexual intercourse by a man with a woman who is closely related to him by blood or by marriage (prohibited degrees of relationship). It is not a criminal offense.

Option B: Intercourse with children

  • Pedophilia: Sexual attraction to prepubescent children.

Option C/D: Intercourse with friends/ Intercourse with a married woman

  • Lesbianism/sapphism/Tribadism: Female homosexuals.
  • Adultery: Intercourse with a married woman, other than his spouse. It is Not liable for criminal prosecution but can be used as a ground for divorce or dissolution of marriage.

questions.text: Marking nuts are black heart-shaped and have a thick, cellular pericarp that contains an irritant juice that is brownish, oily, and acrid but turns brown on exposure to air. Applied externally, the juice causes irritation and a painful blister that contains acrid serum which causes eczematous eruptions of the neighboring skin with which it comes into contact and there is itching. What is the scientific name of this plant poison which causes such an "Artificial bruise"?
questions.solution:
Option B: Semicarpus anacardium

  • Semicarpus anacardium: The fruit of this plant is known as ‘marking nut’ or ‘bhilawa’ as its juice is used by washerman/laundries to inscribe identification number on the clothes.
  • Active Principles: Semecarpol and bhilawanol.
  • Bruise-like lesion with small blisters may be seen near the angle of the mouth or lips. Blisters are also seen in the mouth and throat.
  • Semecarpus anacardium (seeds)

Option A: Strychnos nux vomica

  • Strychnos Nux-vomica (Kuchila): It is used as a respiratory stimulant, rodenticide, and for killing stray dogs. Strychnine is still available as herbal and homeopathic remedies, as a purgative, appetite suppressant, and as a constituent of nerve tonics. It can be found as an adulterant in some street drugs (cocaine, heroin, and amphetamines).

Option C: Abrus precatorius

  • Abrus Precatorius (Rati, Gunchi, Jequirity): Seeds contain active principles, abrin, a thermolabile toxalbumin; abrine, an amino acid; hemagglutinin, a lipolytic enzyme; and abralin, a glycoside.
  • Abrus precatorius is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages. The toxic principle is injected into the animal in the form of fine needle-shaped structures called ‘suis'. Seeds are also used as abortifacient and as an arrow poison.

Option D: Capsicum annum

  • Capsicum or chilli fruits are universally employed as a condiment, the powdered form being known as red pepper or lal mirch.
  • Active Principles: Capsaicin and capsicin, are exceedingly acrid, volatile, non-alkaloidal, and non-fatal substances.
  • It may be thrown into the eyes to facilitate robbery. The powder is used as a means of torture to extort money or a confession of some guilt by introducing it into the eyes, urethra, vagina or rectum, burning it under the nose or rubbing it on the female breasts.
  • Superstitious people use the fumes from burning chillis to scare away devils and ghosts.

questions.text: A certain syndicate has acquired the rights to excavate a part of a forest area for the construction of a factory. During the excavation, the remains of a couple of bodies have been recovered. It has been sent to the forensic lab for the determination of its identity. The forensic team would use all of the following formulae to determine the sex of the bone. Which among them is not the right method?

choices.text: Sciatic notch index - Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100
Washburn ischiopubic index - Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100
Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100
Sternal index - Manubrial length/ Body length x 100

questions.solution:
Corporobasal index - Length of 1st sacral vertebra/ Length of base of sacrum x 100 is WRONG as In the FORMULA BREADTH is used.

Vital Indices for Sex Determination from Bones

Name of the index Formulae Males Females
Sciatic notch index Width of notch/ Depth of notch x 100 4-5 5-6
Washburn ischiopubic index Pubic length/ Ischial length x 100 73-94 91-115
Corporobasal index of sacrum Breadth of 1st sacral vertebra/ Breadth of base of sacrum x 100 45 40.5
Sternal index Manubrial length/ Body length x 100 46.2 54.3

questions.text: The patient came to OPD with complaints of numbness in his feet. Physical examination of the feet reveals erythema, edema, and the presence of several clear blisters. Peripheral pulses are palpable. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Second-degree frostbite injury

  • The given condition is of second-degree Frostbite injury.
  • Full-thickness skin freezing, erythema, edema, clear blisters. Also patients complain of throbbing and numbness.

Option A: Frostnip

  • Superficial freeze injury that causes no tissue loss. Rewarming quickly reverses the symptoms.

Option B: First-degree frostbite injury

  • Partial skin freezing, erythema, edema, no blisters, and desquamation several days later.

Option D: Third-degree frostbite injury

  • Extends into the subdermal plexus. The skin is blue or gray, hemorrhagic blisters.

questions.text: A 24-year-old male presented to the OPD with h/o eating street food after which pain in the abdomen, bloating, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhoea appeared. The condition was diagnosed as food poisoning. Food poisoning is an example of which of the following?
questions.solution:
Option A: Point source epidemic (single exposure)

  • Sudden rise sudden fall.
  • Cluster of cases in single IP.
  • All cases develop within one incubation period of the disease E.g. Food poisoning, Bhopal gas tragedy.

Option B: Propagated source epidemic

  • Gradual rise & gradual fall over a long time.
  • Person to person transmission E.g: HEP. A, POLIO.

Option C: Common source epidemic

  • Sharp rise
  • Fall is interrupted by secondary peaks Eg. Contaminated well in a village, Water Borne Cholera.

Option D: Pandemic

  • Pandemic is an epidemic that spread to more than one country.
  • It includes Covid 19, HIV, Ebola etc.

Learning Objective: In a Point source epidemic there will be a Sudden rise and a sudden fall. Cluster of cases in single Incubation Period. All cases develop within one incubation period of the disease e.g., Food poisoning, Bhopal gas tragedy.

questions.text: Disease prevention is a procedure through which individuals, particularly those with risk factors for a disease, are treated in order to prevent a disease from occurring. The most cost-effective mode of intervention for the prevention of disease is which among the following?
questions.solution:
• Health education is one of the most cost-effective interventions.
  • A large number of diseases could be prevented if people were adequately informed & if they were encouraged to take necessary precautions in time.

questions.text: A 3-year-old baby was brought to the hospital by his mother with complaints of fever, severe watery diarrhea, vomiting, and decreased urination. On history taking the mother revealed that she is not been able to follow the vaccination schedule for the baby correctly. The baby is infected with rotavirus as per the physician. Rotavirus vaccine schedule can be given till the age of?
questions.solution:
Option D: 12 months

  • Routine rotavirus vaccination recommended for all infants begins at 6 weeks of age (1 dose), followed by 1 dose each at 10th & 14 weeks of age.
  • Rotavirus vaccine can be given up to 1 year of age according to the National Immunization Schedule.

questions.text: A rural PHC has reported many cases where the population is acquiring the disease in spite of being vaccinated for that disease. This condition is due to vaccine failure. Which of the following is the most common cause of Vaccine failure?
questions.solution:
Option D: Maternally derived antibodies

  • Vaccine failure are of 2 types primary and secondary.
  • Primary vaccine failure means failure to serologically respond to vaccine.
  • Too young age where maternal antibody interfere is the most common cause of vaccine failure.

Learning Objective: Vaccine failure

Primary vaccination failure: Failure to serologically respond to vaccine

  • Too young age where Maternal antibodies interfere (MC Cause)
  • Vaccine production problems
  • Cold chain failure
  • Inappropriate administration technique
  • Immunodeficiency
  • Poor health

Secondary vaccination failure: ‘Waning immunity’ where there is loss of vaccine-induced protection in an individual who had previously seroconverted to vaccination. Causes are not well understood.

questions.text: Determination of the threshold for screening or diagnosis of a positive test is done by Receiver Operating Characteristic Curve. Which is the false statement regarding Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC)?

choices.text: Trading off between sensitivity and specificity is achieved by the ROC curve
The higher the curve, the better the screening test/ cut-off
It represents the likelihood ratio of a positive test

questions.solution:
Option D: None of the above

Receiver Operating Characteristic (ROC) curve:

  • The relationship between sensitivity and specificity is achieved by the ROC curve.
  • The higher the curve better is the screening test.
  • It represents LR+ (likelihood ratio of a positive test)
  • The test accuracy is also shown as the area under the curve.
  • The greater the area under the curve, the more accurate the test is.

Option A: Trading off between sensitivity and specificity is achieved by the ROC curve

  • The relationship between sensitivity and specificity is achieved by the ROC curve.

Option B: The higher the curve, the better  the screening test/ cut-off

  • The higher the curve, the better is the screening test in ROC curve.

Option C: It represents the likelihood ratio of a positive test

  • The ROC curve represents the likelihood ratio of a positive test.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male presented to the physician complaining of polyuria, polydipsia, polyphagia, and weight loss. The physician suspected diabetes and a screening test was done. What will happen if the cut-off point for blood glucose is lowered to detect Diabetes (say less than 120 mg percent)?

choices.text: Sensitivity of the test is increased
Specificity of the test is increased
Predictive accuracy of the test is decreased

questions.solution:
Option A: Sensitivity of the test is increased

  • The sensitivity of the test (true positive) is increased as we lower the cut-off.
  • The number of false positives will also increase.
  • This increase in sensitivity occurs at expense of specificity. i.e., Specificity will decrease (As sensitivity and specificity are inversely related to each other so if Sensitivity Increases → Specificity Decreases and Vice Versa).

Option B: Specificity of the test is increased

  • If we lower the cut-off value of the test, the false positives will be increased.
  • Therefore, the specificity of the test will decrease.

Option C: Predictive accuracy of the test is decreased

  • The predictive value of the test is not affected by sensitivity and specificity.
  • The predictive value is dependent on the prevalence of the disease.
  • If the prevalence of the disease is high, then the positive predictive value will be increased and vice versa.

Option D: None of the above

  • If we lower the cut-off value then sensitivity will increase, therefore this is an incorrect choice.

questions.text: A community medicine intern was asked to calculate the child-women ratio for the rural village population. In the child-woman ratio, the number of 0-4 year aged children is expressed by which of the following?

choices.text: Per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years)
Per 1000 married women in the reproductive age group
Per 1000 married women in the post-reproductive age group

questions.solution:
Option B: Per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15-49 years)

  • Child woman ratio is the number of 0-4 years aged children expressed per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15–49 years).
  • This ratio is used where birth registration statistics either do not exist or are inadequate.

Option A: Per 1000 women

  • Child woman ratio is the number of 0-4 years aged children expressed per 1000 women but in a specific age group (reproductive age group women 15–49 years).

Option C: Per 1000 married women in the reproductive age group

  • Child woman ratio is the number of 0-4 years aged children expressed per 1000 women in the reproductive age group i.e, 15–49 years.

Option D: Per 1000 married women in the post-reproductive age group

  • Child woman ratio is the number of 0-4 years aged children expressed per 1000 women in the reproductive age (not post-reproductive age group) group i.e, 15–49 years.

questions.text: The care and treatment of women in childbirth and during the period before and after delivery is known as obstetric care. Which of the following is not included in Essential obstetric care?

choices.text: Safe delivery at home or institution

questions.solution:
Option B: MTP facilities

Essential obstetric care

  • Essential obstetric care intends to provide the basic maternity services to all pregnant women through.
    • Early Registration of pregnancy.
    • Provision of minimum three antenatal check up by ANM or medical officer to monitor progress of pregnancy and detect any risk/complications.
    • Provision of safe delivery at home or in an institution.
    • Provision of three postnatal check-ups to monitor the postnatal recovery and detect complications.
  • MTP facilities are not included in Essential obstetric care RCH phase I.

Components of obstetric care in RCH program:

Essential Obstetric Newborn care Emergency Obstetric Newborn Care (EMONC)
  • Level 1
    • PHC's
      • Early registration of pregnancy (within 12-16 weeks)
      • Antenatal care: Min 3 checkups by ANM/MO
      • Safe Delivery
      • Postnatal care- Min. 3 postnatal checkups
      • Newborn Care

Basic EmONC

  • Level 2
    • 24 × 7 PHC's, CHC's
      • Manual removal of Placenta
      • Oxytocics
      • Antibiotics
      • Anti convulsants
      • Assisted Delivery
      • Vaccum aspiration
      • Newborn Resuscitation

Comprehensive EmONC (CEMONC)

  • Level 3
    • District Hospital, FRU's
      • Includes Basic EmONC and
      • Blood transfusion
      • Surgery

Learning Objective

Essential obstetric care includes:

  1. Early registration of pregnancy (within 12-16 weeks).
  2. Antenatal care: Minimum 3 checkups by ANM/MO.
  3. Safe Delivery
  4. Postnatal care: Minimum 3 postnatal checkups.

questions.text: A 26-year-old pregnant female recently delivered a healthy baby in the hospital. You assisted your senior in this delivery. When should breastfeeding be initiated after delivery?
questions.solution:
Option B: One hour

  • Initiation of early breastfeeding within one hour of birth, exclusive breastfeeding for 6 months, and timely weaning at 6 months as per infant and young child feeding guidelines.
