  • Early breastfeeding initiation is immediately after birth, preferably within one hour (According to MoH India).
  • Early skin-to-skin contact keeps the baby warm.

questions.text: Dietary modification (PRUDENT DIET) is the principal preventive strategy in preventing CORONARY HEART DISEASE. As per the WHO recommended Goal of a Prudent diet, the Total Cholesterol: HDL ratio should be less than?
questions.solution:
Option C: 3.5

  • As per the WHO recommended Goal of a Prudent diet, the Total Cholesterol: HDL ratio should be less than 3.5.
  • Reduction in dietary cholesterol to < 200 mg/day.
  • Reduction of salt intake to < 5 gms per day.

questions.text: A 32-year-old vegetarian male presented to the OPD with pale skin, fatigue, and numbness. On examination, he was having vitamin deficiency for which only animal sources had to be consumed. Which of the following vitamins is deficient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Vitamin B12

  • A vegetarian male with pallor, fatigue, and numbness suggests the patient is having anemia with peripheral neuropathy, which is most likely due to B12 deficiency.
  • Vitamin B12/Cyanocobalamin is only obtainable through animal sources, therefore strict vegetarians develop B12 deficiency.

Option A: Vitamin B1

  • Since B12 only obtain through animal sources this patient is more likely to have B12 deficiency.
  • Thiamine deficiency can cause peripheral neuropathy but anemia would be uncommon.
  • Given Strict vegetarian, B12 is the more likely answer.

Option B: Vitamin B2

  • Vitamin B2 deficiency can lead to angular stomatitis, cheilosis, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis.

Option D: Vitamin C

  • Vitamin C deficiency is also known as "scurvy" present with bleeding gums, petechiae, poor wound healing, and corkscrew hair.

questions.text: A sociology student is studying theories of disease causation. Putting profit ahead of health as a cause of the disease is provided by which of the following theory of sociology?
questions.solution:
Option C: Marxist

  • Putting profit ahead of health as a cause of the disease is provided by Marxist theory.
  • It is concerned with the relationship between health and illness and capitalist social organization.

Option A: Feminist

  • The feminist theory suggested that disease occurs d/t the role of women enforced by men.

Option B: Parsonian theory

  • The Parsonian theory suggested that disease occurs d/t social constraints which arise d/t social demands.

Option D: Foucauldian

  • Foucauldian theory suggested that disease occurs, the population is segregated into groups, making them easier to control.

questions.text: A health worker was using the Nalgonda technique for the defluorination of water in a rural village. Which of the following is the correct sequence of adding required materials?
questions.solution:
Option D: Lime + Alum

  • It involves the ‘addition of Lime, Alum, and Bleaching powder (Mnemonic: LAB) followed by Flocculation, Sedimentation, and Filtration.
  • In the Nalgonda technique, Aluminum is a major de-fluoridating agent.

Option A: Lime + Soda 

 

  • This is incorrect.
  • The correct sequence of adding materials:
    • Lime
    • Aluminum
    • Bleaching powder

Option B: Soda + Alum 

  • Soda+ alum is not the correct sequence.
  • The Nalgonda technique involves the ‘addition of Lime, Alum, and Bleaching powder.

Option C: Alum + Soda

  • Alum+ soda is not the correct sequence.
  • The Nalgonda technique involves the ‘addition of Lime, Alum, and Bleaching powder (Mnemonic: LAB) followed by Flocculation, Sedimentation, and Filtration.

questions.text: A PSM intern was posted in a rural PHC. In the morning OPD session, the senior physician asked him to explain about the Primary health care center. All of the following are incorrect statements regarding PHC except?

choices.text: Staff of PHC must have a radiographer
PHC with ≥ 10 deliveries per month is categorized as type B PHC
1 PHC is established per 5000 population in hilly areas
School health is responsibility of PHC

questions.solution:
Option D: School health is responsibility of PHC

  • SCHOOL HEALTH

    · SH first recommended by:Bhore Committee

    o Established in 1943

    o Recommendation given by 1946

    · Comprehensive SH program was first given by: Renuka Roy Committee

    o Established in 1960

    o Recommendation given by 1961

Other options

Option A: The staff of PHC must have a radiographer

  • Staff at PHC: Existing staff + 1 AYUSH doctor, 1 Dentist, 1 More allopathic doctor, 1 MHW
  • 15 Total staff (including 1 allopathic doctor).

Option B: PHC with ≥ 10 deliveries per month is categorized as type B PHC

  • Type B PHC: PHC with ≥ 20 deliveries per month.

Option C: 1 PHC is established per 5000 population in hilly areas

  • Population covered by PHC in tribal areas/hilly areas: 20,000

questions.text: A 25-year-old married female visited to the gynaecology OPD with concerns regarding the use of OCPs. Which of the following is the absolute contraindication for the use of OCPs?
questions.solution:
Option A: Thromboembolism

  • Combined OCPs and thromboembolism have a relative risk of >1.

Absolute contraindications of OCP: (Mnemonic: CLUTCH)

  • C: Cancers (breast, cervical)
  • L: Liver diseases (adenoma)
  • U: Uterine bleeding (excessive & undiagnosed)
  • T - Thromboembolism
  • C: Cardiovascular diseases
  • H: Hyperlipidemia (congenital)
  • Pregnancy

Option B: Hypertension

  • Grade-I hypertension is a relative contraindication and Grade-II is an absolute contraindication.

Option C: Diabetes

  • Long-standing or complicated diabetes (with microvascular complications) is an absolute contraindication.

Option D: Epilepsy

  • Simultaneous use of some anti-epileptics is relatively contraindicated.

Learning Objective

  • Combined OCPs are MALA-N and MALA-D.
  • Frequency: Once a day pill for the first 21 days.
  • Last 7 days tablets: 60 mg Ferrous Fumarate.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female visited the OPD with complaints of missed periods. On UPT examination she was found to be 14 weeks pregnant. The female does not want to continue her pregnancy. All of the following are the contraindications for Medical abortion except?
questions.solution:
Option A: Age more than 35 years

  • Age is not a contraindication for medical abortion.
  • The contraindications for medical abortion include
    • Hemoglobin less than 8 gm% (Option B)
    • Leukopenia/ thrombocytopenia
    • Active renal or liver disease
    • Undiagnosed adnexal mass (Option C)
    • Uncontrolled seizure disorder (Option D)
    • Ectopic pregnancy > 4cm in size
    • High initial HCG concentration > 5000mU/ml
    • An intrauterine device in situ
    • Acute inflammatory bowel disease.

Learning Objective

MTP ACT

  • Passed in 1971
  • Implemented in 1972
  • Revised in 1975
  • Amendment 2021 - Can now be done till 24 weeks, the reason for MTP must be approved by the board.

Indications:

  • Maternal risk such as NYHA grade III, IV.
  • Fetal risks such as anencephaly.
  • Humanitarian cause: Pregnancy caused by rape.
  • Contraceptive failure.

Can be done by:

  • Gynecologist (MD/ DNB/ Diploma).
  • The doctor who trained for 6 months in gynecology.
  • The doctor who performed at least 25 MTPs under supervision.

Can be done where:

  • Government approved center
  • Blood availability
  • CMO approved

questions.text: Polypoidal mass in ear, on touch bleeding heavily, cause is:
questions.solution: Glomus jugulare can perforate the TM and come into the external auditory canal presenting like a bleeding polyp of external auditory canal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with complaints of intermittent headaches and palpitations for the past 8 months. He is noted to have profuse sweating. On examination, his blood pressure is 180/95 mmHg. ECG shows sinus tachycardia with a heart rate of 108 beats/min. The physician suspects this is a case of Pheochromocytoma. Which is the best imaging modality to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option D: MRI abdomen

Imaging

Sensitivity

Specificity

CT

++++

+++

MRI

++++

+++

MIBG scintigraphy

+++

++++

Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy

++

++

Fluoro – DOPA PET/CT

+++

++++

  • Imaging studies such as CT scans and MRIs are diagnostic tests of choice for pheochromocytomas.

  • CT and MRI are the most sensitive tests to diagnose this disease.

  • CT scans may be more advantageous over MRI, but the latter has no exposure to ionising radiation.

Option A: MIBG Scintigraphy

  • MIBG Scintigraphy is highly specific but not as sensitive as an MRI. The quality of the image is also subjective, depending on the centre carrying it out.

Option B:  Somatostatin Scintigraphy

  • Somatostatin scintigraphy is used to diagnose carcinoid tumours and not Pheochromocytoma.

Option C: PET DOPA

  • PET DOPA is the most advanced imaging technique to diagnose Pheochromocytoma. However, it is not as widely available.

questions.text: A 66-year-old female with poorly controlled diabetes mellitus type-2 comes to the outdoor patient clinic with complaints of bilaterally painful lesions on her legs. She has a 20-pack-year history of smoking and had 1 prior episode of myocardial infarction for which coronary angioplasty with stent placement was done. Her current medications include atorvastatin, aspirin, clopidogrel and metformin. On examination, there are tender bilateral ulcerated lesions anterior to her shins, as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of the lesions of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum.

  • Diabetes mellitus (DM) is a disease of beta cells of the pancreas.
  • It is characterized by polydipsia, polyphagia, polyuria, fatigue, weight loss, blurred vision, fungal infections, numbness and tingling of hands and feet, diabetic ketoacidosis, and hyperosmolar hyperglycemic state.
  • Chronic complications of diabetes mellitus include:
    • Small vessel disease: It is caused by diffuse thickening of the basement membrane.
      • It can affect the eye, causing retinopathy (hemorrhage, exudates, microaneurysms, and vessel proliferation) and glaucoma.
      • It can also involve the kidney leading to nephropathy, nodular glomerulosclerosis(microalbuminuria), and arteriosclerosis, eventually progressing to chronic kidney disease.
    • Osmotic damage:  It is caused by sorbitol accumulation in organs with aldose reductase and decreased or absent aldose dehydrogenase. It leads to cataracts and neuropathy.
    • Some skin manifestations that are associated with diabetes are:
      • Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum(NLD):
        • It is a skin rash that develops as a shiny yellow area on the shin with telangiectasias.
        • Patients usually present with shiny, asymptomatic patches that slowly enlarge over time.
        • The patches are red-brown and then progress to yellow, depressed, atrophic plaques.
        • Ulcerations can occur in these lesions, occasionally with associated pain.
        • These lesions could be tender to touch due to secondary infections and are primarily seen in patients having type-2 DM.
      • Acanthosis nigricans:
        • It is epidermal hyperplasia causing symmetric hyperpigmented skin thickening in the axilla or neck.
        • It is associated with insulin resistance (diabetes, obesity, Cushing syndrome etc.) and gastric cancers.

Option B: Acanthosis nigricans.

  • It is epidermal hyperplasia causing symmetric hyperpigmentation of the skin in the axilla or neck.
  • It is associated with insulin resistance (diabetes, obesity, Cushing syndrome etc.) and gastric cancers.

Option C: Lupus pernio.

  • These are clusters of firm, raised, glistening papules usually on the nose, lips and cheeks.
  • These are associated with chronic sarcoidosis.

Option D: Pretibial myxedema.

  • Pretibial myxedema is associated with Grave’s disease.
  • It is caused by the deposition of hyaluronic acid in the dermis and appears as areas of non-pitting oedema on the anterior aspect of the legs.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents to the emergency with complaints of palpitations, shortness of breath, chest pain, and nausea. Electrocardiography shows tall tented T waves. Serum electrolytes show potassium = 8.2 mEq/L. Which of the following is the best drug used to manage this condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Calcium chloride

Management of hyperkalemia:

  • Calcium is the main treatment choice in the management of hyperkalemia.
  • Whenever the potassium level goes greater than 6.5 mEq/L, then immediate intravenous calcium is given to the patients.
  • Calcium is given in the form of calcium gluconate or calcium chloride.
  • Insulin with glucose is the other treatment option
  • Beta-agonist such as salbutamol is also given
  • Sodium polystyrene sulfonate (Kayexalate)] reduces total body potassium levels 
  • Calcium chloride - Onset of action is <5min and lasts about 30-60 min.
  • Doses should be titrated with constant monitoring of ECG changes during the administration

Option B: Calcium hydroxide

  • Calcium is given in the form of calcium gluconate or calcium chloride.

Option C: Potassium binding resin enema

  • Potassium-binding resin exchanges Na+ for K+.
  • The onset of action after PO ranges from 2-12 h.
  • Calcium gluconate should be the immediate step to make the cardiac membrane resistant to the effect of potassium.

Option D: Calcium carbonate

  • Calcium hydroxide and calcium carbonate have no role in the management of hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male presents to the emergency with pedal oedema, fatigue, and shortness of breath. The doctor diagnoses him with Stage 3 CKD. His levels of serum urea/creatinine are elevated. Routine urinalysis with dipstick reveals trace albumin. Which of the following statements represents microalbuminuria?

choices.text: Can be detected by routine lab tests
Urine protein less than 30-299 mg/day is called microalbuminuria
Microalbuminuria is not a risk factor for cardiovascular risk in diabetic patients
Microalbuminuria is the delayed marker of diabetic nephropathy.

questions.solution:
Option B: Urine protein less than 30-300 mg/day is called microalbuminuria.

The significance of microalbuminuria:

  • An earlier symptom of vascular injury is known as microalbuminuria. This condition is characterised by urine albumin excretion of 30-300 mg/day or 20-200 g/min.  
  • It is a measure of overall vascular dysfunction and is believed to be a predictor of worse outcomes for patients who have renal disease as well as heart disease. 
  • Microalbuminuria is brought on by glomerular capillary injury, and as a result, it has the potential to serve as a signal for generalised endothelial dysfunction.
  • Microalbuminuria is the presence of albumin in the urine that is not identifiable by using a urine dipstick because the urine dipstick is only sensitive to protein concentrations that are more than 1gm%.
  • It precedes the drop in GFR and implies the presence of renal and cardiovascular problems.
  • Screening for microalbuminuria on an annual basis will enable the identification of people with nephropathy at an extremely early stage in the disease's progression.

Definition of abnormalities in albumin excretion

Category

24-hr-urine albumin (mg/24h)

Dipstick analysis

Spot collection (µg/mg creatinine)

Normal

Microalbuminuria

Clinical albuminuria

<30

30-299

>300

Negative

Negative, trace, 1+

1+ to 3+

<30

30-299

>300

Option A: Can be detected by routine lab tests

  • Microalbuminuria can not be detected in routine lab tests.

Option C: Microalbuminuria is not a risk factor for cardiovascular risk in diabetic patients

  • Microalbuminuria indicates vascular damage, so it is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular risk in diabetic patients.

Option D: Microalbuminuria is the delayed marker of diabetic nephropathy.

  • In diabetic nephropathy, microalbuminuria can be detected as the earliest of all other markers.

questions.text: A 50-Year-old man became dizzy while passing stool and noticed fresh blood in the stool. The previous two concurrent colonoscopic examinations done for routine screening of carcinoma colon were normal. What is the most likely cause of bleed?

choices.text: Dilatation of veins of the colon

questions.solution:
Option D: Dilatation of veins of the colon

  • Angiodysplasia is a degenerative lesion of previously healthy blood vessels found most commonly in the cecum and proximal ascending colon.
  • In the cecum and ascending colon, 15% are located in the jejunum and ileum, and the remainder is distributed throughout the alimentary tract.
  • These lesions are typically non-palpable and small (< 5 mm).
  • Angiodysplasia is the most common vascular abnormality of the Gl tract. After diverticulosis.
  • It is the second leading cause of lower Gl bleeding in patients older than 60.

 

Option A: Early carcinoma colon

  • Cancer of the right side of the colon presents with occult bleeding
  • Left side with obstructive symptoms.
  • Cancers arising in the rectosigmoid are often associated with hematochezia, tenesmus, and narrowing of the calibre of stool.
  • Signs and symptoms of colon cancer include:
    • A persistent change in bowel habits, including diarrhoea or constipation or a change in stool consistency.
    • Rectal bleeding or blood in the stool.
    • Persistent abdominal discomfort, such as cramps, gas or pain.
  • Stage 1 colon cancer is early-stage cancer that is curable. The primary treatment is removing the cancerous tissue with surgery or during colonoscopy – without chemotherapy or radiation.
  • Colon cancer screening helps find early cancers before they spread.

 

Option B: Sigmoid diverticulitis

  • Diverticulosis is a condition that occurs when small pouches, or sacs, form and push outward through weak spots in the wall of the colon.
  • These pouches form mainly in the lower part of the colon, called the sigmoid colon. One pouch is called a diverticulum.
  • Multiple pouches are called diverticula.
  • Abrupt in onset, usually painless, sometimes massive, and often from the right colon.
  • Since Lesions are easily picked up on sigmoidoscopy, choice B is unlikely

 

Option C: Microscopic colitis

  • Presents with watery, non-bloody diarrhoea and hence ruled out.
  • MC comprises two distinct histological forms — collagenous colitis and lymphocytic colitis, which frequently occur in older populations.
  • Microscopic colitis is an inflammation of the large intestine (colon) that causes persistent watery diarrhoea.
  • The disorder gets its name because it is necessary to examine colon tissue under a microscope to identify it since the tissue may appear normal with a colonoscopy or flexible sigmoidoscopy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents to the outpatient department with the complaints of multiple episodes of diarrhoea approximately for the past 2 months accompanied by weight loss. Occasional blood streaks are noted in the stool. On examination, the patient looks weak with mild pallor. Ulcerative colitis is suspected. What will be the earliest radiological finding on barium enema?
questions.solution:
Option B: Fine mucosal granularity

Fluoroscopy of ulcerative colitis:

  • Double-contrast barium enema allows for exquisite detail of the colonic mucosa and the bowel proximal to strictures to be assessed.
  • It is, however, contraindicated if severe acute colitis is present due to the risk of perforation.
  • Mucosal inflammation leads to a granular appearance on the surface of the bowel.
  • As inflammation increases, the bowel wall and haustra thicken. Mucosal ulcers are undermined (button-shaped ulcers).
  • When most of the mucosa has been lost, islands of mucosa remain, giving it a pseudopolyp appearance. In chronic cases, the bowel becomes featureless with the loss of normal haustral markings, luminal narrowing, and bowel shortening (lead pipe sign).
  • Small islands of residual mucosa can grow into thin worm-like structures (so-called filiform polyps)
  • Colorectal carcinoma in the setting of ulcerative colitis is more frequently sessile and may appear to be a simple stricture.

Option A: Loss of haustrations

  • Loss of haustration is a late finding of ulcerative colitis.

Option C: Pipe stem colon

  • In extended standing UC, Luminal narrowing combined with the loss of haustrations results in the pipe-stem appearance of the colon.

Option D: Collar button ulcer

  • Once the granular appearance develops after the inflammation, a continued inflammation results in collar button ulcer formation.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl from a Punjabi family is brought to the hospital complaining of pale-coloured skin, fatigue and dyspnea. She has a history of repeated hospital admissions for blood transfusions. Physical examination reveals a palpable liver and spleen. Her lab findings include haemoglobin 7.5 g/dl, MCV – 70 fL, RDW – 22 and decreased osmotic fragility. The peripheral smear reveals golf ball inclusion bodies. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: HbH disease

The history, presenting complaints and lab findings in this patient mostly suggest a diagnosis of HbH disease.

HbH disease:

  • It is the most severe form of alpha thalassemia, mainly caused by the loss of three of the four alpha-globin alleles.
  • Golf ball inclusion bodies are known as HbH bodies and are found in alpha thalassemia.
  • Lab findings include: Decreased haemoglobin, MCV <80, raised RDW, and decreased osmotic fragility of RBC.
  • The peripheral smear stained with supravital stain (brilliant cresyl blue stain) shows multiple inclusions in an evenly distributed panel (see image below).

 

  • The diagnosis is confirmed by genetic testing.
  • Children with mild-to-moderate microcytic hypochromic hemolytic anaemia and hepatosplenomegaly should be evaluated for HbH disease.

Option A: Iron deficiency anaemia

  • It is microcytic hypochromic anaemia resulting from a reduced iron level in the body.
  • It does not cause hepatosplenomegaly, and repeated blood transfusions are usually not required.

Option C: Pernicious anaemia

  • It results from vitamin B12 deficiency in the body due to an autoimmune inflammation of the stomach.

Option D: G6PD deficiency

  • It is an inherited condition caused by deficient glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase enzyme in the body that leads to hemolysis.
  • The peripheral smear will show Heinz bodies (denatured and precipitated haemoglobin) in a supravital stain.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presented with complaints of generalized fatigue. His complaints are also associated with petechiae & purpura. On detailed evaluation, peripheral blood smear showed characteristic "Auer rods", suggesting Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia (AML). Which of the following subtypes could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: M3-AML

Acute Myeloblastic Leukemia

  • M3 subtype is Acute promyelocytic leukaemia (APL)
  • Seen in young patients with chromosomal translocation t(15,17).
  • Myeloblasts are usually characterized by positive cytoplasmic staining for myeloperoxidase (MPO); crystal aggregates of MPO are seen as "Auer rods". 
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation (bleeding tendencies) are characteristic. 
  • M3 AML is associated with PML-RARA mutation.
  • Treatment is ATRA ( All trans-retinoic acid ) and Arsenic trioxide.
  • This subtype has an excellent prognosis.

Option B: M4-AML

  • M4 subtype of AML has chromosomal translocation t(16,16).
  • It is associated with eosinophilia and gingival hyperplasia

Option C: M2-AML

  • M2 type of AML is the most common subtype with chromosomal translocation of t(8,21).
  • This subtype has an excellent prognosis.
  • Myeloid Sarcoma is also seen in the M2 subtype.

Option D: M5-AML

  • M5 subtype of AML is associated with organ infiltration, gingival hyperplasia, increased WBCs count and fever sweat syndrome.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male injured in a road traffic accident was brought to an emergency department. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 102 beats/min, respirations are 16 breaths/min, and blood pressure is 125/75 mmHg. On examination, the patient is moaning with an inability to speak. He can understand all the questions but appears frustrated as he is unable to speak. Which of the following area of the brain is affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Broca’s area

  • The inability to speak with preserved comprehension suggests Broca's aphasia.
  • This is caused by damage to the inferior frontal gyrus of the frontal lobe (Broca's area) in the dominant cerebral hemisphere (usually left).
  • A stroke of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) affects the Broca’s area.
  • Broca’s aphasia is characterized by: 
    • Nonfluent speech
    • Comprehension remains intact
    • Repetition impaired
    • Patient appears frustrated as he understands everything but is unable to speak properly

Option A: Frontal eye field

  • It is an area in the frontal cortex that controls eye movements.
  • Damage to the frontal eye field causes deviation of eyes towards the side of the lesion.

Option C: Wernicke's area

  • The posterior third of the superior temporal gyrus makes the Wernicke’s area.
  • It is involved in language comprehension. 
  • Damage caused to Wernicke's area results into: 
    • Impaired comprehension
    • Fluent speech
    • Patient does not have insight into what he is saying
    • Repetition impaired 

Option D: Occipital cortex.

  • It is involved in visual processing.
  • A posterior cerebral artery stroke affects the occipital lobe and causes contralateral hemianopia with macular sparing.

questions.text: An 18-year-old boy presents to the emergency department with repeated transient loss of consciousness lasting less than 10 minutes. After regaining consciousness, he experienced no disorientation, confusion, or tongue‐biting. He has been diagnosed with Juvenile Myoclonic Epilepsy 3 years ago and is currently on maintenance with Sodium Valproate. Subsequently, an electroencephalogram (EEG) showed a 4-6 Hz polyspike pattern. Which of the following would be this patient's most common additional presentation?

choices.text: Generalized tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

questions.solution:
Option C: Myoclonus

Juvenile myoclonic epilepsy (JANZ syndrome)

  • It is a common form of generalised epilepsy that occurs in otherwise healthy adolescents and presents with the triad of myoclonic jerks, generalised tonic‐clonic seizures, and absence seizures.
  • It is commonly characterised by bilateral myoclonic jerks that may be single or repetitive.
  • It has a Polygenetic inheritance and is strongly associated with a family history
  • Onset is usually 10 -19 years of age.
  • Clinical Features include: Sodium Valproate (lifelong)
    • Myoclonic Jerk (early morning) Prominent in the morning after awakening.
    • Consciousness is preserved unless severe.
    • EEG shows a 4-6 Hz Polyspike pattern.
    • May develop generalised tonic-clonic seizures; in the future, and 30% will also develop absence seizures in the future.
  • Provoking factors include:
    • Sleep deprivation
    • Alcohol withdrawal
  • Treatment:
    • Sodium Valproate (lifelong)

Option A: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures during sleep

  • It is a form of Primary generalised epilepsies that can be seen when a person is asleep.
  • These Seizures may be provoked by:
  • Sleep deprivation 
  • Fatigue, alcohol
  • Fever
  • Menstrual cycle
  • Flashing lights

Option B: Generalised tonic‐clonic seizures in the awake state

  • It is the most common form of Primary generalised epilepsies.
  • Onset is 10–25 years of age.
  • EEG shows spikes and waves on waking and sleep onset.
  • It is provoked by Sleep deprivation.
  • Treatment includes sodium valproate.

Option D: Absence seizures

  • Absence seizures (petit mal) always start in childhood > 10 years.
  • They frequently occur (20–30 times a day) and are not associated with post-ictal confusion.
  • Seizures start and finish abruptly (unaware of absence)

questions.text: A 64-year-old female patient presents to the clinic complaining of acute cough, purulent sputum production, and fever. He has a medical history of hypertension and diabetes mellitus type 2. He does not smoke or use illicit drugs. CT image is given below. Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding the given condition?

choices.text: Mycobacterium Avium Intercellulare- Upper lobe bronchiectasis
End-stage fibrotic lung disease- Lower lung bronchiectasis

questions.solution:
Option A: Mycobacterium Avium Intercellulare- Upper lobe bronchiectasis

  • CT image reveals bronchiectasis and peribronchial infiltration on the left lower lobe of the lung.
  • Bronchiectasis is a disease characterized by progressive, irreversible dilation of the bronchial trees resulting in permanently dilated airways.
  • Clinical manifestations include cough with mucopurulent sputum lasting for months to years.
  • Other symptoms include shortness of breath, hemoptysis, chest pain, and recurrent pulmonary infections.
  • Causes and association of bronchiectasis based on lobes of the lung are:
Upper lobe bronchiectasis
  • Tuberculosis
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Post-radiation fibrosis
Mid lung bronchiectasis
  • M.A.I ( Mycobacterium Avium Intercellular)
  • Immotile Cilia Syndrome
Lower lung bronchiectasis
  • Chronic recurrent aspiration
  • End-stage fibrotic lung disease
  • Recurrent immunodeficiency-associated infections
Central bronchiectasis
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA)
  • Cystic fibrosis
  • Mounier Kuhn Syndrome (cartilage deficiency leading to tracheomegaly)
  • William Campbell syndrome
  • Ct scan is the most important modality for the diagnosis of bronchiectasis.
  • It demonstrates the airways and, to some degree, can help distinguish the underlying cause.
  • The treatment of bronchiectasis is medical, and treatment is aimed at sputum clearance.
  • Surgical resection of the affected lobe and lung transplantation may be considered in some cases.

Option B: ABPA - Central bronchiectasis

  • Central bronchiectasis is characterized by the involvement of bronchi within the central third of lung parenchyma.
  • Some of the causes are ABPA, cystic fibrosis, etc.

Option C: End-stage fibrotic lung disease- Lower lung bronchiectasis

  • The lower lobe is the most common zone for bronchiectasis development.
  • It is mostly idiopathic but can be seen in end-stage fibrotic lung disease, chronic recurrent aspiration, recurrent childhood infections, etc.

Option D: Immotile Cilia syndrome- Mid-lung bronchiectasis

  • Mid-lung bronchiectasis is when the bronchiectasis is confined to the middle lobes.
  • It is seen in immotile cilia syndrome and non-tuberculous mycobacterial infections.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented to the OPD with complaints of chronic cough and fatigue for 2 weeks. He was recently diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and treated with a four-drug anti-tuberculous treatment. The patient stated he had had small amounts of blood-streaked sputum for the past 2 weeks, but immediately before coming to the emergency department, he had coughed up a large volume of blood, estimated to be greater than 250 ml of fresh blood. The procedure of choice for controlling massive hemoptysis in this case is?
questions.solution:
Option C: Bronchial artery embolization

  • In massive Hemoptysis, the source of bleeding is the bronchial artery.
  • So, bronchial artery embolization is the procedure of choice to control massive hemoptysis.
  • Bronchial-artery embolization (BAE) is a procedure that utilizes X-rays to examine the bronchial arteries.
  • This enables the doctor to find the bronchial artery, which is bleeding and causing hemoptysis.
  • A thorough review is required to correctly identify the bronchial artery and document angiographic abnormalities.
  • When the bleeding site is identified, all abnormal bronchial arteries to that region are embolized.
  • This method is especially helpful in cases of massive hemoptysis.
  • Massive hemoptysis is bleeding greater than 240 to 300 mL/24 hours.

Option A: Balloon catheter tamponade

  • Balloon tamponade usually uses balloons inserted into the oesophagus, stomach or uterus and inflated to alleviate bleeding.
  • It is of no use in case of massive hemoptysis.

Option B: Rigid bronchoscopy and photocoagulation

  • Rigid bronchoscopy is used to gain access to the patient's proximal airway.
  • Bronchoscopy and photocoagulation are more suitable for diagnosing and treating airway disorders.
  • They can play a small role in massive hemoptysis.

Option D: Flexible bronchoscopy and cautery

  • Flexible bronchoscopy is a procedure that helps to examine the distal airways of the lungs.
  • Flexible bronchoscopy can be either a diagnostic procedure or a therapeutic procedure.
  • It's not a method that is surgically appropriate for the treatment of massive hemoptysis.

questions.text: A 49-year-old male presented with ulcerative lesions in his lower limbs associated with progressive pain, arthralgias, purulent discharge and abnormal gait. He was also reported to have generalized hyporeflexia, thenar and hypothenar neural atrophy, and painless nodules on the forehead. What will be the next step in managing this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Exchange transfusion

The given clinical features and image findings show that this is a case of the Lucio phenomenon.

  • Lucio phenomenon is characterized by recurrent crops of large, sharply marginated, ulcerative lesions, particularly on the lower extremities. These are frequently fatal due to secondary infection and consequent septic bacteraemia.
  • It is seen in leprosy.
  • Optimal wound care and therapy for bacteraemia are indicated. Ulcers tend to be chronic and heal poorly.
  • In severe cases, exchange transfusion is indicated.

Option A: Steroids

  • Glucocorticoids are not effective against this syndrome.

Option B: Lenalidomide

  • Lenalidomide (thalidomide derivative) is the drug of choice in myelodysplastic syndromes with 5q deletion.

Option C: Clofazimine

  • Clofazimine is used to treat leprosy paired with dapsone and rifampicin. It is used specifically for erythema nodosum leprosum and multibacillary (MB) leprosy.
  • It is considered an orphan drug and is unavailable in pharmacies.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child who had a history of frequent febrile convulsions was taken to the emergency room. Further inquiry revealed a history of head dips, axial myoclonic jerks, and a shortened attention span over the previous two months. He was delivered at term via spontaneous vaginal delivery. Normal milestones were reached. There is no history of immunisations. He had a history of a viral infection that included a skin rash and conjunctivitis when he was just 8 months old, diagnosed with measles. What should be the recommended treatment for the condition mentioned above?
questions.solution:
Option B: Isoprinosine

  • This patient is most likely suffering from subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE).
  • SSPE is a rare and serious consequence of untreated measles. This neurological sequela generally appears in the first few years of adolescence, progresses over time, and has a high mortality rate. Implementing vaccinations has positively impacted SSPE patients by lowering the incidence of measles cases.
  • Some of the disease’s specific histopathological features include inflammation of the meninges and cerebral tissue, necrotising leukoencephalopathies with dispersed demyelination, viral inclusion bodies in neurons and support cells, neuronal loss, and astrocytosis.
  • The hallmarks of subacute sclerosing panencephalitis are a progressive decrease in cognitive and motor function, most commonly accompanied by myoclonus, autonomic dysfunction, and localised paralysis. About one-third of individuals with SSPE develop epilepsy, and some patients experience focal or generalised seizures. According to the criteria, Pleocytosis and elevated immunoglobulins can be seen in the CSF together with normal glucose and protein levels. The measles virus will normally be detectable in CSF by ELISA.
  • Isoprinosine for the management of patients with SSPE.
  • Inosine pranobex is an oral immunomodulator and antiviral that prevents viral replication. Three doses of 100mg/kg/day are given daily, with a daily maximum of 3000mg. It is known that this medication raises uric acid in urine and serum samples and occasionally makes people feel queasy.

Option A: Abacavir

  • Abacavir is used in treating human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection in conjunction with other drugs.
  • Abacavir belongs to the category of drugs known as nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs). It functions by lowering the level of HIV in the blood.
  • It is not used in the treatment of SSPE.

Option C: Glatiramer

  • Glatiramer is an immunomodulator that is used to treat and control multiple sclerosis.
  • Although its exact mechanism is unknown, it seems to function by changing the immunological mechanisms that cause MS.

Option D: Interferon gamma-1b

  • Interferon gamma-1b is recombinant human interferon used to treat infections brought on by chronic granulomatous illness and delay the course of severe malignant osteopetrosis.

questions.text: What is the treatment for heparin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Option A: Protamine sulfate

  • Protamine sulfate is DOC for heparin toxicity.

  • Symptoms of overdose may include:

  • nosebleed.
  • blood in urine.
  • black, tarry stools.
  • easy bruising.
  • unusual bleeding.
  • red blood in stools.
  • vomit that is bloody or looks like coffee grounds.

Other options

Option B. Deferoxamine

  • This option is incorrect it is used in iron overdose.

Option C. Calcium disodium EDTA

  • Used in Lead overdose.

Option D. Dimercaprol

  • Used in Mercury overdose.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to the emergency department after a brief episode of syncope. For the last 3 days, he has been feeling dizzy. His past medical history is significant for type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. On examination, his blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg, his heart rate is 40 beats/min, and his respiratory rate is 16 breaths/min. Atropine is given twice,1.5mg every time over 5 minutes, but the bradycardia remains unresponsive. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Transcutaneous pacing

  • Transcutaneous pacing is also known as an external cardiac pacemaker. It is used to regulate heart rate and cardiac output in hemodynamically unstable bradycardia, including atropine-resistant unstable bradycardia.
  • It is a temporary non-invasive method of pacing a patient's heart during a medical emergency.
  • It is done by delivering an electric current through the patient's chest, which stimulates the heart to contract.

Option A: Transvenous Pacing

  • Also known as an endocardial pacer. It is used to treat bradycardia refractory to medicines or transcutaneous pacer.
  • Therefore, atropine-resistant bradycardia, as in this patient, should first be treated with a transcutaneous pacer rather than a transvenous pacer. In case bradycardia remains unresponsive to the transcutaneous pacer, the next management option would be transvenous pacing.

Option C: Implantable cardioverter defibrillator

  • An implantable cardioverter-defibrillator is a device implantable inside the body, able to perform defibrillation, cardioversion and pacing of the heart.
  • It is used for defibrillation mainly, not for bradycardia

Option D: Repeat atropine

  • Atropine is the first-line medication for the treatment of bradycardia.
  • The dosing for atropine is 1 mg IV every 3-5 minutes as needed, and the maximum total dosage for administration is 3 mg.
  • Therefore, in this scenario, 3mg of atropine(maximum dose) has been given; hence next best step would be transcutaneous pacing

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents to his general practitioner with vision loss, headaches and cold intolerance for the past few days. He has unintentionally gained 5kg in the last three months. On examination, he is found to have bitemporal hemianopia and a pulse of 50 bpm. A thyroid function test is ordered. Which test results are most likely to belong to this patient?

choices.text: TSH: Low, T4: Low, T3: Low
TSH: high, T4: low, T3: low
TSH: high, T4: normal, T3: normal
TSH: low, T4: high, T3: high

questions.solution:
Option A: TSH: Low, T4: Low, T3: Low

  • Cold intolerance & Weight gain (aetiology - hypothyroidism)
  • Visual deficit - Bitemporal hemianopia (Pituitary adenoma may be the cause)
  • Secondary (or central) hypothyroidism is caused by disorders of the pituitary gland or hypothalamus. Generally, secondary Hypothyroidism is associated with low TSH, T3 and T4. However, TSH levels may also be normal or even slightly elevated. For this reason, TSH is often an unreliable measure of secondary Hypothyroidism
  • Clinical Diagnosis of 2º Hypothyroidism (pituitary affected)
    • TSH ↓↓
    • T4↓↓
    • T3↓↓

Option B: TSH: high, T4: low, T3: low

  • High TSH with low thyroid hormones is seen in Primary Hypothyroidism.
  • The causes are Hashimoto thyroiditis and infectious thyroiditis.

Option C: TSH: high, T4: normal, T3: normal

  • High TSH with normal T4 and T3 are seen in subclinical Hypothyroidism

Option D: TSH: low, T4: high, T3: high

  • Low TSH with high T4 and T3 is seen in Primary Hyperthyroidism.
  • The causes are Graves disease, MNG and Toxic adenoma.

questions.text: A 28 yrs old female with a previous history of nephrolithiasis was advised to do a CT scan. On workup, the characteristic 'paintbrush appearance' is seen as shown in the image below.  Which of the following is the common symptom of this condition?
questions.solution:
Option D: UTI

  • It is also known as Lenarduzzi kidney or Cacchi, and Ricci disease, a benign congenital condition generally detected incidentally during the evaluation of renal colic.

Essentials of Diagnosis

  • Precalyceal tubular ectasia with a pathognomonic “paint brush appearance” on excretory urogram.
  • Usually without a positive family history and with normal renal clearance.

Clinical Findings

  • Symptoms and Signs: Patients with medullary sponge disease remain asymptomatic, but some may present with nephrolithiasis (Calcium oxalate or calcium phosphate), recurrent urinary tract infections and microhematuria.
  • Laboratory Findings
    • Renal pathology: Macroscopically, kidneys are of normal size with papillary deformity and calcifications. Microscopically, calcified ectatic or cystic dilations of the medullary collecting ducts are present.
    • Urinary abnormalities: Microscopic hematuria, high urine pH, hypercalciuria, and hypocitraturia are common urinary abnormalities in these patients.
  • ​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Imaging Studies: Excretory urography in patients with medullary sponge disease shows linear striated densities in one or more papillae resembling a “paintbrush”, which is pathognomonic of this disease.
  • Treatment
    • Nephrolithiasis is treated as the one that occurs in sporadic renal stone patients. Antimicrobial therapy for a long period may be required to treat urinary tract infections.

​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​​Option A: Anuria

  • In medullary sponge kidneys, GFR is normal. There is no parenchymal issue. There is no pre-renal or post-renal issue in this condition, so urine output is normal

Option B: Polycythemia

  • Erythropoietin levels are decreased in Medullary sponge kidney

  • Peritubular cells that are responsible for Erythropoietin production are damaged causing anemia.

Option C: Azotemia

  • No pre-renal, post-renal issue or parenchymal problem in this condition, so there is normal GFR and no build-up of kidney excretory products

questions.text: 23 years female presented to OPD with complaints of pain abdomen, nausea and 1 episode of hematemesis. The pain aggravates after taking meals. There is no h/o melaena. She is k/c/o of gastric ulcer disease and has been taking medication for that. To mention this case to be Refractory gastric ulcer, the criteria is -

choices.text: Ulcer that fails to heal despite 4 weeks of regular proper dose PPI
Ulcer that fails to heal despite 8 weeks of regular proper dose PPI
Ulcer that fails to heal despite 12 weeks of regular proper dose PPI
Ulcer that fails to heal despite 16 weeks of regular proper dose PPI

questions.solution:
Option C: Ulcer that fails to heal despite 12 weeks of regular proper dose PPI

  • The criteria for refractory gastric ulcer is when the ulcer fails to heal despite 12 weeks of regular proper dose proton pump inhibitors.
  • The most common cause could be use of NSAID's and H.pylori.
    • NSAID's and
    • H.pylori.
    • Zollinger Ellison syndrome
    • Crack cocaine
    • Mesentric ischemia
    • Crohn disease and vasculitides
    • Giant ulcers

Option A: Ulcer that fails to heal despite 4 weeks of regular proper dose PPI

  • The duration of 4 weeks is included neither in the diagnostic criteria for refractory gastric ulcer nor duodenal ulcer.

Option B: Ulcer that fails to heal despite 8 weeks of regular proper dose PPI

  • The criteria of a refractory duodenal ulcer are when the ulcer does not heal after 8 weeks of regular proper dose proton pump inhibitors.
  • Again, Zollinger Ellison syndrome could be the underlying cause.

Option D: Ulcer that fails to heal despite 16 weeks of regular proper dose PPI

  • The duration of 4 weeks is included neither in the diagnostic criteria for refractory gastric ulcer nor duodenal ulcer.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy has come to the hospital for taking a blood transfusion. He is a known case of thalassemia major and is on repeated packed RBC transfusions. He is on iron chelators and has a history of arrhythmias. He suddenly developed chest pain during the current blood transfusion and looked very anxious. Which of the following will be the next management for this patient?

choices.text: Observe for changes in the colour of the urine
Stop BT and wait for the patient to become normal, and then restart BT
Stop BT and perform a clerical check of the blood group

questions.solution:
Option D: Stop BT and perform a clerical check of the blood group

  • The development of back pain and anxiety during the blood transfusion refers to mismatched blood transfusion. A clerical error is the most common cause of mismatched blood transfusion.
  • Fever, chills, urticaria (hives), and itching are also commonly found in mismatched blood transfusions.
  • Some symptoms resolve with no or little treatment.
  • Mismatched blood transfusion causes type 2 hypersensitivity.
  • High fever, respiratory distress, hypotension and red urine indicate a more serious reaction.
  • The immediate management of this condition is to stop the blood transfusion and investigate if there was any clerical error during blood bag choosing.

Option A: Observe for changes in the colour of the urine

  • Changes in the colour of urine, such as red urine, result from intravascular hemolysis.
  • It is a serious complication due to mismatched blood transfusion.
  • The appearance of primary symptoms of mismatched blood transfusion should be taken seriously, and discontinuing transfusion is preferred.

Option B: Continue BT

  • Continuation of mismatched blood transfusion can lead to serious effects.
  • It results in hemolysis and eventually acute renal failure and DIC. 

Option C: Stop BT and wait for the patient to become normal, and then restart BT

  • Once a mismatched blood transfusion is recognized, it will be fatal if the same blood is transfused again.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman is sent to a psychiatrist by her family doctor because she is depressed. She has trouble expressing her feelings during the interview. What is the best way to describe the phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Option C: Alexithymia

  • Alexithymia is an inability to express emotions of self and to understand those of others. (aleXi= expression problem as the patient is unable to understand self and others ).
  • Alexithymia is a personality trait characterized by the subclinical inability to identify and describe emotions experienced by oneself.
  • The core characteristic of alexithymia is marked dysfunction in emotional awareness, social attachment, and interpersonal relations.
  • Furthermore, people with high levels of alexithymia can have difficulty distinguishing and appreciating the emotions of others, which is thought to lead to unempathic and ineffective emotional responses.

Option A: Ambivalence

  • Ambivalence is an inability to decide motor movement (am"bi"= 50-50. so, unable to decide)

Option B: Affective flattening

  • Affective flattening is also known as emotional blunting, in which a person does not experience any emotion in response to external stimuli.

Option D: Anhedonia

  • Anhedonia is an inability to take pleasure from previously pleasurable activities. (anh-DON= Done with life and no pleasure in activities)

questions.text: A 24-year-old male is brought to the psychiatric outpatient department by his father due to a belief that others have been conspiring against him for 8 months. His belief has grown despite reassurances from his father. He also hears voices that criticize his activities. He has no history of any medical disorder. He drinks wine on occasion only. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Schizophrenia

  • The patient presents with clinical features of Schizophrenia.
  • These include:
    • Change in behavior (disorganized)
    • Delusions (paranoid in this case)
    • Third-person hallucination (Auditory)
    • Disorganized speech.
  • Personality changes occur in Schizophrenia.
  • Negative symptoms include seen in Schizophrenia include:
    • Avolition: loss of drive for meaningful activities
    • Apathy: lack of concern
    • Anhedonia: lack of pleasure
    • Asociality: lack of social interaction
    • Affective: flattening / Emotional blunting
    • Alogia: decreased verbal communication
  • The symptoms should be present for at least 6 months to be labeled as a case of Schizophrenia.
  • Also, the absence of schizoaffective disorder and mood disorder is required to diagnose Schizophrenia.

Option B: Delirium tremens

  • Delirium tremens is an alcoholic withdrawal syndrome seen in chronic alcoholics.
  • It presents with clinical findings of confusion, disorientation & hallucination.
  •  The patient drinks alcohol occasionally, which does not lead to withdrawal symptoms.
  • Hallucinations are not a feature of delirium tremens.

Option C: Delusional disorder

  • It is characterized by false, fixed beliefs which are incongruent with cultural beliefs.
  • No hallucinations are seen.
  • No changes in behavior are present.

Option D: Alcoholic-induced psychosis

  • Alcoholic psychosis, or Korsakoff's psychosis, occurs in heavy drinkers.
  • It presents with amnesia and confabulation.
  • This patient is an occasional drinker and has no recent history of heavy drinking.

questions.text: A 60–year–old male presents to the psychiatric outpatient department due to a belief that his intestines have rotten away since the death of his wife 3 months ago. He also believes that he is responsible for his wife’s death. He also reports loss of weight, appetite, and energy. He has a medical history of hypertension and hyperlipidemia for 20 years, treated with amlodipine and atorvastatin. Which of the following is the preferred treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Guidance and counselling with a guru and antidepressants

questions.solution:
Option A: Antipsychotics and antidepressants

  • DSM-5 Specifiers for Depressive Disorders Criteria C includes depression with psychotic features (delusions and hallucinations).
  • With mood-congruent psychotic features, the delusions and hallucinations are consistent with the typical depressive themes of personal inadequacy, guilt, disease, death, nihilism, or deserved punishment.
  • With mood-incongruent psychotic features, the delusions and hallucinations are not consistent with the typical depressive themes of personal inadequacy, guilt, disease, death, nihilism, or deserved punishment, or the content is a mixture of mood-congruent and mood-incongruent themes.
  • The patient presented with nihilistic delusions (intestines rotting away) and pathological guilt (believing that the patient was responsible for death).
  • The death of his wife acted as a stressor to precipitate major depressive disorder with psychotic features in this patient.
  • Major depressive disorder with psychotic features requires treatment with antidepressants and antipsychotics.
  • Counselling is done after the patient regains insight and the mood is corrected.

Option B: Antidepressants with cognitive behavioural therapy

  • The patient presented with major depressive disorder with psychotic features.
  • He needs treatment with antidepressants and antipsychotics to treat depression and nihilistic delusions, respectively.
  • Cognitive behavioural therapy and counselling are done after the mood is corrected and insight is regained.

Option C: Guidance and counselling with a guru and antidepressants

  • The patient's major depressive disorder with psychotic features requires treatment with antipsychotics and antidepressants.
  • Guidance and counselling can be done later when insight is regained.

Option D: Antidepressants alone

  • The patient has a major depressive disorder with psychotic features.
  • Antidepressants will treat depression only.
  • It should be combined with antipsychotics to treat delusions.

questions.text: Kabir has anger management issues. Preethi's (Kabir's girlfriend) father opposes her and Kabir's relationship due to his brash behavior. Kabir demands Preethi decide within six hours otherwise he will end their relationship. Following this incident, Preethi's parents seize her phone, preventing her from contacting Kabir. By the time she manages to visit Kabir's house, he injects morphine into himself and becomes unconscious for two days. Apart from bladder incontinence, we could have noticed the following except:
questions.solution:
• Hypotension is a feature and not hypertension

  • Features of Morphine Poisoning:

    • Euphoria - Initial euphoria followed by a period of sedation (nodding off)
    • Lethal – Respiratory depression
    • Slow respiration, hypothermia, hypotension, bradycardia, cyanosis, pinpoint pupil

The net effect of morphine is the activation of descending inhibitory pathways of the CNS as well as inhibition of the nociceptive afferent neurons of the PNS which leads to an overall reduction of the nociceptive transmission.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient department with a massively enlarged left breast, as shown below:



On biopsy, the tumor has malignant with cellular atypia and hypercellular stroma. Which of the following is the best treatment option for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Simple mastectomy

  • This patient, with a large, firm breast mass with biopsy findings of cellular atypia and increased stromal cellularity, most likely has a phyllodes tumor.
  • Phyllodes tumor is also known as cystosarcoma phyllodes or serocystic disease of Brodie (Phyllodes-leaf-like appearance on the cut section).
  • It has a dual origin, i.e., mammary epithelium and connective tissue (stroma)
  • It can be benign, borderline, or malignant; however, most tumors are benign.
  • The cut section shows a leaf-like appearance and cystic areas because of hemorrhage and necrosis.
  • Cystosarcoma phyllodes are unique because it does not involve the following structures:
    • Nipple
    • Chest wall
    • Breast skin
  • Clinical features of Phyllodes tumor are as follows:
    • It can present with a mobile mass and can mimic fibroadenoma
    • Affected breasts can be massively enlarged
    • Pressure atrophy/necrosis of skin
    • No skin fixity (because the tumor does not involve the overlying skin)
    • The skin may appear shiny with visible breast veins
    • No fixation of a tumor to the chest wall as the chest wall is not involved. (tumor is mobile over the chest wall)
    • No nipple retraction/ulceration/deviation
  • The most common route of spread is hematogenous (lymphatic route of spread is not seen)
  • The most common site of metastasis is the lungs, although it rarely metastasizes.
  • Benign-appearing cystosarcoma phyllodes are treated with wide local excision, including a 2cm margin of normal tissue.
  • Malignant tumors are treated with simple mastectomy with or without reconstruction.
  • Modified radical mastectomy is not performed because the tumor is not associated with lymph node metastasis.

Option A: Breast conservation surgery

  • Breast conservation surgery with wide local excision is indicated for small phyllodes tumors.
  • This patient has quite a large tumor which requires a mastectomy.

Option C: Wide local excision

  • Wide local excision, including a rim of normal tissue, can be attempted with small tumors having a small tumor-to-breast ratio.
  • This patient’s large phyllodes tumor should be treated with a complete mastectomy.

Option D: Modified radical mastectomy

  • Modified radical mastectomy is done for locally invasive breast cancer with axillary lymph node spread.
  • Phyllodes tumor rarely spread to axillary lymph nodes or other organs and can be treated with simple mastectomy.

questions.text: An 18-month-old baby was brought in with complaints of abdominal mass, blueberry muffin spots on the skin, proptosis, and periorbital ecchymosis. Upon further evaluation, urinary catecholamines and their metabolites were elevated. Which of the following is incorrect about the described condition?

choices.text: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood
It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

questions.solution:
Correct Option

Option B: Most common Intracranial solid tumor of childhood

  • This is incorrect statement.
  • The above-described clinical condition is neuroblastoma

NEUROBLASTOMA

  • Most common extracranial solid tumor in infants and children, arises from neural crest cells
  • Malignant neoplasm of the sympathetic nervous system
  • Over 80% of cases are present before the age of 4, and the peak incidence is 2 years
  • It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain
  • Most common site: 65% occur in the abdomen, with 50% localized to the adrenal medulla, neck (5%), chest (20%), or pelvis (5%)
  • Exhibit spontaneous regression completely, especially in stage 4S with a spontaneous cure
  • Mostly occur sporadically, but 1% to 2% are familial
  • Homer Wright pseudorosettes are characteristic of neuroblastoma
  • Metastasizes to the liver, lungs, cortices of long bones, bone marrow, regional or distant lymph nodes, skull, eyes, and skin
  • Clinical features
    • Asymptomatic
    • Constitutional symptoms
    • Enlarging mass, Pain, Abdominal distension
    • Lymphadenopathy
    • Respiratory distress
    • Bladder or bowel disturbance (diarrhea) - Tumor metabolites (VIP)
    • Horner syndrome - Stellate ganglion involvement
    • Periorbital swelling and proptosis (raccoon eyes) - ocular metastases
    • Long bone pain and tenderness- bony metastasis
    • Rubbery lymph nodes in the neck or axilla - Lymph node metastases
    • Limping, paralysis or weakness, and failure to thrive - bone marrow metastases
    • Palpable skull nodule - skull metastases
    • Blueberry muffin syndrome (blue subcutaneous nodules) - skin metastases
    • Paraneoplastic syndromes (intractable diarrhea)
    • Opsoclonus myoclonus syndrome
  • Diagnosis
    • Elevated levels of
      • Urinary catecholamines and their metabolites (vanillylmandelic acid or homovanillic acid)
      • Lactate dehydrogenase (>1500 U/ml)
      • Ferritin >142 ng/mL
      • Neuron specific enolase (>100 ng/mL)
    • Histology - Undifferentiated small round blue cells
    • Modified Shimda Classification - Helps to predict prognosis
  • Treatment
    • Localized neuroblastoma: Excision
    • Unresectable tumor: Biopsy, initially treated by chemotherapy and radiotherapy, followed by surgical resection of residual tumor
    • Disseminated disease: Chemotherapy (Cyclophosphamide, vincristine, dacarbazine, doxorubicin, Cisplatin)

Other Options

Option A: Homer Wright pseudorosettes are characteristic

  • Homer Wright’s pseudorosettes are classically seen on the histological examination of the tumor.

Option C: May undergo spontaneous regression

  • Some neuroblastoma variants also undergo spontaneous regression.

Option D: It can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain

  • Neuroblastoma can originate anywhere along the sympathetic chain from the cervical sympathetic ganglia to the thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic ganglia.

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presented with repeated episodes of hematemesis. There is no history of jaundice or liver decompensation. On examination, the significant findings include massive splenomegaly and esophageal varices. His liver function tests are normal. Which of the following is likely the cause of this patient's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Non-Cirrhotic portal fibrosis

  • Non-Cirrhotic Portal HTN is elevated portal venous pressure without liver cirrhosis (without liver Pathology).
  • It is an autosomal recessive hereditary condition.
  • It is also called " obliterative portal venopathy."
  • About 85% of people with NCPF have multiple episodes of recurrent bloody vomiting.
  • The features of NCPF (Non-Cirrhotic Portal Fibrosis) are:
    • No ascites
    • No jaundice
    • No encephalopathy
    • No hepatic failure
    • Varices present
    • Splenomegaly
      • It is more common (Moderate to Massive).
    • In this condition, there is sclerosis and thrombosis of portal vein branches.

Option A: Hepatitis C

  • The patients with Hepatitis C mostly have liver cirrhosis, which presents with bloody vomiting due to esophageal varices, splenomegaly, and ascites which is absent in the case.

Option C: Cirrhosis

  • Cirrhosis patient presents with abdominal distension called ascites which is absent in this patient, so this option is wrong.

Option D: Hepatic venous outflow tract obstruction

  • Hepatic venous outflow obstruction is called Budd-Chiari syndrome.
  • The causes of this condition are a hypercoagulable state, anti-thrombin 3 deficiency, nephrotic syndrome, cancer, or malignancy.

questions.text: A 46-year-old female gives a vague history of occasional mild abdominal pain. Her CT scan revealed the findings shown in the given image. How will you manage this case?
questions.solution:
Option B: Cholecystectomy

  • The given image is of Porcelain Gallbladder
    • Porcelain gallbladder is characterized by dense circumferential calcification of the gallbladder wall
    • Clinical Features:
      • Most porcelain gallbladders (90%) are associated with gallstones
      • It is a rare premalignant condition that is associated with an approximately 10% risk of gallbladder carcinoma
    • Diagnosis:
      • Generally diagnosed incidentally on X-Ray or CT but is more commonly seen on CT. In ultrasound, it will appear as a curvilinear echogenic focus along the entire gallbladder wall with posterior shadowing.
    • Treatment:
      • Cholecystectomy is the treatment of choice in patients with porcelain gallbladder, even if asymptomatic (due to the high incidence of development of carcinoma gallbladder)

Option A: Reassurance and conservative management

  • Porcelain gallbladder is associated with a 10% risk of gallbladder carcinoma
  • Therefore, cholecystectomy is the best next step.

Option C: Left Hepatectomy

  • Left hepatectomy is not required because it is not a malignant condition.

Option D: Extended left hepatectomy

  • Extended left hepatectomy is not required because it is not a malignant condition.

questions.text: A 48-year-old man with a history of stage IV pancreatic adenocarcinoma was referred for a second opinion for a worsening dry cough in the setting of cavitary ground-glass opacities and non-cavitating nodules found on chest CT. The previous workup was non-diagnostic and his CT findings were atypical for pulmonary metastasis. Due to his extensive alternative therapy use, he was diagnosed with interstitial lung disease (ILD). Flexible bronchoscopy with transbronchial cryo biopsies revealed adenocarcinoma with intestinal/pancreaticobiliary differentiation consistent with metastatic pancreatic cancer. The most common gene mutation that you would expect in a case of pancreatic adenocarcinoma is :
questions.solution:
Pancreatic cancer

  • Pancreatic cancer is more common in older adults with most patients being 75 to 84 years old. It is slightly more common in men than women. Risk factors include family history, smoking, alcohol and coffee consumption, diet high in fat and low in fibre, fruits and vegetables, diabetes mellitus, chronic pancreatitis
  • About two-thirds of pancreatic adenocarcinomas arise within the head or uncinate process of the pancreas; 15% are in the body and 10% are in the tail with the remaining tumours demonstrating diffuse involvement of the gland
  • Ductal adenocarcinoma makes upto 75% of nonendocrine cancers of the pancreas. Other less common types include adenosquamous carcinoma, acinic cell carcinoma
  • Genetics of pancreatic cancer
    • The K-Ras oncogene is currently thought to be the most commonly mutated gene in pancreatic cancer with approximately 90% of tumours having a mutation. The Her2/neu oncogene is overexpressed in pancreatic cancer. Multiple tumour suppressor genes are deleted and/or mutated in pancreatic cancer, including p53, p16 and DPC 4(Smad 4) and in a minority of cases , BRCA2
    • Rare familial cancer syndromes that are associated with an increased risk of pancreatic cancer include BRCA2, Familial atypical multiple mole melanoma syndrome , Hereditary pancreatitis, Familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), Hereditary non polyposis colorectal cancer, Peutz Jeghers syndrome and Ataxia telangiectasia

questions.text: Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in a patient with findings suggesting acute pseudo-obstruction of the colon?
questions.solution:
Option C: Ogilvie's syndrome

  • This patient with acute colonic pseudo-obstruction most likely has Ogilvie's syndrome.
  • Ogilvie's syndrome:
    • Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction (Ogilvie's syndrome) is a disorder characterized by acute dilatation of the colon in the absence of an anatomic lesion that obstructs the flow of intestinal contents.
    • Acute colonic pseudo-obstruction usually involves the cecum and right hemicolon, although occasionally, colonic dilation extends to the rectum.
    • Patients usually present with abdominal distension that occurs gradually over three to seven days but may develop rapidly within 24 to 48 hours. Patients may also have nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, constipation, and diarrhea. Plain and upright abdominal radiographs show a dilated colon, often from the cecum to the splenic flexure and occasionally to the rectum; haustral markings are normal.
    • Complications include colonic ischemia and perforation. The risk of colonic perforation increases when the cecal diameter exceeds 10 to 12 cm and the enlargement has been present for more than six days.
    • The diagnosis of acute intestinal pseudo-obstruction should be suspected in patients with abdominal distension or pain and a physical examination that reveals a distended and tympanitic abdomen.
    • The diagnosis is established by abdominal computed tomography [CT] scan, which demonstrates proximal colonic dilatation, often with an intermediate transitional zone at or adjacent to the splenic flexure and a characteristically absent structural cause of colonic obstruction. Occasionally, dilation may extend to the rectum.
    • Colonoscopy should not be used to diagnose acute intestinal pseudo-obstruction as air insufflation may increase colonic dilatation.
    • Initial management of acute colonic pseudo-obstruction consists of conservative therapy in patients without significant abdominal pain or signs of peritonitis.
    • Conservative therapy can be continued for approximately 72 hours in the absence of significant abdominal pain or extreme colonic dilatation (>12 cm)

Option A: Sjogren's syndrome

  • Presents dry eyes, joint pain, and dry mouth.
  • Intestinal obstruction is not a feature.
  • However, it can present with dysphagia

Option B: Gardner's syndrome

  • Gardner syndrome is a rare condition that's characterized by multiple colorectal polyps.
  • People with Gardner syndrome have a high risk of developing colorectal cancer early in life.

Option D: Peutz-Jeghers syndrome

  • Peutz-Jeghers syndrome (PJS) is an autosomal dominant inherited disorder characterized by hamartomatous intestinal polyps associated with a distinct skin pattern and mucosal macular melanin deposition.
  • Patients with Peutz-Jeghers syndrome have an estimated 15-fold increased risk of developing intestinal cancer compared to the general population

questions.text: A 42-year-old man comes to your hospital with a complaint of abdominal pain, abdominal distension, and constipation associated with a poor appetite for the past 1 month. The patient underwent a barium enema, and it showed a characteristic sign, which is shown in the image given below. Which of the following is not true regarding the pathology involved?

choices.text: Most common laboratory abnormality seen - increase in ESR
Surgical management is the treatment of choice

questions.solution:
Option D: Surgical management is the treatment of choice

  • The given image shows Goose Neck Deformity, which is a classical sign of Abdominal TB.
  • The deformity is characterized by fibrosed cecum (red arrow) and dilated ileum (blue arrow) with a loss of normal ileocecal angle.

GASTROINTESTINAL TUBERCULOSIS

  • Caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • Two types - Ulcerative and Hyperplastic
  • Characterized by the formation of a transverse ulcer in the ileum (longitudinal ulcers are seen in Typhoid)
  • The serosa is usually studded with tubercles
  • The abdomen has a doughy feel; a mass may be found in the right iliac fossa
  • Most common site is the terminal ileum and ileocecal junction
  • Most common lab abnormality seen is an increase in ESR
  • On Barium meal follow-through or barium enema, In GI TB - contraction of mesocolon causes pulled–up>
  • Treatment - Antituberculous therapy

Indications of Surgery in GI Tuberculosis
  •  
  • Intestinal obstruction secondary to a stricture (most common)
  • Free perforation
  •  
  • Severe GI haemorrhage
  • Intra-abdominal abscess
  • Internal or external fistula

Option A: Has Transverse ulcer

  • In most cases of abdominal TB, the ileum has transverse ulcers on gross appearance.
  • Longitudinal ulcers are present on enteric fever.
  • Hence this finding is not unusual in abdominal TB.

Option B: Common site - ileocecal region

  • Extrapulmonary TB accounts for 12% of TB cases and among them, gastrointestinal TB accounts for 16% of cases, with the ileocecal region being the most common one.
  • Hence this is a true statement and corresponds with the diagnosis.

Option C: Most common laboratory abnormality seen - increase in ESR

  • Tuberculosis is a chronic mycobacterial infection and leads to an inflammatory response in the body by virtue of Interferon-gamma interleukins.
  • This inflammatory response results in markedly increased ESR.
  • Hence this is a true statement and corresponds with the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male was admitted with a 6-month history of rectal bleeding, anal discharge, and altered bowel habits. He gave the family history of a grandmother who died of carcinoma of the esophagus. On examination, he had a low rectal mass that was obliterating the anal orifice. A colonoscopy was not possible, but a rectal biopsy revealed a well-differentiated carcinoma of the rectum. Abdominoperineal resection was done. During surgery, he was found to have multiple polyps. Colonoscopy through the colostomy and biopsy confirmed the presence of multiple benign adenomatous polyps involving the entire colon up to the caecum. After counseling, the patient had a total proctocolectomy and an ileostomy done. What is the probable gene mutated in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: APC gene

  • This is a case of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP) in which the patient presents with complaints of rectal bleeding, anal discharge, and alteration in bowel habits for six months.
  • Familial adenomatous polyposis is an autosomal dominant disorder.
  • It is characterized by adenomatous polyposis coli (APC) gene mutation, usually located on the long arm of chromosome 5q 21
  • The investigation of choice for screening of family members of FAP patients is APC gene testing.
  • Treatment includes:
    • Restorative proctocolectomy + Ileal pouch-anal anastomosis (J-shaped pouch created).
    • Total proctocolectomy with an end (Brooke) ileostomy.
    • Total abdominal colectomy with ileorectal anastomosis.

Option A: K-ras gene

  • The mutation in the K-ras gene can cause colorectal cancer, lung cancer, and pancreatic cancer.
  • It is located on chromosome 12p 12.1.

Option C: P53 gene

  • Most cancers are caused due to mutation in the P53 gene.
  • It usually causes Li-Fraumeni syndrome.
  • The P53 gene is located on chromosome 17p 13.1

Option D: PIK3CA gene

  • The cancers which are associated with PIK3CA gene mutation cause the production of the p110a subunit, which allows P13K to signal without regulation.
  • Its mutation is usually seen in breast cancer.
  • It is located on chromosome 3q26.3

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy who is the second child in his family is brought to the emergency department with complaints of blood in urine with clots and a history of crying at each time of urination. The child's birth and developmental history are uneventful. On examination, the abdomen was soft and not tender, but at the right side of the abdominal wall, a mass is palpated, which is freely movable with smooth edges and did not extend over the midline.  CT scan showed a solid mass with cystic areas in the lower and upper quadrants arising from the right kidney. The hematologic assessment showed moderate microcytic anaemia. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Wilms tumor

  • Clinical signs: In the scenario mentioned above, a 4-year-old boy has complained of blood in his urine with clots and a history of crying at each time of urination. Examination revealed a mass with freely movable and smooth edges and a solid mass with cystic areas on a CT scan associated with moderate microcytic anaemia. Young age, associated with a large unilateral mass with anaemia, is the typical presentation of a Wilms tumor.
  • Wilms tumor
  • Wilms Tumor: Most common primary renal tumor of childhood (2-5 Years).
  • Wilms Tumor: 2nd most common malignant abdominal tumor in children (Most common is neuroblastoma).
  • Arise from the kidney, composed of three elements- Blastema, Epithelium & Stroma. (BESt).
  • The most common presenting feature is asymptomatic abdominal mass or swelling.
  • Other symptoms include hypertension, hematuria and weight loss.
  • Treatment involves surgery and chemotherapy.

Option A: Neuroblastoma

  • It is also a tumor presented in childhood.
  • However, it involves multiple sites and times of onset.
  • Presenting complaints include lumps under tissues, back pain, and proptosis.

Option B: Angiomyolipoma

  • It is a benign tumor of muscle or fat.
  • It is usually presented in adults.

Option D: Grawitz tumor

  • These are malignant adenocarcinomas of the kidney.
  • They are presented in adults of about 50-70 years of age.

questions.text: A 35-year old patient was admitted to the hospital because of multiple injuries he sustained in a car crash. He was conscious with GCS 15/15. Clinical examination suggested multiple abrasions all over the body and severe tenderness in the pelvic region. Also, one failed urinary catheterization was attempted, and blood appeared in the catheter during this procedure. A CT scan was performed, which detected a fracture of the left pubic rami and the presence of the catheter balloon inside the urethra. The patient underwent RGU, which revealed a membranous urethral rupture. In this patient, the extravasated blood/contrast can be seen in which of the following? shorten the question. reframe shorter version of question
questions.solution:
Option B: Deep perineal pouch

Injuries to the posterior urethra

Aetiology

  • The part of the urethra most likely to be injured in a pelvic fracture is the membranous urethra.
  • The membranous urethra is sheared at the bulbomembranous or prostatomembranous junction.
  • Bulbomembranous junction is more prone than prostate membranous junction during pelvic fracture (posterior urethra densely adheres to pubis via urogenital diaphragm & puboprostatic ligaments)

Clinical features

  • Retention of urine + blood at urethral meatus + pelvic hematoma and high-lying prostate.
  • The blood at the external urethral meatus suggests immediate urethrography is needed to establish the diagnosis.
  • Associated with deep extravasation of urine in the pelvis & retroperitoneal tissues.
  • Pie-in-sky appearance on IVP in membranous urethral injury.
  • Superior displacement of the prostate can not occur in case of the puboprostatic ligaments remain intact.

Option A: Ischiorectal fossa

  • It is the space presents between the internal surface of the perineal skin and t the plate of the levator ani muscle.
  • Blood supply to the ischiorectal fossa is done by the internal pudendal artery.

Option C: Superficial inguinal region

  • The superficial inguinal region is the terminal end of the inguinal canal.
  • The superficial inguinal region is located superior to the pubic tubercle.
  • The blood supply to this region is derived from the branches of the common femoral artery.

Option D: Pelvic diaphragm

  • The pelvic diaphragm forms the inferior border of the abdominopelvic cavity. 
  • The blood supply to the pelvic diaphragm is carried by the inferior phrenic, superior phrenic, musculophrenic, pericardiacophrenic, and lower internal intercostal arteries.

questions.text: A male newborn was found to have an undescended testicle on one side, but his external genitalia appeared normal. An ultrasound was ordered, which revealed a mass on the left side of his lower abdomen in the area of the superficial inguinal ring. Later, the mass was identified as the true undescended testicle. The parents requested immediate surgery, as they were concerned that this could potentially affect their child's future fertility. At what time would you recommend surgery for undescended testicles in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: 6 months of age

Undescended testis

  • An undescended testis requires orchidopexy between 6 and 12 months of age.
