  • Best time – 6 months (Values given closest to this according to question).
  • Cryptorchidism, or undescended testis, is a condition in which one testis or both testes fail to descend into the scrotum before birth.
  • The testicle may reside in the retroperitoneum, in the internal inguinal ring, in the inguinal canal, or even in the external ring. At birth, approximately 95% of infants have the testicle normally positioned in the scrotum.
  • Up to 30% of preterm infants and 3% of full-term infants can present with cryptorchidism. Some undescended testes eventually descend by 1 year of age, but they are unlikely to descend after this time.
  • A retraction testis reaches the base of the scrotum but retracts.
  • Examination reveals a hypoplastic or poorly rugated scrotum. Usually, a unilateral undescended testis can be palpated in the inguinal canal or in the upper scrotum. If no testicle is palpated, examine with legs crossed. This manoeuvre diminishes the cremasteric reflex and facilitates the identification of the location of the testes.
  • When the testicle is not present within the scrotum, it is subjected to a higher temperature resulting in decreased spermatogenesis.
  • The undescended testis is associated with histologic and morphologic changes as early as 6 months of age; atrophy of Leydig cells, decrease in tubular diameter, and impaired spermatogenesis can occur by 2 years of age.
  • The undescended testis also demonstrates an increased predisposition to malignant degeneration. Non-seminomatous germ cell tumors are usually associated with undescended testis.
  • An undescended testis requires orchidopexy between 6 and 12 months of age. It is now recommended that the "undescended testicle be surgically repositioned by 1 year of age" to optimise spermatogenesis and improve fertility and reduce the risk of malignancy. Though this procedure improves fertility potential, it is never normal, and the risk of malignant change is also present. However, the location of the testis in the scrotum facilitates potentially earlier detection of testicular malignancy.
  • The use of chorionic gonadotropin occasionally may be effective in patients with bilateral undescended testis.
  • When an undescended testis is not palpable in the inguinal canal, a diagnostic laparoscopy is useful. If the testicular vessels are seen exiting the internal ring, an open inguinal orchidopexy is performed. For an intra-abdominal testis, two-stage Fowler Stephens orchidopexy can be considered in which testicular vessels are ligated as a first stage to allow collateral circulation to develop for 6 months before orchidopexy is performed as a second stage.

Option A: Just after birth

  • The best time for surgery for undescended testes is 6 months.
  • Early surgical treatment can lower the complications.

Option C: 12 months of age

  • The surgical treatment of undescended testes should be done before the age of 12 months.
  • Taking a longer time may increase the risk of infertility or testicular cancer.

Option D: 24 months of age

  • The optimal time for orchidopexy is 6 months.
  • The early management of cryptorchidism may reduce the risk of complications such as infertility or testicular cancer.

questions.text: A 43-year-old man came to the OPD complaining of severe pain in his both legs for the past 20 days. On history-taking, the patient complained of cramp-like pain felt in the muscles after walking along with redness and swelling, but for the past one day, he's had severe pain in his foot even while he's resting, which is exacerbated even by lying down and by touching his bed sheet. With a positive sunset foot sign, there are no pedal pulses. Which of the following patient complaints will necessitate emergency intervention to prevent limb amputation?
questions.solution:
Option B: Resting pain

  • Bilateral pain, severe pain in the legs associated with cramp-like pain felt in the muscles after walking (intermittent claudication), redness and swelling with absent pedal pulses and positive sunset foot sign indicate peripheral arterial stenosis and occlusion in the limb. The dangerous sign in this patient is resting pain, and it is an indication of emergency intervention to prevent limb amputation.
  • Resting pain means that the blood supply to the organ is so compromised that the muscles cannot even fulfill their metabolic demands at rest and have to switch to anaerobic respiration.
  • This means that the blood supply is getting critical, and if necessary measures are not taken, it will eventually lead to limb amputation.

Option A: Intermittent claudication

  • Intermittent claudication means cramp-like pain in the foot while doing any movement like walking or running.
  • This indicates that the blood supply is sufficient during the resting period, but when the metabolic demands are increased due to some activity, the blood supply is insufficient.

Option C: Swelling

  • It is an indication that there is some obstruction and inflammation, which has led to the leaking of fluid from the vessels to the extracellular compartment.
  • It is a sign of disease, but it is not a danger sign.

 

Option D: Redness

  • Redness indicates that there is an inflammatory process going on in the organ.
  • The presence of inflammatory mediators has led to vasodilation and increased blood supply, thus, redness and warmth.
  • It is not a dangerous sign of arterial stenosis.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man presents to the OPD with a feeling of weakness and dull aching shoulder pain and experiences decreased grip power and hypoesthesia in the medial side of the hand in the full-draw position for the last 12 days. On CT angiography, the cross-sectional area of the subclavian artery in the costoclavicular space decreases by 40% compared with that of the subclavian artery in a non-compressed state. The patient underwent the first rib resection through the supraclavicular approach with a clavicle osteotomy. Which of the following complications could occur during this surgery?
questions.solution:
Option D: Long thoracic nerve injury

  • These clinical signs are suggestive of the first rib compression, and the only cure for it is resection by clavicle osteotomy.
  • A clavicular osteotomy in complicated cases of revision TSA is an important surgical method that decreases damage to the anterior deltoid muscle, improves glenoid access, increases the superior exposure area, provides safer dissection, and allows for superior dislocation of the humeral component.
  • Brachial plexus injuries (long thoracic nerve injury), vascular injuries, pleural effusion, winged scapula, and infection are a complication that may arise secondary to first rib removal.
  • Long thoracic nerve injury results in observable scapular winging at rest (usually inferior border only), with overhead movements, or resisted wall push-ups/push-ups whereby the entire scapula demonstrates winging.
Complications of Surgical treatment of TOS
  • Brachial plexus injuries
  • Winged scapula due to long thoracic nerve injury
  • Horner's syndrome
  • Vascular injuries (subclavian vessels)
  • Pleural effusion
  • Pneumothorax
  • Air embolism
  • Infection

Option A: Hydropneumothorax

  • Iatrogenic hydrothorax is very much rare.
  • Although pneumothorax in cervical osteotomy is common.

Option B: Ansa cervicalis injury

  • Surgery for the parotid gland, excision of the deep cervical lymph nodes, thyroplasty, arytenoid adduction, teflon injection, nerve-muscle pedicle implantation, and others may result in iatrogenic damage to the ansa cervicalis.

Option C: Lymphocutaneous fistula

  • After surgical intervention in lymphatic-rich locations, lymphocutaneous fistulas are a rare event that might develop.
  • A spontaneous lymphatic leak may happen when lymphedema is present or close to venous stasis ulcers.

questions.text: A 64-year-old man is suffering from a headache and left-sided upper extremity weakness. He also complains of difficulty in speech. The doctor suggests an MRI brain which is given below. What does this MRI exhibit?

choices.text: The lesion is regular in shape
Shows a ring pattern of enhancement with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic center
Shows an absence of surrounding white-matter edema

questions.solution:
Option C: Shows a ring pattern of enhancement with intravenous contrast and has a non-enhancing necrotic centre

  • MRI shown above shows Glioblastoma multiforme, which crosses the midline, and the image also shows a ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis.
  • Glioblastoma multiforme
    • Most common primary malignant brain tumour in adults. It is a WHO grade IV astrocytoma that accounts for most high-grade astrocytomas. These tend to arise from lower-grade tumours (secondary glioblastomas) and have a better prognosis.
    • Known as a butterfly tumour as it crosses the midline
    • They usually present in the 6th and 7th decade of life with headaches, seizures, focal deficits, and personality changes.
    • Treatment involves gross total resection with postoperative chemotherapy and radiation therapy. Temozolomide is the current drug of choice.

Option A: Lesion is regular in shape

  • Imaging demonstrates a ring-enhancing lesion with central necrosis, surrounding edema, and mass effect.
  • These are highly infiltrative tumours.
  • The areas of increased T2/FLAIR signal surrounding the main tumour mass contain invading tumour cells
  • The lesion is irregular in shape and highly infiltrated.

Option B: Well-demarcated from surrounding brain tissue

  • The lesion is irregular in shape.
  • It is highly infiltration and hence cannot be well demarcated from surrounding tissue.
  • Lesions in the brain include abscess, sclerosis, and cerebral infarction.
  • Most of them are irregular and cannot be well demarcated.

Option D: Shows an absence of surrounding white-matter edema

  • Surrounding edema is present.
  • In Cerebral edema, the additional fluid within the brain's white matter is accumulated.
  • It is usually the response of the brain to an insult. It may take two major types: cytotoxic (grey and white matter) and vasogenic (white matter) edema.
  • Treatments include hyperventilation, osmotherapy, diuretics, corticosteroids, and surgical decompression.

questions.text: A 2-month-old female baby comes complaining of swelling on the posterior aspect of the neck. The patient is stable. On examination of the posterior triangle of the neck, a soft, compressible, and painless swelling that trans-illuminates is found. Which of the following clinical conditions may be associated with the presentation of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option A: Turner's syndrome

  • This patient most likely suffers from cystic hygroma associated with Turner's syndrome.
  • Cystic hygroma is a multi-loculated cystic space lined by endothelial cells.
  • It occurs due to the sequestration of a portion of the jugular lymph sac from the lymphatic system.
  • Cysts are filled with clear lymph and are lined by endothelium.
  • Turner's syndrome is associated with cystic hygroma.
  • Most cystic hygromas involve the lymphatic jugular sacs.
  • The most common site is the posterior neck region (Posterior triangle of the neck), as shown in the image below:

Option B: Klinefelter's syndrome

  • Cystic hygroma is not associated with Klinefelter's syndrome.

Option C: Down's syndrome

  • Cystic hygroma is not associated with Down's syndrome. Down's syndrome is associated with congenital cardiac abnormalities such as VSD and ASD.

Option D: All of the above

  • This statement is incorrect as cystic hygroma is not associated with Down's and Klinefelter's syndrome.

questions.text: A 32-year-old female from a rural background presented with a history of chronic tobacco chewing since age 14. Now she has difficulty opening her mouth. On oral examination, no ulcers are seen. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Oral submucous fibrosis

  • The most probable diagnosis in the Asian female with a history of chronic tobacco chewing and difficulty in opening her mouth with no ulcers on oral examination is oral submucous fibrosis.
  • ORAL SUBMUCOUS FIBROSIS:
    • Progressive disease in which fibrous bands form beneath the oral mucosa
    • Almost confined to the Asian population
    • Risk factors:
      • Pan masala areca nut, with or without concurrent alcohol use.
      • Tobacco smoking alone is not associated with oral submucous fibrosis.
    • Pathology:
      • Characterized by epithelial fibrosis with associated atrophy & hyperplasia of the overlying epithelium.
      • Epithelium shows changes in epithelial dysplasia.
    • Clinical features: Scarring produces contracture resulting in limited mouth opening and restricted tongue movement
    • Treatment: Restricted mouth opening can be treated with either Intralesional steroids or Surgical excision and Skin grafts.

Option B: Oral hairy leukoplakia

  • Oral hairy Leukoplakia is a benign condition characterized by painless, white plaques with a feathery or hairy appearance on the lateral tongue (or, less commonly, the floor of the mouth, palate, or buccal mucosa) that cannot be scraped off.
  • It is caused by Epstein-Barr virus infection but typically only occurs in patients who are also immunocompromised.
  • Oral hairy leukoplakia (OHL), which is caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, manifests as white patches on the oral mucosa that cannot be wiped off with gauze, and biopsy can show marked hyperkeratosis and parakeratosis.
  • However, the lesions of OHL are typically found on the lateral surfaces of the tongue, not the gingiva, and have a hairy or feathery rather than granular texture.
  • Moreover, OHL lesions typically only manifest in immunocompromised patients, and there is no evidence of immunocompromised in this patient.

Option C: Erythroleukoplakia

  • Erythroleukoplakia is a type of nonhomogeneous oral Leukoplakia characterized by white plaques with red speckles.
  • It has a higher risk of malignant transformation than homogeneous Leukoplakia.

Option D: Trigeminal neuralgia 

  • Trigeminal neuralgia, or Tic douloureux, is a condition characterized by attacks of facial pain in the area of one or more branches of the trigeminal nerve. 
  • The pain is typically very intense, sharp, and stabbing and lasts for several seconds.
  • Attacks can occur without provocation but are sometimes triggered by innocuous stimuli like chewing.

questions.text: A 29-year-old woman presents with severe abdominal and flank pain after a motor vehicle collision where she was the seatbelt-restrained driver. Her abdomen was distended and showing guarding with rebound tenderness. There is frank blood at the urethral orifice, and the introduction of a bladder catheter yielded no urine. Retrograde cystography is shown below. What is the next step in management?

choices.text: Radical cystectomy has to be performed
Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis
Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained

questions.solution:
Option B: Requires laparotomy

 

rupture of the urinary bladder: An unusual presentation of intraperitoneal bladder rupture managed conservatively - ScienceDirect" src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2214442019300142-egi10T00ZMQGKT.jpg" />

 

  • A ruptured intraperitoneal bladder is depicted in the photograph. Note the extraluminal contrast (red arrows) seeping into the peritoneal cavity from outside the normal bladder's boundaries.
  • There is contrast outside of the intestine, in the left paracolic gutter (yellow arrow)
  • The intrarenal collecting system and ureter are visualized because the patient had a contrast-enhanced CT done moments earlier.
  • Intraperitoneal Rupture (20%):
    • Blow, kick or fall on a fully distended bladder.
    • Apart from the classic triad suggestive of bladder rupture (Suprapubic pain and tenderness + Difficulty inability to pass urine + Hematuria), patients develop peritonitis and abdominal distention.
    • Diagnosis is made by retrograde cystography or CT cystography.
    • Cystography demonstrates a typical sunburst appearance. Laparotomy with peritoneal lavage and bladder repair with SPC should be done.

Option A: Radical cystectomy has to be performed

  • The patient has intraperitoneal rupture with the ruptured bladder, so radical cystectomy does not indicate this case.
  • A radical cystectomy is done to treat cancer that has invaded muscle tissue of the bladder or recurrent noninvasive bladder cancer.

Option C: Simple catheter drainage + Broad-spectrum antibiotics as a precaution for peritonitis

  • The patient discussed above has intraperitoneal rupture leading to peritonitis.
  • A simple catheter cannot drain it. However, broad-spectrum antibiotics should be given to treat the peritonitis.

Option D: Conservative management is enough, as the intra-abdominal fluid can be drained

  • Peritonitis is a fatal condition which requires immediate drainage by doing laparotomy and giving broad-spectrum antibiotics to treat peritonitis.
  • Conservative management is not enough in this case.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man, Vibhu presents with pulmonary lesions seen on a chest CT scan. He has a history of melanoma which was treated with wide local excision with negative margins and lymph node dissection. Biopsy of these pulmonary lesions proves to be metastatic melanoma. The general condition of the patient is good & there is no evidence of recurrence or extrathoracic disease. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

choices.text: Pulmonary metastasectomy followed by radiation therapy

questions.solution:
Pulmonary metastasectomy (Option B) is the most appropriate treatment for this patient.

Malignant melanoma

Melanoma is the most type of skin cancer that develops from the melanocytes that produce melanin. Melanomas can develop anywhere in the body but most often develop in areas exposed to the sun, such as the back, legs, arms, and face. There are five types of standard treatments used: surgery, chemotherapy, radiation therapy, immunotherapy, and targeted therapy.

  • In this patient, it is likely to be a case of metastasis from the earlier removed malignant melanoma.
  • Since the primary lesion is excised & there is no evidence of extrathoracic disease and the patient’s general condition is good, the appropriate treatment is pulmonary metastasectomy.
  • Pulmonary metastasectomy can be performed for sarcomas, melanomas, germ cell tumors, and carcinomas of the colon, renal cell, and head and neck.

Option A: Pulmonary metastasectomy followed by radiation therapy

Pulmonary metastasectomy alone is an appropriate treatment for this patient. There is no role for radiation therapy here.

Option C: Chemotherapy

Chemotherapy is not playing a good role in metastatic melanomas. So it is not preferred for this patient.

Option D: Radiation therapy

Radiation therapy is not an appropriate treatment for this patient due to the low benefits-risk ratio.

Learning objective:

Melanoma is the most invasive skin cancer with the highest mortality rate. It accounts for only 1% of all skin cancers but has the highest cancer-related mortality. Even though it is serious skin cancer, it is highly curable if diagnosed early. It grows quickly and has the ability to metastasize to many organs including the lungs. In this patient, melanoma is already metastasized to the lungs but with no clinical symptoms. So the appropriate management for this patient is Pulmonary metastasectomy.

questions.text: A patient is presented to the ER after a roadside accident with the symptoms of abdominal swelling and discomfort, and a feeling of tightness in chest. His intra-abdominal pressure, when measured, was 25 mmHg. What could be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Abdominal compartment syndrome

ABDOMINAL COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

  • ACS is defined as increased intra-abdominal pressure (IAP > 20mm Hg) resulting in compression of abdominal structures, producing fatal complications due to pulmonary failure and mesenteric vascular compromise.
  • Normal IAP = 5-7 mm Hg: Intra-abdominal hypertension IAP ≥ 12 mm Hg
  • ACS occurs predominantly in:
    • Patients in profound shock
    • Patients requiring large amounts of resuscitation fluids & blood
    • Those with major visceral or vascular abdominal injuries
  • IVC compressed →Decreased Venous return→ Decrease Cardiac Output → Decrease systolic blood pressure → Decrease renal blood flow & vascular blood flow → Decrease GFR → Decrease urine output.

 

Option B: Hemothorax

  • Hemothorax is a blood collection in the space between the chest wall and the lung (the pleural cavity).
  • Hemothorax is a frequent consequence of traumatic thoracic injuries. It is a blood collection in the pleural space, a potential space between the visceral and parietal pleura.
  • The most important treatment for a hemothorax is draining the blood out of the chest cavity.
  • The doctor will likely put a tube through the chest muscles, tissues, ribs, and chest cavity to drain any pooled blood, fluid, or air. This is called a thoracentesis or thoracostomy.

Option C: Portal hypertension

  • Portal hypertension is an increased blood pressure within the portal venous system, a network of veins.
  • Blood cannot adequately flow through the liver if the arteries are obstructed by liver disease. As a result, the portal system experiences significant pressure.
  • The oesophagus, stomach, rectum, or umbilical region may develop big, swelling veins (varices) due to this elevated portal vein pressure (belly button).
  • Varices can bleed and rupture, which can lead to consequences that could be fatal.

​​​​​​​Option D: Aortic stenosis

  • Heart valve disease, known as aortic stenosis, affects the aortic valve (valvular heart disease). The aorta's main artery and the lower left cardiac chamber are connected by a small valve that does not fully open. As a result, the aorta and the rest of the body's blood flow from the heart are lessened or blocked.
  • One of the most prevalent and dangerous valve disease issues is aortic stenosis. The aperture of the aortic valve narrows in aortic stenosis.
  • The blood flow from the left ventricle to the aorta is restricted by aortic stenosis, which may alter the pressure in the left atrium.
  • Aortic stenosis is obstruction of blood flow across the aortic valve due to aortic valve fibrosis and calcification. The presentation includes fatigue; exertional symptoms including shortness of breath, angina, or syncope; and heart failure.

questions.text: Marimuthu is a 65-year-old man with type 2 diabetes. His primary care physician refers him to you for an evaluation of his obesity and treatment options, including weight-loss surgery. He weighs 156 kg and is 182cm tall, with a BMI of 47.1 kg/m2. Roux-en-Y Gastric Bypass (RYGB) surgery is recommended. The patient’s blood glucose level on post-op day 2 is 156 mg/dl. Two months post-surgery, the patient is recovering well, and his fasting and pre-dinner blood glucose levels are consistently < 120 mg/dl, without oral hypoglycemic agents. In addition to the effects of weight loss, the resolution of type 2 diabetes mellitus after the RYGB is thought to be contributed by which of the following?

choices.text: Increased activity of beta cells of the pancreas

questions.solution:
Gastrectomy removes much of the Ghrelin-producing portion of the stomach, leading to weight loss after both gastric sleeve and RYGB procedures.

GLP-1, is dramatically increased after RYGB, and after gastric sleeve

questions.text: A 60-year-old chronic smoker male presented complaints of left-sided facial swelling for the past 4 years. On examination, a marble-sized firm and non-tender mass is noticed beneath his left ear. A diagnosis is made by biopsy, and the mass is eventually excised. Which of the following is this patient's most likely benign parotid gland disease?

choices.text: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

questions.solution:
Option D: Papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum

  • This 60-year-old male, who has a 40-pack-year history of smoking, presented with a marble-sized mass beneath his left ear. This diagnosis is consistent with papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, also known as Warthin's tumour.
  • Warthin's tumour, called Adenolymphoma or papillary cystadenoma lymphomatosum, is the second most common benign salivary gland tumour (after pleomorphic adenoma). It represents 10-15% of the total salivary gland neoplasms.
  • They are commonly seen between the fifth and seventh decades of life.
  • It has an apparent male predilection for their occurrence. 
  • Histologically, it is composed of an oncotic epithelium and a lymphoid stroma.
  • It consists of an encapsulated mass containing numerous irregular cystic spaces lined by bilayered oncotic epithelium growing in the cystic spaces as papillary projections.
  • The underlying stroma separating the oncotic epithelium is typically a large lymphoid matrix with germinal centres.
  • Warthin's tumour and oncocytoma are the two tumours that show a 'hot spot' on the Tc-99m pertechnetate scan. It is because of the high mitochondrial content within the oncocytes.
  • Treatment is superficial parotidectomy, although they can be enucleated without danger of recurrence.

Option A: Glandular hypertrophy, secondary to vitamin A deficiency

  • Parotid gland hypertrophy can occur during malnutrition due to vitamin A deficiency. It is a reversible condition that returns to normal after adequate nutrient intake. There is no history of malnutrition in this patient.

Option B: Cystic dilation

  • Sialectasis is the cystic dilatation of the parotid duct. It is associated with ascending infections and gland destruction.

Option C: Mikulicz’s disease

  • It is an autoimmune disorder of bilateral salivary and lacrimal glands, resulting in infiltration of the glands with round cells.

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy presents to the clinic with a complaint of fever chills and left thigh pain for the past 3 hours. Two days ago, he injured his thighs while playing football. His lower left thigh is hot, swollen, and tender on examination. The knee joint appears normal and has a full range of motion. The patient has a temperature of 38.3ºC. An X-ray of the left femur is done, indicating soft tissue swelling without any apparent abnormalities of the bone. Which of the following is the most commonly affected area in this condition?
questions.solution:
Based on the information provided, the most likely diagnosis in this case is osteomyelitis, which is an infection of the bone. Osteomyelitis can result from the spread of bacteria to the bone through the bloodstream or from direct introduction of bacteria into the bone tissue, often occurring after an injury. The presentation of fever, chills, thigh pain, swelling, and tenderness is characteristic of acute osteomyelitis.

Explanation of Options:

  1. Epiphysis: The epiphysis is the end part of a long bone that develops separately from the main bone. Infections primarily affecting the epiphysis are relatively less common than in other parts of the bone. Epiphyseal involvement is not a typical feature of osteomyelitis.

  2. Diaphysis: The diaphysis is the main shaft or middle part of a long bone. While osteomyelitis can affect any part of the bone, including the diaphysis, it more commonly affects other areas, particularly the metaphysis.

  3. Metaphysis (Correct Option): The metaphysis is the region of a long bone where the growth plate (physis) is located. It is the most common site for osteomyelitis, especially in children. This is due to the relatively slower blood flow and the presence of terminal vessels in this area, making it more susceptible to bacterial infections.

  4. Articular Surface: The articular surface is the portion of the bone that forms a joint with another bone. While joint infections (septic arthritis) can occur, the symptoms described in the scenario, including thigh pain, fever, and localized tenderness, are more indicative of osteomyelitis rather than a primary joint infection.

In summary, the correct answer is 3. Metaphysis. Osteomyelitis often affects the metaphyseal region of long bones, especially in children, due to the unique blood supply and growth plate anatomy in this area.

questions.text: A 50-year-old female presents to the clinic for the evaluation of her right knee deformity. Her medical history is consistent with mechanical back pain, hypertension, and diabetes for the past many years. Her medications include metformin, insulin, amlodipine, and ibuprofen. On examination, posterior subluxation of the tibia is noted. The leg is externally rotated, and the knee is in a flexed position. Which of the following is the most likely cause of her joint deformity?
questions.solution:
Option B: Tuberculosis

  • Tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis
  • It is an acid-fast bacterium
  • It can affect any organ in the body.
  • Lungs are the primary site of infections
  • Infection of the bones can lead to osteomyelitis and joint deformity.
  • The patient usually presents with a long history of night sweats, low-grade fever, and significant weight loss.
  • Complication of tuberuculosis Knee: Triple deformity( Mnemonic PErF ):-
    • P- Posterior subluxation of the tibia
    • Er- External rotation of the leg
    • F- Flexion at the knee

Causes of triple deformity of the knee :

  • Tuberculosis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Iliotibial band contracture
  • Polio
  • Low clotting power
  • Excess bleeding

Option A: Fracture patella

  • Occurs due to violent muscular pull (indirect), direct trauma
  • Tube cast may be used
  • Displaced transverse fracture: tension band wiring by k-wire and stainless steel wire
  • Comminuted fracture: at least a proximal a third of the patella is intact (partial patellectomy)
  • Severe comminution: total patellectomy

Option C: Rheumatic arthritis

  • The most common area involved in RA is the upper cervical spine( Also known as the craniovertebral junction)
  • Occurs in young female
  • Bilateral hand pain
  • The joint involved in RA is the Metacarpophalangeal joint.

Option D: Ankylosing spondylitis

  • Occur in young male
  • Lower back pain: Sacroiliac joint involvement
  • Reduced chest inspection
  • Controlled by swimming and cycling

questions.text: A 35-year-old female developed a tumor on the knee joint. She has pain in the affected area, which is not sharp. X-ray shows marginal sclerosis and lobulated structures. A biopsy was done, showing the pathology below. It is self-limiting most of the time. Which of the following are differentials of the given pathology?
questions.solution:
Option B: Non-ossifying fibroma

  • The above is a non-ossifying fibroma, a fibrous cortical defect.
  • Most common benign lesion.
  • Involves the metaphysis.
  • Self-resolving.
  • Not premalignant. 

Option A: Ossifying fibroma

  • The biopsy image shows a characteristic multinucleated osteoclast-like giant cell with nuclei similar to the surrounding mononuclear cells, suggesting a giant cell tumor.
  • An eccentric lytic lesion with no calcification is the commonest differential for giant Cell Tumors.
  • Calcification:
    • Ossifying fibroma
    • Chondroblastoma
    • Osteosarcoma
  • Hence non-ossifying fibroma is a preferred answer here.
  • A tumor of distal end radius is always a giant cell tumor until proven otherwise.
  • The most common site of giant cell tumors is lower end femur
  • The lower-end femur is the most common site for
    • Giant cell tumor
    • Osteosarcoma
    • Osteomyelitis
  • Tissue biopsy to differentiate b/w giant cell tumor & giant cell variants.
  • Giant cell variants: -
  • Have giant cells are lytic
  • On – Ossifying fibroma (commonest) fibrous cortical deficit
    • FD (fibrous Dysplasia)
    • Chondroblastoma
    • Chondromyxoid fibroma
    • Osteoblastoma/osteosarcoma
    • Brown tumor (Hyperparathyroidism) osteogenic

Non-ossifying fibroma:

  •  
  • Benign (non-cancerous)
  • Eccentric
  • Age <15 years
  • Non-aggressive tumor
  • Metaphyseal lesion
  • Sclerotic margin
  • Histologically giant cell with foam cell

 

Note: Closest differential is ABC.

Option C: Osteogenic sarcoma

  • Primary is idiopathic.
  • Secondary comes with Paget disease, bone infarction, and radiation injury.
  • Pain worsens at night and with activity.
  • Swelling is progressive.
  • A pathological fracture can happen.
  • Limping and decreased range of motion can happen.

Option D: Chondroblastoma

  • Benign tumor of cartilage.
  • It is very rare.
  • Peak incidence in ages 10-20.
  • Location epiphysis.
  • Joint pain and swelling.

questions.text: A 24-year-old right-handed man presents to the sports medicine clinic with right arm weakness and numbness. Her symptoms began several days before, immediately after she performed repeated sessions of recreational skydiving simulation in a wind tunnel. Her arms had been in an abducted, extended, and externally rotated position for repeated, prolonged durations while she maintained the freefall position. After 1 session, she noticed profound weakness in her right arm flexion and elbow flexion with a loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. The probable nerve injured in this patient is?
questions.solution:
Option D: Musculocutaneous nerve

  • Isolated injury to the musculocutaneous nerve is a rare occurrence.
  • Common causes are prolonged arm positioning during an unrelated surgery or direct injury to the nerve during surgery.
  • Repetitive, vigorous upper extremity activity (e.g. lifting, throwing, or carrying) or a single forceful extension of the upper extremity (e.g. pushing or wrestling) are more commonly cited mechanisms of injury.
  • Most reported injuries to the musculocutaneous nerve occur proximal to the biceps and brachialis muscles, most commonly at the coracobrachialis muscle, due to hypertrophy or strong contraction of the muscle resulting in mechanical and/or ischemic nerve injury.
  • Associated signs and symptoms of an isolated musculocutaneous neuropathy may include weakness in elbow flexion or shoulder flexion, atrophy of the biceps brachii, and pain or paresthesia at the lateral forearm.
  • It is the terminal branch of the lateral cord of the brachial plexus. It receives fibers from the C5, C6, and C7 nerve roots. It branches off the lateral cord just distal to the coracoid process and exits the axilla by piercing the coracobrachialis.
  • It descends between the biceps brachii and brachialis, supplying both muscles.
  • At the cubital fossa, specifically at the lateral margin of the biceps aponeurosis, it pierces the cutaneous fascia. It continues as the lateral cutaneous nerve of the forearm supplies sensory innervation to the skin of the lateral forearm.

Option A: Median nerve

  • Median nerve injury leads to Ape thumb deformity and weakness in wrist flexion.
  • The hand deviates to the ulnar side on flexion, and in addition to that, flexion of the index and middle finger is also lost.
  • Anterior abduction, opposition, and flexion of the thumb are compromised.
  • There is also a sensory loss on the lateral 3 & ½ fingers. There is difficulty in making an 'O' with the thumb and index finger (O-sign).

Option B: Radial nerve

  • The radial nerve is the most common nerve damage in the human body.
  • The most common cause is the fracture of the middle shaft of the humerus.

Option C: Axillary nerve

  • The axillary nerve innervates teres minor & deltoid muscles.
  • Regimental Badge Area: Loss of sensation at this site known as the Regimental badge sign.
  • It is commonly damaged due to shoulder dislocation(anterior or inferior) or fracture of the upper end of the humerus or injection into the deltoid muscle.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents to the hospital after a traffic accident in the casualty with complaints of severe abdominal pain and an altered state of consciousness. His vitals are as follows, pulse 110/min; blood pressure 70/40 mm Hg, spO2 74% on room air. On examination, there is generalized abdominal tenderness and absent bowel sounds. After initial management, he was admitted to the intensive care unit. His Glasgow coma scale was 6/15. A definitive airway should be secured to prevent this patient from gastric aspiration contents. Which of the following should be used in this case to prevent gastric aspiration?
questions.solution:
Option B: Endotracheal tube

  • This is a case of a road traffic accident in which the patient presents with an acute abdomen and an altered state of consciousness. His vitals are as follows, pulse 110/min; blood pressure 70/40 mm Hg, spO2 74% on room air. His Glasgow coma scale was 6/15.
  •  An endotracheal intubation should be done to prevent this patient from aspiration of gastric contents.
  • Definitive airway: airway that prevents pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents, allows central ventilation and permits high FiO2 concentration.
  • Tracheal intubation is the gold standard for airway management which provides maximal protection against aspiration of gastric contents and allows positive pressure ventilation with high airway pressures than a face mask or supraglottic airways.
  • ET tube, nasal tube, tracheostomy, and cricothyroidotomy are definitive airways.
  • Non-definitive -Do not prevent gastric aspiration, and lower FiO2 is delivered.
  • Examples include the laryngeal mask airway, oropharyngeal airway, and nasopharyngeal airway.

Option A: Nasotracheal intubation

  • In nasotracheal intubation, an endotracheal tube is passed through the naris into the nasopharynx and the trachea.
  • It is most commonly done in the case of oral surgeries and dental procedures.

Option C: Oropharyngeal airway

  • It is a curved airway device placed in the mouth to prevent the tongue from falling back and occluding the airway.
  • It can be placed in an unconscious patient with airway obstruction.
  • But it cannot be placed in the case mentioned above as it does not prevent aspiration of gastric contents.  

Option D: Laryngeal mask airway

  • A laryngeal mask airway (LMA) is an artificial airway device that impedes the distal oropharynx to facilitate positive pressure ventilation.
  • It consists of an inflatable mask attached to the end of a tube.
  • It can be used in case of failed endotracheal intubation and minor surgical procedures requiring general anaesthesia.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the surgical outpatient clinic for a follow-up regarding her ventral hernia. Her surgery is planned for a few days. She is a known case of hypertension, diabetes, and hypothyroidism. She is already taking Amlodipine 5 mg twice a day, subcutaneous short-acting insulin and Thyroxine 100 µg once a day. She is posted for ventral hernia repair. The preoperative instruction to be advised for this patient would be?

choices.text: Thyroid medications need to be stopped before surgery
Insulin should be given 24 hrs prior to surgery
Clopidogrel should be discontinued 14 days before surgery
Antihypertensives should be discontinued on the day of surgery

questions.solution:
Option B: Insulin should not be continued on the day of surgery

  • The patient is on follow-up regarding her ventral hernia repair. She is already taking Amlodipine, short-acting insulin, and Thyroxine for her hypertension, diabetes, and hypothyroidism, respectively. The preoperative instruction to be advised for this patient would be that insulin should not be continued on the day of surgery.
  • The following drugs have to be continued on the day of surgery:
    • Antihypertensive medications
    • Cardiac medications (e.g.,β-blockers, digoxin)
    • Antidepressants, anxiolytics, and other psychiatric medications
    • Thyroid medications
    • Anticonvulsant medications
    • Asthma medications
    • Steroids (oral and inhaled)
    • Oral contraceptive pills
    • Eye drops
    • Heartburn or reflex medications
    • Opioids
    • Statins
  • Aspirin: continue in patients with prior percutaneous coronary intervention, high-grade ischemic heart disease, and significant CVD. Otherwise, discontinue three days before surgery.
  • P2Y12 inhibitors: Patients with cataract surgery with topical or general anaesthesia, drug-eluting stent until six months of dual antiplatelet therapy (unless patients, surgeons, and cardiologists discussed the risk of discontinuation) need not stop thienopyridines.
  • The same will apply to patients with bare metal stents until the completion of 1 month of dual antiplatelet therapy. If reversal of platelet inhibition is necessary, discontinue,
    • Clopidogrel-5-7 days before surgery
    • Ticagrelor-5-7 days before surgery
    • Prasugrel-7-10 days before surgery
    • Ticlopidine-10 days before surgery
  • Drugs that should be discontinued on the day of surgery:
    • Insulin:
      • Discontinue all short-acting insulin(regular) on the day of surgery (unless continuous infusion pump).
      • Patients with type 2 DM should take none or one-half of their dose of long-acting or combination (eg.70/30 preparation) insulin on the day of surgery.
      • Patients with type 1 DM should take a small amount (1/3 of the morning dose) of long-acting insulin on the day of surgery
      • Patients with an insulin pump should take their basal rate only.
    • Topical medications, non-insulin antidiabetic medications (except SGLT2 inhibitors, which should discontinue 24 hours before surgery), Diuretics (except thiazides for hypertension which should be continued).
    • NSAIDs: Discontinue 48 hours before the day of surgery.
    • COX-2 inhibitors continue unless the surgeon is concerned about bone healing.
    • Warfarin: Discontinue five days before surgery, except for patients having cataract surgery without a bulbar block.
    • Sildenafil or similar drugs-discontinue 24 hours before surgery.
    • MAO Inhibitors: continue these medications and adjust the anaesthesia plan accordingly.

Option A: Thyroid medications need to be stopped before surgery

  • This medication should be taken on the day of the surgery as it positively affects the patient's health before the surgery is carried out.

Option C: Clopidogrel should be discontinued 14 days before surgery

  • Clopidogrel must be stopped 5-7 days before surgery.
  • It's a blood-thinning agent, so it must be stopped a week before surgery.

Option D: Antihypertensives should be discontinued on the day of surgery

  • Antihypertensive should be continued on the day of surgery.
  • As it controls the blood pressure before anxiety-related high blood pressure.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the emergency department after sustaining a road traffic accident. Both his forearm bones are fractured. He has been taken to the emergency operative room for immediate open reduction and internal fixation with plating under the supraclavicular approach of the brachial plexus block. Injection lignocaine is used for the blockade. While injecting, the patient develops seizures followed by unresponsiveness. On examination, the carotid pulse is not felt. Which of the following is the least likely treatment measure in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vasopressin

  • Vasopressin is not given in the case of cardiac arrest secondary to local anesthesia.
  • This is likely because vasopressin can worsen acidosis and can cause arrhythmia.
  • Management of Local anesthesia-associated systemic toxicity and cardiac arrest:
    • Presently, the three pillars of LAST treatment are seizure management, advanced cardiac life support (ACLS), and prompt administration of a 20% lipid emulsion.
    • For hemodynamically stable patients with isolated seizure activity, intravenous benzodiazepines may be used. Some consider small doses of propofol an acceptable alternative for seizure control but can worsen cardiac dysfunction that may develop with LAST.
    • Supplemental oxygen is appropriate for any patient exhibiting signs of LAST. Still, immediate, more aggressive airway management or circulatory support is required for patients with apnoea, hemodynamically unstable arrhythmias, or cardiac arrest.
    • The goals are to maintain pulmonary ventilation and adequate organ perfusion with well-oxygenated blood and to avoid further acidosis until the initiation of lipid emulsion therapy.
    • Before the introduction of lipid emulsion resuscitation, the treatment of severe cardiac toxicity was limited to ACLS and cardiopulmonary bypass. The use of vasopressors during resuscitation potentially worsened acidosis and arrhythmias. Cardiopulmonary bypass has been used in some cases; unfortunately, not all hospitals have that capability.
    • The idea that a lipid-rich substance has the potential to reverse the effects of certain drugs began in the 1960s when several animal experiments demonstrated that intravenous administration of an oil emulsion decreased the duration of action of thiopental or decreased the free fraction of chlorpromazine in blood.
    • Serendipitously, in 1997, the case of LAST in a young woman with isovaleric acidemia and carnitine deficiency inspired a series of animal experiments.
    • Carnitine is required to transport fatty acids into the mitochondria for β-oxidation, and accumulation of cytoplasmic acylcarnitines (e.g., during myocardial ischemia) is associated with arrhythmias. So, Weinberg et al. hypothesised that overloading cells with exogenous fatty acids by infusing a lipid emulsion would exacerbate LA toxicity. Surprisingly, the opposite was seen. Infusing a fat emulsion decreased and even reversed LA toxicity.
    • In 2006, the first successful resuscitation of a human patient with a lipid emulsion was reported. Since then, many clinical reports have described effective reversal of LAST in adults and children.
    • Treatment of toxicity with an intravenous lipid emulsion has been termed lipid resuscitation therapy (LRT). The mechanism of LRT is a multimodel in action, with lipids exerting both a scavenging effect (previously known as the "lipid sink") and a direct cardiotonic effect.
    • The scavenging effect is moderated by the lipid emulsion's ability to take up lipophilic moieties and transfer them around the blood to sites of storage and detoxification. This provides a "lipid shuttle" effect
    • However, the scavenging effect is not sufficient to explain the rapid recovery. A second effect occurs whereby in laboratory models infusing the lipid emulsion increases cardiac output through a combination of volume and direct cardiotonic effects to improve cardiac output once the cardiac concentration of the drug drops below ion channel–blocking thresholds.
    • A 20% lipid emulsion is efficacious in treating LAST caused by bupivacaine and other less-soluble LAs, such as ropivacaine, mepivacaine, and lidocaine.
    • The lipid emulsion LD50 (median lethal dose) tested in a rat model was much higher than the doses used for human lipid rescue. Potential side effects include interference with clinical laboratory measurements (haemoglobin, methemoglobin, electrolytes, base excess), allergic reactions; nausea/emesis, dyspnea; and chest pain.
    • Nonetheless, reported side effects are limited to bronchospasm, hyperamylasaemia, and laboratory measurement interference.
    • Transaminitis, hepatosplenomegaly, and bacterial contamination are typically associated with prolonged use of a lipid emulsion and do not play a role in the short-term administration of LAST.
    • Although the use of high volumes of lipid emulsion (especially 30%) in premature and low birth weight neonates has been associated with death from fat accumulation in the lungs, there are case reports in neonates, toddlers, and older children of successful reversal of drug overdose (bupivacaine and non-LAs) using the standard recommended regimes of 20% lipid.
    • Last, as mentioned, one should exercise caution with propofol in this setting. It is not a substitute for a lipid emulsion. There is insufficient lipid content in standard sedating or antiseizure doses of propofol to exert a benefit in the overdose setting; however, propofol can compromise CV stability.

Option A: Cardiac compression

  • Cardiac arrest following local anaesthetic infusion must be managed immediately with ACLS guidelines.
  • Cardiac compression is an important component of this protocol.

Option B: Adrenaline

  • In case of cardiac arrest caused by local anaesthetics, small initial doses of 10-100 μg of Adrenaline are usually preferred.

Option C: 20 % intralipid emulsion

  • Intravenous lipid emulsion (ILE) is a novel method for treating local anaesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST) that also shows promise as an effective antidote for other lipophilic drug poisonings.
  • Cardiovascular collapse is the most life-endangering complication of local anaesthetic (LA) absorption or intravascular injection during regional anaesthesia

questions.text: A 40-year-old male who is a known case of systemic hypertension controlled with regular intake of antihypertensives is being posted for emergency laparotomy under general anaesthesia with rapid sequence induction and epidural analgesia for acute intestinal obstruction. He has a history of 27% burns 10 months back. Which of the following is the neuromuscular blocker of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Rocuronium

  • Rocuronium is the fastest-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker (since Rapacuronium is withdrawn from the market), and it can be used for rapid sequence induction because succinylcholine is contraindicated in burns for up to 1 year.

  • Mivacurium is the only short-acting non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker currently available in Europe and is metabolized by butyrylcholinestrases at about 70-88% the rate of succinylcholine to a monoester, dicarboxylic acid.

Option A: Atracurium

  • It is a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker with an intermediate duration of action not currently recommended to be used during the rapid sequence induction procedure.

Option B: Succinylcholine

  • Succinylcholine is contraindicated in burns for up to 1 year, so it must be avoided in this patient.

Option C: Vecuronium

  • It is a non-depolarising neuromuscular blocker with an intermediate duration of action, but it is not as rapid as rocuronium and, thus, currently not used during the RSI.

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presents to her family physician complaining of a burning sensation during urination and pain in flank. On physical examination, she has slight fever. She reported that this pain started about a week ago. After evaluation, her doctor suspected the presence of a kidney stone and advised her to do a CT scan to confirm the diagnosis and location of the stone. The doctor also decided it was equally important to detect the chemical composition of the kidney stone. Which of the following investigation should be done in this case?
questions.solution:
Option C: Dual-source CT

  • This is a case of nephrolithiasis in which the patient presents with complaints of a burning sensation during urination.

  • Nephrolithiasis is one of the most common renal diseases in adults.

  • Most renal calculi are made of calcium, ammonium magnesium, uric acid, and cystine.

  • The calcium oxalate stone is the most common type in the kidney, followed by calcium phosphate stones.

  • Dual-source CT uses two different x-ray sources with different Kvp and, based on the interaction with different elements, can characterize the type of kidney stones

  • Clinical dual-energy applications include

    • Characterization of abdominal masses,

    • Chemical composition of renal calculi,

    • Myocardial and pulmonary perfusion imaging.

Option A: Spiral CT

  • Spinal CT is done during arterial portography for preoperative detection and localization of focal liver lesions, renal cell carcinoma staging, or pancreatic disease imaging.

Option B: Multidetector CT

  • Multidetector CT is an accurate and noninvasive method for diagnosing any kind of tracheal pathology.

Option D: HRCT

  • It is usually done in cases of pulmonary tuberculosis and interstitial lung disease.

questions.text: A 67-year-old man presented with a strong headache, behaviour disorder, vomiting, and two episodes of partial complex seizures in the last three months. The neurological examination revealed mild mental confusion and bilateral papilledema. MRI image shows a homogeneous and well-circumscribed lesion along the superior sagittal sinus. DSA image showing Sunray/ spoke wheel vasculature (image is shown below ). Most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option D: Meningioma

  • On DSA- The classic angiographic appearance of a meningioma is a radial "sunburst" of vessels extending from the base of the tumor toward its periphery.
  • Dural vessels supply the core or center of the lesion, radiating outward from the vascular pedicle of the tumor.
  • DSA image showing characteristic SUNBURST PATTERN of meningioma.
  • Mother-in-law sign- Lesions that enhance early during the arterial phase and remain opacified well after the venous phase are seen in meningioma.

Other Features of Meningioma

  • Dural tail sign
  • Hyperdense on CT
  • Isointense/Hypointense on T2
  • Calcification
  • Skeletal Hyperostosis
  • Pneumosinus dilatans

Option A: Craniopharyngioma

  • The more common adamantinomatous subtype on MRI appears as a predominantly cystic suprasellar mass with a solid component.
  • Characteristic calcifications may not be discernible, though gradient-echo (GRE) images may show susceptibility effects from calcified components.
  • Cystic areas appear hyperintense on T2-weighted and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) images with heterogeneous isointense to hypointense solid components.
  • Some craniopharyngiomas can be both intrasellar and suprasellar, having a "snowman" appearance.
  • The location of the adamantinomatous subtype is characteristic, with most tumors located in the sellar or suprasellar region.

Option B: Glioblastoma multiforme

  • MRI findings demonstrate a heterogeneous mass generally of low signal intensity on T1-weighted images and high signal intensity on T2-weighted images.
  • There are internal cystic areas, internal flow voids representing prominent vessels, internal areas of high signal intensity on T1 (hemorrhagic foci), neovascularity, necrotic foci, significant peritumoral vasogenic edema, and significant mass effect.

Option C: Oligodendroglioma

  • Oligodendrogliomas do not behave specifically; they are usually heterogeneous but have a relatively low intensity on T1-weighted sequences and a high intensity on T2-weighted sequences.
  • Peritumoral edema is nicely depicted with T2-weighted sequences and fluid-attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) sequences, which are sensitive, but surrounding vasogenic edema is not common in oligodendrogliomas.
  • Perifocal edema is less often observed in low-grade oligodendrogliomas.
  • Small cystic-appearing regions and h]emorrhages are commonly found in the mass.

questions.text: A 48-year-old female comes to the hospital with slowly progressive pain and swelling around the right knee joint. Her past medical history includes Hyperparathyroidism, recurrent renal stones, and pathological fractures. She has a generalized weakness but no history of unwanted weight loss. Laboratory investigation results include S. calcium 11.9 mg/dl, alkaline phosphatase 717 U/L, inorganic phosphorus 1.3 mg/dl, and S. parathyroid hormone 1265 pg/mL. Protein electrophoresis for the M band was negative. An X-ray of the right leg denotes a well-defined osteolytic lesion at the distal end of the femur, as shown in the image below. What is the most common site of this type of lesion?
questions.solution:
ANSWER Option A: Mandible

The radiological features and presenting complaints of this patient mostly suggest a brown tumor.

Brown tumor:

  • A Brown tumor is a benign bone tumor caused by osteoclast-mediated bone resorption and replacement by giant cells and fibrous tissue.
  • It is commonly associated with hyperthyroidism.
  • Involvement of the mandible, maxilla, palate, nasal cavity, paranasal sinuses, and orbital and temporal bones has been reported.
  • Among them, the mandible is the most commonly involved site.
  • These tumors are usually asymptomatic except when large.
  • Radiologically these are shown as single or multiple osteolytic lesions and are associated with pathological fractures.

Option B: Maxilla

  • The mandible is more commonly affected by brown tumors than the maxilla.

Option C: Tibia

  • The tibia is a less common site for brown tumors.
  • Osteosarcoma is more commonly found in the tibia and other long bones.

Option D: 2nd metacarpal

  • The 2nd metacarpal bone can be affected by a brown tumor, but it is far less common than the mandible.
  • Enchondroma is the most common bone tumor of the hand.

questions.text: A 47-year-old man came to the office with complaints of cough and fever for the last week. He also reports mild difficulty in breathing and vomiting since last night. His history is significant for a road traffic accident at 23. He has ten pack-year smoking history. His mother died of chronic kidney disease, and his father has a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The pulse is 112/min, blood pressure is 105/70 mmHg, temperature is 39 C (102.2 F), respiratory rate is 27/min, and SpO2 is 92%. X-ray examination shows a homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins. What would be the most probable diagnosis?

choices.text: Pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe
Pneumonia affecting the superior zone of the right lower lobe

questions.solution:
Option A: Pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe

  • Pneumonia is an inflammation of the lung parenchyma. It is characterized by the presence of fluid or pus in the parenchyma.

  • The symptoms of pneumonia include chest pain, fever, fatigue, confusion, nausea, vomiting, etc.

  • Blood tests such as complete blood count can be performed to diagnose pneumonia. Chest X-ray is mainly used for diagnosis.

  • Pneumonia can be bacterial, viral, or fungal in origin.

  • Silhouette sign refer to the loss of normal borders between thoracic structures. It is caused by intrathoracic radio-opaque mass.

  • Obscuring lesions may be large or small. It may be present inside or outside the lungs.

 

  • Silhouette signs provide useful information regarding the location of the diseased part.

  • X-ray showing homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins indicates pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.

Silhouette sign:

Obscuration of a mediastinal border

  • Occurs by a pathology that is in close anatomical contact with it

Obscuration of the right heart border

  • Rt middle lobe pathology

Obscuration of the left heart border

  • Lingular pathology

Obscuration of aortic knuckle

  • Left apicoposterior pathology

Obscuration of hemidiaphragm

  • Lower lobe pathologies

 

Option B: Pneumonia affecting the superior zone of the right lower lobe

  • Obscuration of the hemidiaphragm will be present in the pathologies of the lower lobe.

  • X-ray showing homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins indicates pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.
    lobe pneumonia | Radiology Case | Radiopaedia.org" class="n3VNCb KAlRDb" data-noaft="1" height="181" jsaction="load:XAeZkd;" jsname="HiaYvf" src="https://prod-images-static.radiopaedia.org/images/34273035/59caed0dade101b371439adb8066ea_jumbo.jpeg" style="margin: 0px;" width="218" />

Option C: Pleural effusion

  • Pleural effusion is characterized by excessive fluid build-up between the pleura layers.

  • Blunting of the costophrenic angle and cardiophrenic tip is present in pleural effusion. Fluid within the horizontal or oblique fissures may also be present

Option D: Obscuration of aortic knuckle

  • Obscuration of the aortic knuckle indicates pathology in the left Apicoposterior region.

  • X-ray showing homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins indicates pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.

questions.text: A 26-year-old P1L1 woman presents to the clinic for advice regarding natural methods of contraception and safe days for intercourse. The doctor explains about cervical mucous method and examines her cervical mucous under a microscope after smearing it on a slide. The mucous shows a ferning or tree like pattern. Which of the following hormones is reponsible for such findings?
questions.solution:
Option D : The cervical mucous showing a tree branching like pattern is suggestive of ferning which is due to the effect of estrogen on cervical mucous. Estrogen is the predominant hormone of proliferative or follicular phase of menstrual cycle. Estrogen makes the cervical mucous thin, slippery, copious and ideal for sperm penetration.

  • The Ferning of the cervical mucus is because of the high estrogen content and its DOES NOT diagnose ovulation.
  • Maximum before ovulation and once ovulation happens, the ferning actually reduces and finally disappears due to the high progesterone. This implies that loss of ferning pattern is suggestive of ovulation.
  • Due to the presence of sodium chloride in the mucus under estrogen effect this fern pattern is also known as Arborisation.

Option A : LH is responsible for Final maturation of the follicle and ovulation. It has no action on cervical mucous.

Option B : FSH is responsible for stimulation and growth of ovarian follicle and negative feedback inhibition of estrogen. It has no action on cervical mucous.

Option C : Progesterone makes cervical mucous thick, scanty and non-penetrable to sperms. It causes loss of spinnbarkeit effect an loss of ferning. These two are thus suggestive of ovulation.

questions.text: A 39-year-old woman, para 3 Live3, complains of severe, progressive secondary dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia. Pelvic examination demonstrates a tender, diffusely enlarged uterus of around 12 weeks pregnant size uterus, with no adnexal tenderness. The results of the endometrial biopsy are normal. This patient most likely has:-
questions.solution:
Option C : A parous woman at 39 years of age with severe, progressive dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia with a diffusely enlarged tender uterus is most likely suggestive of adenomyosis

  • Adenomyosis is a condition in which normal endometrial glands grow into the myometrium. Symptomatic disease primarily occurs in multiparous women over the age of 35 years, compared to endometriosis, in which onset is considerably younger.
  • Patients with adenomyosis complain of dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, and the classical examination findings include a tender, symmetrically enlarged uterus without adnexal tenderness.
  • As compared to fibroids, the 'Progressive' dysmenorrhea here is a classical presentation of adenomyosis. In adenomyosis, the uterine size is almost never more than 14 cms in size
  • Also, the fibroids are generally seen in nulliparous women and mostly the uterus is irregularly enlarged to varying sizes
  • Adenomyosis is benign growth of the endometrium into the muscular layer of the uterus.
  • Patients are usually multiparous, around the age of 40 years.
  • Symptoms: Menorrhagia and progressively increasing dysmenorrhea, Pelvic discomfort, Backache and Dyspareunia.
  • Clinical examination: Typically symmetrical enlargement of uterus (rarely in case of a localized adenomyoma the enlargement may be asymmetrical).
  • Uterus is enlarged but seldom more than a ’14 weeks’ pregnant size uterus.

  • USG findings
    • Uterine enlargement not explained by leiomyoma
    • Subendometrial echogenic linear striations
    • Heterogenous echotexture
    • Cystic anechoic spaces or hypoechoic areas: lakes of endometrial blood
    • Junctional zone between endometrium and myometrium>12 mm (normal 5-8 mm)
    • Obscured endo-myometrial interface
  • Treatment - Progesterone can be used for relief but the definitive treatment is Hysterectomy.

Option A : Endometriosis can present with pain, dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, however is more common in younger women, with infertility and there is no uterine enlargement.

Option B : Endometritis can present with enlarged and tender uterus along with dysmenorrhea and menstrual irregularities but also presents with vaginal discharge, fever and usually presents post delivery or abortion, is associated with uterine currettage and USG shows endometrial collection.

Option D : Uterine sarcoma is a malignant tumor of uterine muscle layer which is rare and may develop in a pre-existing fibroid, present with vaginal bleeding, pelvic pain or pressure, diagnosis should be suspected if pelvic pain accompanies an enlarging uterus specially in menopausal women.

questions.text: Which quantification method is used for the diagnosis of hirsutism in women?
questions.solution:
Option C : The Ferriman–Gallwey score is a method of evaluating and quantifying Hirsutism in women.In the modified method, hair growth is rated from 0 (no growth of terminal hair) to 4 (extensive hair growth) in each of the 9 locations.A patient’s score may therefore range from a minimum score of 0 to a maximum score of 36.Score ≥8 - Hirsutism

Option A : - Bishops score is used to assess inducibility/ response to induction, of a patient planned for induction of labour

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation Closed 1-2 3-4 5
Length (Effacement) >4 3-4 1-2 0
Consistency Firm Medium Soft --
Position Posterior Midline Anterior --
Head : Station -3 -2 -1,0 +1,+2

Option B : ROTTERDAM’S CRITERIA : any 2 of 3 for diagnosis of PCOD

1. Clinical/ Lab hyperandrogenism

2. Anovulation : irregular cycles

3. USG features of PCOS ·

  • PCO : have no cysts, smooth surface of ovary ·
  • Multiple small follicles arranged in periphery (Necklace of pearls), 2-6 mm (< 9mm) > 20 such follicles per ovary
  • Thick stroma
  • Slightly enlarged ovary, ovarian volume > 10 mL (L X W X H X 0.523)

Option D : AFS score is used for grading of endometriosis

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents to Gynecology OPD with complaints of abdominal distention and pain over the previous 3 months. Her physical examination reveals an abdominal mass without shifting dullness and bilateral adnexal masses. Her digital rectal examination reveals the presence of induration in the rectal pouch. Her breast examination and recent mammogram are normal. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Option A: Serous cystadenocarcinomas of both ovaries

  • The patient is a 68-year-old woman with abdominal distention, pain with bilateral adnexal masses, and induration in the rectal pouch. Bilateral adnexal masses in postmenopausal must raise suspicion of epithelial ovarian cancers. Most common of which are serous cystadenomas/ carcinomas. Induration in the rectal pouch suggests locally advanced disease and favors a malignancy.
  • The picture below shows the Serous cystadenocarcinoma.

  • Serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common malignant tumors of ovaries and the most common tumors associated with a bilateral origin.
  • The peak incidence of invasive epithelial ovarian cancer is about 60. About 30% of ovarian neoplasms in postmenopausal women are malignant.
  • Mostly unilocular
  • Bilateral in >50%
  • Mostly malignant
  • Surface growth present
  • Psammoma Bodies are present in 40-45%

​​​​​​​

Option B: Krukenberg’s tumors of the ovaries

  • Krukenberg’s tumors are also bilateral but are associated with another primary malignancy (most commonly gastric carcinoma) and are less common than epithelial tumors.
  • Hence, it is not the correct option.

Option C: Malignant ascites

  • It is ruled out as there is no shifting dullness. Please note that serous cystadenocarcinomas do present with ascites quite commonly.
  • So, it is a false statement.

Option D: Meig's syndrome

  • Meig's syndrome is ascites and pleural effusion associated with fibroma of the ovary, which is again ruled out due to the absence of ascites.
  • So, it is not a true option.

questions.text: A woman undergoes radical hysterectomy with lymphadenectomy for Stage Ib Cervical cancer. On histopathological examination, it was found that there was a 3 cm growth that extended to the lower body of the uterus. What is the subsequent management?

choices.text: Repeat surgery for further disease reduction

questions.solution:
Option D : The point to note here is that in Ca Endometrium, the involvement of the cervix is stage II, but in Ca cervix, involvement of the uterus does not change the staging. It’s considered natural progression of the cancer. Here since a radical surgery has already been done, the patient only requires observation and follow up. The stage here is likely 1B2, macroscopic cancer 2-4 cm in size.

TREATMENT

  • For all stages → Radiotherapy is good
  • Stage I – IIA1 → Radical Hysterectomy
  • Stage IIA2 and beyond → Chemo Radiation

Management of Ca cervix

IA1 <3 mm NO LVSI<3 mm with LVSI

Conization or Extrafascial Hysterectomy

Radical Trachelectomy

Or Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD
IA2 >3 mm <5 mm Same
IB1 >5 mm <2 cm Same
IB2 >2 cm <4 cm Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD
IB3 >4 cm Chemoradiation
IIA1 <4 cm + upper vagina Radical Hysterectomy + Pelvic LAD or Chemoradiation

Option A : Chemotherapy is indicated if stage is 1B3 or beyond II A2

Option B : Radiotherapy is indicated if stage is 1B3 or beyond II A2

Option C : A repeat surgery is not required here as the treatment previously done is complete and only a follow up is required.

questions.text: A 76-year-old female presents to the Gynaecology department with complaints of a non-healing ulcerative lesion on labia majora for the last 12 months. She has had significant weight loss over the last 6 months. On examination, the ulcerative lesion appears reddened. The ulcer is 2x3 cm with no palpable lymphadenopathy. Biopsy shows Squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. What will be your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option B: Stage 1B vulvar Cancer

  • The cancer stage in the patient is stage 1B because the ulcer is >2 cm in size, and there was also no palpable lymphadenopathy.
  • Other characteristics of stage 1B include stromal invasion >1.0 mm confined to the vulva or perineum.

 

 

STAGE 1 1A

 

 Limited to vulva/perineum

 

Size<=2cm stromal invasion <=1mm

 Wide local excision + sentinel lymph node study.

 
1B

 

 Size >2cm stromal invasion >1mm

 

 Radical local excision plus · B/L LAD: central lesion.

Radical local excision plus · U/L LAD for lateral lesion (>2cm from midline).
STAGE 2

 

 Any size, Spreads to lower 1/3 urethra, lower 1/3 vagina, anus.

 

 Early: radical excision/ radical vulvectomy plus B/L LAD.

 

Advanced: radiation + surgery + LAD
STAGE 3

 

 Positive inguinofemoral lymph nodes

 

 Radiation + surgery + LAD.

 
STAGE 4A

 

4B

 The upper urethra, upper vagina, bladder, rectum, pelvis sidewall.

 

Distant metastasis, Pelvic or other lymph nodes.

 Radiation + surgery + LAD.

 

 

 

LAD= lymphadenectomy

 

  • The physician will first conduct a physical and pelvic exam.
  • A biopsy is the best way to confirm the diagnosis, so a small sample of cells is removed from the vulva and examined under a microscope.

Option A: Stage 1A vulvar Cancer

  • Stage 1A vulvar cancer is less than 2cm in size.
  • Stromal invasion is also less than 1cm.
  • Limited to the vulva and the perineum.

Option C: Stage 2 vulvar Cancer

  • Stage 2 vulvar cancer can be of any size.
  • Spreads to lower 1/3rd of the urethra, lower 1/3rd vagina, and anus.

Option D: Stage 3A vulvar cancer

  • In stage 3, cancer spreads to the upper urethra, upper vagina, and bladder.
  • It  also involves the inguinofemoral lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 40-year-old female with abnormal menstrual bleeding and a pelvic mass undergoes a hysterectomy. The image shows the gross specimen removed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Leiomyoma.

  • The image shows a gross hysterectomy specimen showing a fibroid/ leiomyoma.
  • This can present as abnormal uterine bleeding (usually menorrhagia) and pelvic mass.
  • Recognition is based on a solid, well-defined lesion, inside a pseudo capsule, without any surrounding invasion, with a whirling pattern, which differentiates it from malignancy and adenomyosis.
  • Fibroids are the most common uterine tumours and are made of smooth muscle with varying amounts of fibrous connective tissue.
  • Fibroids are classified as submucosal, intramural, or subserosal; the latter may become pedunculated and simulate ovarian tumours.
  • Although most fibroids are asymptomatic, patients may present with abnormal menstrual bleeding, pressure on adjacent organs, pain, infertility, or a palpable abdominal-pelvic mass.
  • Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the most accurate imaging technique for detecting and locating fibroids.

Option B: Adenomyosis

  • Adenomyotic uterus appears  asymmetrically enlarged, globular uterus due to associated myometrial hypertrophy reflected by thickened myometrium, with trabeculated cut surface with ill defined hypertrophic swirls of smooth muscle and petechia-like gray foci of endometrium.
  • A clear demarcation or capsule is absent, unlike as shown in the specimen in the question, which suggests fibroid

Option C: Ovarian neoplasm

  • The image in the question shows a solid benign looking growth arising from the uterus, hence ovarian neoplasm is unlikely, which are mostly cystic and are seen adjacent to the ovary.

Option D: Carcinoma of the uterus

  • Carcinoma is a malignant condition, hence a clear demarcation or capsule as evident in the picture, is unlikely

questions.text: A 35-year-old mother of two children, aged 5 and 6 years has had amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea for the past 12 months. Her serum prolactin level is 450 ng/ml. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Option B : Pituitary adenoma

  • In patients with both galactorrhea and amenorrhea, approximately two-thirds will have hyperprolactinemia; of those, approximately one-third will have a pituitary adenoma.
  • A prolactin level as high as 150-200 ng/mL is almost always due to a pituitary adenoma.

Option A : Menopause is not characterized by galactorrhea

Option C : Breast papilloma is not associated with hyperprolactinemia or amenorrhea

Option D : Sheehan's syndrome is characterized by amenorrhea and lactation failure (not galactorrhea)

questions.text: A P3L3 with the previous 3 LSCS presents for a sterilization procedure. During surgery, the surgeon encounters pelvic adhesions such that only the most distal parts of the fallopian tube are approachable, and so he cuts the fimbrial ends and ligates them. What is the procedure known?
questions.solution:
Option D: Kroener method

  • The technique of fimbriectomy, as described by Kroener, employs the ligation of the distal ampulla of the tube with two permanent sutures and then division and removal of the infundibulum of the tube.
  • It is the most effective method for fimbriectomy.

Option A: Uchida method

  • This method involves dissecting the Fallopian tube from the overlying connective tissue (serosa), placing two ligatures and excising a segment of the tube, and then buries the end of the Fallopian tube closest to the uterus underneath the serosa.
  • A saline-epinephrine solution is injected into the subserosal area of the tube, causing the muscular tube to separate from the serosa. The ballooned serosa is incised, and the muscular tube is withdrawn.

Option B: Irving method

  • Tubal ligation by the Irving method starts by placing two ligatures around the fallopian tube in its proximal to mid-segment and removing the tubal segment between the two ligatures.
  • This procedure calls for placing two ligatures (sutures) around the fallopian tube and removing the segment of tubing between the ligatures.
  • Then to complete the procedure, the ends of the fallopian tubes are connected to the back of the uterus and the connective tissue, respectively

Option C: Madlener technique

  • In this technique, a loop of the tube is elevated and crushed before ligation with permanent suture. While no tube is excised, the ligated segment undergoes aseptic necrosis.
  • The end result is similar to the laparoscopic sterilization procedure employing a Silastic band for occlusion as described elsewhere in this text, but with much higher failure rates likely due to fistula formation beneath the permanent suture allowing the ligated segments of the tube to reconnect

questions.text: A 25-year-old G2P1L1 with an Rh-negative blood group reaches the labor room in full dilatation. Her husband's blood group is A+ and her pregnancy was uneventful. Examination shows a normal fetal heart sound. Which of the following is contraindicated in the management of this patient through different stages of the delivery?

choices.text: Cord blood to be saved in 2 vials – plain & EDTA vial
Avoidance of manual removal of placenta

questions.solution:
Option D: Prophylactic use of ergometrine

  • Hemolytic Disease of the Newborn (HDN) is also known by other names, including alloimmunization, isoimmunization, blood incompatibility, or blood sensitization
  • The most common red blood cell incompatibility is due to the Rh protein (also called D protein).
  • Rh disease is the only incompatibility that can be prevented through the administration of a special treatment called "immune globulin" during times of potential exposure to prevent antibody formation.
  • It is recommended that all Rh-negative women receive Rho(D) immune globulin during pregnancy and after delivery if there is a possibility that the father of the baby carries the Rh protein (is Rh positive).
  • Using ergot derivatives is contraindicated in Rh-negative mothers to avoid chances of feto-maternal micro transfusions.
  • As the mother is Rh -ve, early cord clamping decreases the chances of Rh isoimmunization.
  • Cord blood is sampled for the baby's blood group and Direct Coombs Test
  • Manual removal of the placenta is avoided as it would increase the risk of microtransfusion to the mother causing further sensitization

 

Option A: Cord blood to be saved in 2 vials – plain & EDTA vial

  • The blood obtained from the cord should be saved in the EDTA vial and the plain vial.
  • This blood is used to detect the baby’s blood group and perform a direct coomb test.

 

Option B: Early clamping of the cord

  • Early cord clamping can be done as chances for the rh iso-immunization are low due to the negative Rh status of the mother.

 

Option C: Avoidance of manual removal of placenta

  • Microtransfusion of the blood may result during the manual removal of the blood.
  • Hence it should be avoided.

questions.text: A woman presents in a subsequent pregnancy at 38 weeks at the onset of labor pains. She is admitted for safe delivery. On examination, the cervix is 2 cm dilated and membranes are intact, fetal heart is good. With which of the following findings can the patient be allowed to progress with labor?
questions.solution:
