Option A : Occipito-posterior can deliver normally

80% of occipito-posterior deliver normally by becoming occipito-anterior by forward rotation in favorable pelvis in advancing labour.

Out of total Occipito posterior position,

-80% becomes OccipitoAnterior-

  • Mode of delivery - Normal (hence it is preferable to wait and watch for spontaneous rotation to occur)

-15-16% becomes persistent OccipitoPosterior

  • occurs in anthropoid pelvis
  • Mode of delivery - Face to pubis delivery

-2-4% undergoes Deep transverse arrest

  • occurs in android pelvis
  • Mode of delivery - Manual rotation and forceps extraction(sagittal suture of baby should be in AP plane of pelvis) or cesarean section

Indications for LSCS

  • Cephalopelvic disproportion or contracted pelvis
  • Placenta previa
  • Fetal hypoxia
  • Previous cesarean : >=2, previous classical cesarean, previous hysterotomy
  • Pelvic tumors
  • Active genital herpes
  • Transverse lie, complicated breech, non cephalic presenting twin
  • Uterine rupture
  • Scarred uterus such as previous myomectomy, unification surgery
  • Other medical or surgical complications necessitating surgery

Option B : Transverse lie is an absolute contraindication for vaginal delivery

Option C :Absolute indications for cesarean in breech presentation are:

  • Footling breech
  • Breech with extended head
  • Complicated breech such as twin, previous cesarean etc
  • Any of the above mentioned obstetric indications

Option D : contracted pelvis is an indication for LSCS

questions.text: A G2P1L1 presents at 10 weeks for routine evaluation. She had a history of hypothyroidism in her last pregnancy, for which she took supplements and discontinued after pregnancy. Which of the following may be physiologically increased in pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Option D: Thyroid binding globulin

  • Early in the first trimester, the level of the principal carrier protein called thyroxin binding globulin (TBG) increases, reaches its peak at about 20 weeks, and stabilises at approximately double baseline values for the remainder of the pregnancy.
  • The increased TBG concentrations result from higher hepatic synthesis rates due to estrogen stimulation and lower metabolism rates due to increased TBG sialylation and glycosylation.
  • Thes elevated TBG levels increase total serum thyroxin (T4) and triiodothyronine (T3) concentrations but do not affect the physiologically important serum-free T4 and T3 levels.

Option A: TSH/thyrotropin

  • The α-subunits of two glycoproteins, TSH and hCG, are identical, whereas the β-subunits, although similar, differ in their amino acid sequence.
  • As a result of this structural similarity, hCG has intrinsic thyrotropic activity, and thus, high serum hCG levels cause thyroid stimulation, and thus due to feedback inhibition, TSH levels decrease
  • Indeed, thyrotropin levels decrease in more than 80% of pregnant women.

Option B: Free T3

  • Free T3 levels are unchanged during the pregnancy.

Option C: Free T4

  • Free T4 levels are unchanged during the pregnancy

questions.text: A woman is brought by her relatives in an unconscious state. She delivered at home one hour back. On examination, the patient is pale and has a pulse rate of 124/min with unrecordable blood pressure. Which of the following is the most likely associated finding that should be looked for next?

choices.text: CT chest suggestive of amniotic fluid embolism

questions.solution:
Option A: Vaginal bleeding

  • The most frequent cause of shock in the postpartum period is Postpartum haemorrhage, the cause of which most likely is the failure of the uterus to contract sufficiently after delivery and to arrest bleeding from vessels at the placental implantation site

Option B: Raised urine albumin

  • A raised urine albumin indicates kidney injury.
  • During pregnancy, proteinuria usually occurs in the setting of pre-eclampsia.
  • This patient has unrecordable blood pressure, which makes pre-eclampsia highly unlikely

Option C: Inverted uterus

  • An inverted uterus may cause shock due to high vagal activity.
  • However, this is a far less common cause of shock than blood loss

Option D: CT chest suggestive of amniotic fluid embolism

  • ​​​​​​​If the question was 'sudden unexplained death', then an amniotic fluid embolism can be the answer
  • The true incidence of AFE is unknown but has been reported to range from 1:8 000 to 1:80 000 pregnancies.
  • Amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is a syndrome of sudden peripartum shock.
  • This catastrophic obstetric emergency can present as sudden, profound, and unexpected maternal collapse associated with hypotension, hypoxaemia, and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). It occurs when amniotic fluid, fetal cells, hair, or other debris enter the maternal circulation.
  • Risk Factors:
    • Advanced maternal age; multiparity; meconium stained liquor; intrauterine fetal death; polyhydramnios; strong frequent or tetanic uterine contractions; maternal history of allergy or atopy; chorioamnionitis;
    • AFE is caused by fetal antigens in the amniotic fluid stimulating a cascade of endogenous immune mediators, producing a reaction similar to anaphylaxis

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida presents to the hospital with postpartum seizures. She is diagnosed with eclampsia, and magnesium sulfate is started. While on magnesium sulfate therapy, her respiratory rate falls to 10/min and her SpO2 drops to 55%. She was quickly intubated and started on invasive ventilation. Among various lab tests, the doctor orders Mg2+ levels. Which of the following are expected levels of Mg2+ in this patient?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Option C: >10 mEq/L

  • This patient on magnesium sulfate therapy due to postpartum eclampsia has most likely developed magnesium toxicity. This is evident from decreased respiratory rate and SpO2, indicating respiratory depression.
  • Respiratory depression in magnesium toxicity occurs at levels >10 mEq/L.

 

  • Eclampsia is a hypertensive pregnancy disorder characterised by seizures and preeclampsia (headaches, visual disturbances, nausea, high BP, and proteinuria).
  • The first-line treatment of eclampsia is magnesium sulfate therapy.
  • While giving MgSO4, the following points should be considered:
    • Respiratory rate should be at least more than 12
    • Output should be more than 100 ml / 4hrs
    • Knee jerks should be present
  • Magnesium sulfate therapy during the management of eclampsia can result in magnesium toxicity.
  • During Magnesium toxicity, the first reflex to be lost is the patellar reflex (loss of knee jerk).
  • Clinical features of increasing blood magnesium levels are given in the table:
Serum Mg2+ levels(meq/l) Clinical effects
4-7 Normal therapeutic level
8 – 10 Patellar reflex disappears
10-15 Respiratory depression
12-15 Respiratory paralysis
25 – 30 Cardiac arrest
  • Treatment is with calcium gluconate 1 g IV

Option A: 5–7 mEq/L

  • This is the normal therapeutic range of magnesium in the blood. There will be no signs of toxicity at these levels.

Option B: 7-10 mEq/L

  • At these levels, the patellar reflex disappears due to magnesium toxicity. However, there is no respiratory depression at these levels.

Option D: >25 mEq/L

  • This is an advanced stage of magnesium toxicity characterised by cardiac and respiratory arrest.
  • The given patient has not yet developed cardiopulmonary arrest.

questions.text: A 26-year-old primigravida presents at 10 weeks of pregnancy. She is a known case of epilepsy on anticonvulsant therapy. Which of the following is true about the pharmacotherapy of this patient in pregnancy?

choices.text: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice
Therapeutic drug monitoring is not required
Folic acid supplementation prevents the risk of neural tube defects in these patients
Lamotrigine is the most teratogenic drug.

questions.solution:
Option C: Folic acid supplementation prevents the risk of neural tube defects in these patients.

  • Fetal malformations are more likely due to anticonvulsants than epilepsy itself.
  • Lowest dose monotherapy is the goal. Multidrug therapy increases the risk of malformations.
  • Preferable to increase the dose if needed and then add another drug.
  • Phenytoin, phenobarbitol, and valproate are teratogens with known fetal malformation risk
  • Lamotrigine and levetiracetam have the lowest risk of malformation
  • Most are safe with breastfeeding
  • All epileptic women should be advised to take a 5mg folic acid supplement prior to conception to reduce the rate of neural tube defects.

Option A: Sodium valproate is the drug of choice

  • Sodium valproate is the most teratogenic drug.
  • The likelihood of teratogenicity is dose-dependent (>1000mg/day), and it should be avoided in pregnant women, except when epilepsy cannot be controlled with other antiepileptic drugs.
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

Option B: Therapeutic drug monitoring is not required

  •  
  • Increased seizure rates is seen in up to 20-30% of pregnancies with epilepsy. This has two important causes :lower seizure threshold and subtherapeutic anticonvulsant levels
  • All anticonvulsant drugs are associated with congenital anomalies. Therefore, therapeutic drug monitoring is required.
  • All epileptic women should be advised to take a 5mg folic acid supplement prior to conception to reduce the rate of neural tube defects.

 

Option D: Lamotrigine is the most teratogenic drug

  • Lamotrigine is the drug of choice in pregnancy due to its lowest teratogenicity risk.
  • Leveteracitam is also least teratogenic and may be considered as drug of choice
  • Therefore, this option is not correct.

questions.text: A woman in the 16th week of pregnancy presented to the maternity clinic with complaints of fever. On examination, there are pink, macular spots on her abdomen. Her blood pressure is 130/90, her pulse is 86/minute, and her temperature is 103.5℉. Investigations reveal a blood culture positive for Salmonella typhi. Which of the following antibiotics is the most preferred treatment for this infection?
questions.solution:
Option D: Ceftriaxone

  • Salmonella is facultative intracellular flagellated gram-negative rods of two types; Salmonella Typhi and salmonella non-Typhi. They are a common cause of osteomyelitis in patients with sickle cell disease and can also cause endocarditis, septic arthritis and mycotic aneurysms.
  • Salmonella non-Typhi causes gastroenteritis and is spread by poultry, eggs and pets, most commonly in underdeveloped countries. Antibiotics are usually not indicated for salmonella non-Typhi infection. It invaded the gastrointestinal tract and remains localized into the Peyer's patches in lamina propria.
  • Salmonella typhi has a capsular antigen(Vi) which causes it to evade the neutrophilic response, undergoes extensive replication in macrophages and spreads via lymphatics and the reticuloendothelial system. It causes typhoid fever which has the following features:
    • Fever with pulse temperature dissociation (as seen in the patient in the above clinical scenario).
    • Rose spots (pink maculopapular rash on the abdomen).
    • Constipation.
    • Abdominal pain.
    • Gastrointestinal ulceration and perforation.
    • Hepatosplenomegaly.
  • Fluoroquinolones and third-generation cephalosporins, such as ceftriaxone, are the preferred treatment for typhoid fever.Common side effects include GI upset, superinfections, skin rash, leg cramps, myalgias and tendon rupture. These are contraindicated in pregnant women, nursing mothers and children less than 18 years old due to cartilage damage.
  • Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin, a beta-lactam drug that inhibits cell wall synthesis. It is effective against salmonella, shigella, and endocarditis by Streptococcus Viridans, meningitis, gonorrhoea, Lyme disease and empiric management of sepsis. Adverse effects include hypersensitivity reactions, autoimmune hemolytic anaemia and interstitial nephritis. Ceftriaxone is safer to use in a pregnant woman with Salmonella typhi infection as it has no adverse effects on the developing fetus.
  • Typhoid vaccines are of two types; the oral vaccine is live attenuated, and the IM vaccine contains Vi capsular polysaccharide. They appear to exert no harmful effects when administered to pregnant women and should be given in an epidemic or before travel to endemic areas.

 

Option A: Ampicillin

  • Ampicillin is penicillin which blocks the synthesis of the cell wall of bacteria.
  • It can be used to treat salmonella infection, but it is not the first-line treatment for typhoid fever.
  • Side effects include hypersensitivity and pseudomembranous colitis.

 

Option B: Chloramphenicol

  • It is a bacteriostatic antibiotic that blocks peptidyltransferase at the 50S ribosomal subunit and halts the translation of bacterial mRNA. Due to its low cost, it is used in treating meningitis and rickettsial disease in developing countries.
  • It is not used in the treatment of typhoid fever.

 

Option C: Ciprofloxacin

  • Ciprofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone antibiotic used to treat gram-negative urinary and GI tract infections, including typhoid fever. Fluoroquinolones are contraindicated in pregnancy due to possible damage to the developing cartilage of fetus.

questions.text: A 27-year-old female, G3P2, presents in the gynecological ER with complaints of vaginal bleeding and right-sided lower abdominal pain associated with amenorrhea for more than five weeks. She also complains of shoulder pain. On examination, her PR is 120/min, and her BP is 80/50 mmHg, the abdomen shows tenderness and vaginal examination reveals cervical motion tenderness with fullness in the right fornix. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C : History is suggestive of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy in view of acute abdominal pain, pallor and hypotension due to hemoperitoneum. Vaginal bleeding is only due to shedding of decidua. Infertility, per se, (as suggested in this case by history of ovulation induction) as well as the use of Assisted reproductive technology is linked to substantively increased risks for ectopic pregnancy

Presentation of ruptured ectopic

    • Amenorrhea followed by pain abdomen
    • Bleeding PV
    • Triad :pain + bleeding + amenorrhea
    • Syncopal attacks
    • Pain abdomen with distension
       

Signs

    • Shock
    • Abdominal distension
    • On P/v Examination
      • Cervical motion tenderness
      • Adnexal tenderness
      • Fullness in Pouch of Douglas

Option A : Uterine fibroid does not present with such acute presentation, it manifests as menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea or chronic pelvic pain.

Option B : An ovarian cyst can present with acute pain abdomen in case of torsion or rupture, but pallor and hypotension are suggestive of hemoperitoneum.

Option D : Inevitable abortion presents with pain and bleeding, however the pallor and hypotension here should be proportional to the amount of bleeding as all the bleeding is revealed, which here is mentioned to be only slight.

questions.text: A 35-year-old multigravida has had amenorrhea for about 4 months. She had an abortion 5 months back, followed by a curettage to stop bleeding. A urine pregnancy test is negative. A progesterone withdrawal test performed is negative. What is the most likely cause of amenorrhea in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D : The Patient had a second-trimester abortion, following which a curettage was done to remove the retained products leading to intrauterine adhesions called Ashermann syndrome. These adhesions make the endometrium non-functional such that it does not grow( or bleed subsequently) with endogenous E+P (as ovarian function is normal) and similarly to exogenous E+P (E+P challenge).The best diagnostic method is hysteroscopy to visualise adhesions and this is treated by adhesiolysis.

Asherman syndrome

  • Characterized by uterine synechiae, usually results from destruction on large areas of endometrium by overzealous curettage done for
    • AUB
    • MTP
    • Secondary PPH (due to retained bits of placenta)
  • Clinical features - Hypomenorrhea, amenorrhoea, oligomenorrhoea
  • Definitive diagnosis – Hysteroscopy
  • Preferred Rx –Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis and post operative high dose estrogen and progesterone therapy to rebuild the endometrium

Option A and B: Patients with both hypothalmo/ pituitary failure and ovarian failure will get menses with E + P. Absence of withdrawal by E + P indicates end organ failure. In both hypothalamic/ pituitary failure and ovarian failure the end defect is absence of E and P, which when overcome by exogenous E+P, must make the endometrium grow and bleed subsequently.

Option C : In patient with secondary amenorrhea, after ruling out pregnancy progesterone challenge test is to be done. Patients with anovulation will get menses with progesterone. (Progesterone acts only on estrogen primed endometrium. In patients with anovulation, estrogen is present but progesterone is absent).

questions.text: A woman presents to the emergency with heavy vaginal bleeding following a vaginal delivery at home one hour ago. On examination, the doctor diagnosed a traumatic PPH secondary to a complete perineal tear. All of the following regarding complete perineal tear is correct EXCEPT?

choices.text: It includes tears from vaginal mucosa up to the level of rectal mucosa
Internal anal sphincter is identified and repaired separately

questions.solution:
Option D : Complete perineal tear is more often associated with median episiotomy than medio-lateral one.

Option A : Perineal lacerations are classified as

  • First-degree: Fourchette, perineal skin, and vaginal mucosa
  • Second-degree: First degree + fascia and muscles of the perineal body
  • Third-degree: Second degree + anal sphincter
  • Fourth-degree: Third-degree and a tear through rectal mucosa to expose the lumen of the rectum.

Option B, C : Repair of CPT is done in layers.

  • Approximation of the anorectal mucosa and submucosa
  • Rectal muscularis layer + internal anal sphincter
  • Torn end of external anal sphincter by end-to-end anastomoses
  • Then the muscles are repaired in 1-2 layers and then the perineal skin is sutured

Timing of repair: A recent tear should be repaired immediately while in case of delay beyond 24 hours, the repair should be performed after 3 months and antibiotics must be used meanwhile for the prevention of infection.

Compete perineal tear may occur as a complication of vaginal delivery in rigid perineum, shoulder dystocia or instrumental manipulations or may occur as an extension of a midline episiotomy

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with active labor at the 38th week of gestation. Emergency lower segment cesarean section is planned for the patient by the obstetrician. Which of the following is the true statement regarding the cesarean section?

choices.text: Exteriorisation of the uterus for the repair of the uterine incision is a detrimental step and hence avoided
Two-layer closure of uterine incision is associated with significantly less risk of scar rupture
All incidental uterine fibroids should be excised during LSCS
Lower segment cesarean has a lower risk of scar dehiscence in next pregnancy compared to classical

questions.solution:
Correct answer

Option D : Lower segment caesarean has lower risk of scar dehiscence in next pregnancy compared to classical: The correct statement is that lower segment Caesarean has a lower risk of scar dehiscence in the next pregnancy compared to classical Caesarean section. A lower segment Caesarean, also known as low-transverse or low-vertical incision, is the preferred type of incision during Caesarean section because it has been associated with a lower risk of uterine scar dehiscence and rupture in subsequent pregnancies. On the other hand, a classical Caesarean section, which involves a vertical incision in the upper segment of the uterus, is associated with a higher risk of scar dehiscence in future pregnancies.

 

Option A : Exteriorisation of the uterus for repair of uterine incision is a common step during Caesarean section, and it is not considered detrimental. Exteriorisation allows the surgeon to have better access to the uterine incision, facilitating proper repair and closure. This step is typically performed during Caesarean section surgeries.

Option B : Two-layer closure of the uterine incision is associated with a higher risk of scar rupture. The two-layer closure involves suturing the uterine muscle layer separately from the uterine lining (endometrial layer). Research has shown that single-layer closure is associated with lower rates of uterine scar dehiscence and rupture compared to two-layer closure. Single-layer closure is the current standard of care in many institutions for low-transverse uterine incisions.

Option C : Incidental uterine fibroids may be encountered during Caesarean section surgeries. However, not all incidental uterine fibroids need to be excised during the procedure. The decision to remove fibroids during a Caesarean section depends on factors such as the size, location, and potential impact on the surgery or future pregnancies. Not all fibroids require removal during a routine Caesarean section.

questions.text: An 8-day-old neonate is brought to the emergency department due to severe vomiting for 1 day. Physical examination reveals hyperpigmentation of the skin, severe dehydration, and ambiguous genitalia. The laboratory investigations reveal serum glucose level of 44mg/dl, serum Na+ 110mEq/L and K+ 6.2mEq/L. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Congenital adrenal hyperplasia

  • The patient presents with congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) clinical features.
  • CAH is a group of autosomal recessive defects in steroid synthesis.
  • 90% of the cases are due to the deficiency of 21-hydroxylase.
  • This result is the diminished synthesis of cortisol and aldosterone.
  • This reduces the negative feedback on ACTH, which results in increased ACTH production.
  • Excessive ACTH causes accumulation of steroid precursors, i.e., dehydroepiandrosterone, androstenedione and 17-hydroxy progesterone.
  • The patients present with the following:
  • Salt wasting
  • Virilization
  • Recurrent vomiting
  • Polyuria
  • Hyperpigmentation
  • Shock
  • Failure to thrive
  • Electrolyte abnormalities due to salt wasting include:
  • Hyponatremia
  • Hyperkalemia
  • Hypoglycemia
  • Diagnosis is confirmed by measurement of 17-hydroxyprogesterone levels in the blood.
  • The best method to diagnose CAH is the estimation of 17-hydroxyprogesterone level before and 1 hour after intramuscular injection of ACTH.
  • The non-classic form of CAH has a partial deficiency of 21-hydroxylase. These patients show mild hyperandrogenism (hirsutism, acne, and menstrual irregularity).
  • Other variants include 11B-hydroxylase deficiency (10%) and 17alpha-hydroxylase deficiency. These patients present with hypertension and are managed with hydrocortisone only.
  • Patients require life-long treatment.
  • Treatment includes hydrocortisone and fludrocortisone.

Option A: Pyloric stenosis

  • Pyloric stenosis presents at 4-6 weeks of life with non-bilious vomiting, olive-shaped mass in the abdomen, fluid thrill and abdominal distension.
  • Hypochloremic, hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis is seen in pyloric stenosis.

Option B: Hypothyroidism

  • Hypothyroidism in the neonatal period presents as coarse facial features, large tongue and abdomen, umbilical hernia, lethargy, prolonged jaundice, constipation, hypothermia, and hoarse cry.
  • Vomiting and ambiguous genitalia are not seen in hypothyroidism.

Option C: Hyperaldosteronism

  • Hyperaldosteronism presents with hypertension, hypernatremia, and hypokalemia.
  • No changes in blood/serum glucose levels are seen.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the hospital with difficulty walking. The mother reports that the child usually falls while walking and cannot climb stairs. Family history reveals a cousin, who died in his teenage, also had symptoms of muscle weakness. On physical examination, there is proximal muscle weakness in the lower limbs associated with pseudohypertrophy of the calf muscles. The patient started with Eteplirsen, which has been recently approved by FDA and shows some improvement. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Duchenne muscular dystrophy

  • Most common hereditary neuromuscular disease in children.
  • X-linked recessive deletion of the dystrophin gene ( Xp 21)- one of the largest gene

CLINICAL FEATURES:

  • Phase 3 trials have shown benefits from ETEPLIRSEN - FDA APPROVED
  • More common in males. Family history present.
  • Pseudohypertrophy of calf muscles.
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy.
  • Recurrent respiratory infections.
  • Proximal muscle weakness in limbs
  • Intellectual disability
  • 'GOWER SIGN' is positive- Gowers' sign indicates weakness of the proximal muscles, especially of the lower limb, due to the replacement of muscles with fat
  • Phase 3 trials have shown benefits from ETEPLIRSEN - FDA APPROVED

Option B: Spinal muscular dystrophy

  • Spinal muscular dystrophy (SMN) gene mutation

  • Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) are absentwhile present in Duchenne muscular dystrophy.
  • Tongue fasciculations.

Option C: SSPE

  • Subacute sclerosing panencephalitis (SSPE) is seen after an attack of measles.

  • It causes myoclonic jerks and seizures.

  • Mental deterioration is also seen.

Option D: AML

  • Acute myelogenous leukaemia (AML) presents with fever, bone pain, lethargy and fatigue.

  • Many subtypes present
  • Auer rods are typical on blood smear

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl is brought to the paediatric outpatient department by her mother due to joint pains and morning stiffness for 3 months. It is associated with eye pain and photophobia. Her mother reports that the patient limps while walking, which is severe during the early morning hours. Physical examination reveals tender, swollen knees and ankles bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
Option B: Juvenile idiopathic arthritis

  • The patient presents with the clinical features of juvenile idiopathic arthritis (oligoarticular type).
  • Juvenile idiopathic arthritis is characterized by the following:
  • Age at onset< 16 years
  • Duration of disease ≥ 6 weeks
  • Arthritis
  • Associated uveitis, iridocyclitis
  • Types of JIA include:
    • Systemic JIA (systemic involvement is seen)
    • Oligoarticular (4 or fewer joints are involved)
    • Polyarticular (More than 5 joints are involved)
    • Psoriatic (associated with skin lesions)
    • Enthesitis-related arthritis
    • Undifferentiated arthritis
  • The HLA antigen associated with JIA is DR4.
  • C-reactive protein measurement is a marker of disease activity and is helpful in follow-up.
  • Treatment includes physiotherapy, occupational therapy, NSAIDs, and disease-modifying anti-rheumatic drugs (DMARDs).
  • Intra-articular steroids are used for patients who are non-responsive to medical therapy.
  • Newer treatments include IL-1 receptor antagonists (anakinra) and monoclonal antibodies.

Option A: Rheumatic fever

  • Rheumatic fever is characterized by carditis, arthritis, Sydenham's chorea, subcutaneous nodules, and erythema marginatum.
  • Limping and eye pain are not seen in rheumatic fever.

Option C: Behcet syndrome

  • Behcet syndrome presents with oral ulcers, genital ulcers, and ocular lesions.
  • Limping and morning stiffness are not seen in Behcet syndrome.

Option D: Chikungunya fever

  • An arthropod vector causes chikungunya.
  • It causes joint pains like dengue, headache, rash, and swelling.
  • Transient arthritis occurs, which resolves before 6 weeks.

questions.text: A 5-month-old male infant is brought to the pediatric clinic by his parents with complaints of sudden, repetitive jerking movements of his arms and legs. The parents report that these episodes last a few seconds and occur multiple times throughout the day. Developmental milestones are delayed. On examination, you observe brief flexion and extension movements of the limbs during the episodes. The rest of the physical examination is positive for ash-leaf spots and periungual fibromas. Based on the clinical presentation, what is the drug of choice for the management of infantile spasms in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option D: Vigabatrin

  • In this case, a male child presents to the hospital with multiple seizures and impaired mental functioning since birth. On further examination, the patient presents with ash-leaf spots and pitted teeth. The doctor advised an MRI brain, which revealed the presence of subependymal nodules. This scenario indicates that the child is suffering from tuberous sclerosis.
  • Tuberous sclerosis is a rare multi-system disease in which non-cancerous tumours grow in different body organs, which are benign in nature.
  • In this disorder, mutations in the TSC1 (Chr 9) or TSC2 (Chr 16) gene can cause tuberous sclerosis complex. Skin manifestations include ash leaf macules, adenoma sebaceum, cafe au lait spots and shagreen patches.
  • CNS manifestations include developmental delay, intellectual disability, seizures and autism. MRI shows tram-track calcification in these patients.
  • The drug of choice for infantile spasms in a child with Tuberous sclerosis is Vigabatrin.
  • This drug is an analogue of gamma-aminobutyric acid, the inhibitory neurotransmitter.

Option A: Diazepam

  • It is a drug that belongs to the benzodiazepine family that acts as an anxiolytic. It is usually used to treat anxiety, seizures, and alcohol withdrawal.
  • It is the drug of choice in the condition known as status epileptics. It is very specific in action.

Option B: ACTH

  • Adrenocorticotropic is a hormone of the anterior pituitary gland. This hormone is also used as a medication and diagnostic agent.
  • ACTH can be used if treatment with Vigabatrin fails. The drug of choice for infantile spasms is ACTH injection.

Option C: Levetiracetam

  • It is a drug that belongs to the pyrrolidine class. It is also used to treat seizures.
  • This drug is used mostly in partial, tonic-clonic, and myoclonic seizures.

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy is brought to an outdoor department with a history of decreased urine output, cola-coloured urine, and swelling of the face and hands for 2 days. On examination, he is hypertensive, has a puffy face, and pitting oedema of the lower limbs but is vitally stable. He has a history of skin lesions 4 weeks earlier. A diagnosis of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is made. ASO titers, in this case, will be?

choices.text: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

questions.solution:
Correct Answer Option A: Elevated

  • In case of Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN), antistreptolysin O (ASO) titers are typically elevated.

    Poststreptococcal Glomerulonephritis (PSGN) is a type of kidney inflammation that occurs following an infection with certain strains of group A Streptococcus bacteria. It most commonly develops after a streptococcal throat or skin infection, such as strep throat or impetigo.

    During the infection, the body produces antibodies, including antistreptolysin O (ASO), to fight the streptococcal bacteria. ASO is an antibody specifically directed against the streptolysin O toxin produced by the bacteria.

Option B: Not Elevated

  • It is false statement

Option C: Increased Progressively over 3 days

  • This option is incorrect

Option D: Initially elevated, rapidly fall in 3-4 days

  • The levels fall over 6 to 12 months to insignificant levels.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is best to investigate an underweight child with chronic diarrhea, pallor, mild dehydration, and iron deficiency anemia?
questions.solution:
Option A : IgA anti-Tissue transglutaminase

  • As likely diagnosis is coeliac disease, antibodies commonly found are anti-Endomysial (the most diagnostically accurate laboratory test for the diagnosis of celiac disease), anti-reticulin, anti-tissue transglutaminase, and anti-gliadin. They are strongly associated with celiac disease and used for its diagnosis.

Option B: Thyrotropin receptor antibody (TRAb)

  • It is found in Graves' disease patients who present clinical features of thyrotoxicosis and eye symptoms.

Option C: Anti-saccharomyces cerevisiae antibody

  • It is a serological marker that can distinguish between Crohn's disease (CD) and ulcerative colitis (UC) and predict disease phenotype.

Option D: Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) staining

  • It is used to diagnose Whipple's disease in which Periodic acid-Schiff (PAS) positive, non-acid-fast granules are found in macrophages of intestinal biopsy specimens.

questions.text:
A newborn baby was brought to the hospital with complaints of cyanosis associated with paroxysmal attacks of tachycardia. The rest of the examination is normal. The ECG shows tall P waves with a right-bundle branch block. An X-ray revealed the below-depicted image.



Which of the following is responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
Option A: Lithium

  • This patient with cyanosis and features of acute heart failure with a box-shaped heart on chest x-ray is most likely suffering from Ebstein’s anomaly.
  • It is caused by in-utero exposure to lithium during pregnancy. Lithium is a drug used in bipolar disorder.
  • Downward displacement of posterior & septal leaflets of the Tricuspid valve is observed, which results in atrialization of the right ventricle.
  • Huge cardiomegaly, especially in the right atrium, is seen
  • ECG:
    • Very tall & broad P waves were seen due to enlarged atria.
    • These P waves look like a mountain; hence called 'Himalayan' p waves

Option B: Valproate

  • Valproate is an anticonvulsant that can be used in bipolar disorder.
  • It is contraindicated in pregnancy and can cause
    • Neural Tube Defects (NTD)
    • Craniofacial Abnormalities
    • Congenital Heart Defects (CHD)
  • The CHD associated with valproate is coarctation of the aorta, aortic stenosis, pulmonary atresia, and VSD.
  • Our patient has no signs or symptoms suggesting any of the above-mentioned anomalies. In addition, the rest of the physical examination did not find any other abnormality, such as a craniofacial defect. Therefore, valproate exposure is a less likely cause.

Option C: Phenytoin

  • In-utero exposure to phenytoin can cause fetal hydantoin syndrome.
  • It is characterised by cleft palate, phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia, excessive hair growth, and intrauterine growth restriction.
  • In addition, it can cause congenital heart defects such as ASD, VSD, Coarctation of the Aorta, and PDA.
  • Our patient has no signs or symptoms suggesting any of the above-mentioned anomalies. In addition, the rest of the physical examination did not find any other abnormality, such as a cleft lip or any anomalies in the digits. Therefore, phenytoin exposure is a less likely cause.

Option D: Alcohol

  • Alcohol exposure can lead to fetal alcohol syndrome.

  • It is characterised by facial deformities, renal aplasia causing hypertension, limb abnormalities, and congenital heart defects, among other complications.

  • Our patient has no signs or symptoms suggesting any of the above-mentioned anomalies. In addition, the rest of the physical examination did not find any other abnormality. Therefore, alcohol exposure is a less likely cause.

questions.text: A 4-month-old male baby presents to the pediatrician with persistent diarrhea. The patient had a history of recurrent attacks of pneumonia and otitis media, for which he had to be hospitalized. No live vaccines were administered to the patient. Further history reveals the diagnosis of severe combined immunodeficiency. Which of the following features is associated with the condition of this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: GVHD

The patient, in this case, is diagnosed with SCID and graft vs host disease is most likely associated with this disease.

SCID (Severe Combined Immunodeficiency)

  • In this disease, numerous genetic mutations occur that result in the defective development of functional B and T cells.
  • It is caused by
    • ADA deficiency
    • JAK3 deficiency
    • RAG mutations
  • It may develop mostly if many lymphocytes are introduced into the patient's body or peripheral blood lymphocytes are administered instead of bone marrow cells and cord blood.
  • Due to immune-competent cells attacking an immunosuppressed host, GVHD can still be seen.

Option A: Autoimmune diseases.

  • In SCID, both B and T cells are deficient, so the patient’s immune system is not strong enough to develop any autoimmune disease.
  • So, SCID is not associated with autoimmune diseases.

Option B: Granuloma formation

  • Granuloma is formed in chronic inflammation when the body's immune system forms macrophages to protect against any pathogen.
  • But in SCID immune system is very weak due to a deficiency of B and T cells, so no granuloma formation can occur in this patient.

Option D: Graft rejection

  • Graft rejection can't be done in SCID patients due to a deficiency of T and B cells, which causes a weak body immune system.
  • Combined deficiency of B & T cells is seen in SCID, so autoimmune diseases, granuloma formation & graft rejection are absent.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with a known case of uncontrolled diabetes presents to the clinic with severe pain in the left ear and otorrhoea not responding to antibiotics. On his examination, granulation tissue is seen in the external auditory canal and paralysis of the ipsilateral facial nerve. What would be the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Malignant otitis externa

  • It is a correct statement.

  • Malignant otitis externa is also called acute necrotizing otitis.

  • It is caused by “Pseudomonas Aeruginosa”.

  • The predisposing factors are immunocompromised patients, elderly uncontrolled diabetics, and chemotherapy.

  • The clinical features may include pain and greenish-black discharge.

  • Examination reveals granulations in the external auditory canal.

  • It spreads to the skull base, leading to lateral skull base osteomyelitis.

  • It may also present with multiple cranial nerve palsies; the facial nerve is most commonly affected.

  • It can also spread to skull bone through the fissures of Santorini in the cartilaginous part of the external auditory canal.

  • The dangerous complication of otitis media is a brain abscess.

  • The most common symptoms are headache, fever, nausea, vomiting, neurologic deficits, and altered consciousness.

  • It is confirmed by doing a bone scan (Tc -99m) during early stage.

  • Antibiotics include ciprofloxacin as a drug of choice.

  • Other antibiotics may include third-generation cephalosporins, meropenem, and sulbactam.

Option A: Otomycosis

  • It is a false statement.

  • Otomycosis is an infection of the ear canal due to fungus.

  • It often occurs due to Aspergillus Niger, Aspergillus fumigatus, or Candida albicans.

  •  It is seen in tropical and subtropical countries with hot and humid climates. Secondary fungal growth is also seen in patients using topical antibiotics to treat otitis externa or middle ear suppuration.

  • The clinical features of otomycosis include intense itching, discomfort or pain in the ear, watery discharge with a musty odour, and ear blockage. The fungal mass may appear white, brown, or black and has been likened to a wet piece of filter paper.

Option B: Serous otitis media

  • It is a false statement.

  • Serous otitis media is a special type of effusion caused by transudate formation due to the decrease in middle ear pressure compared to the atmospheric pressure. The fluid, in this case, is watery and clear.

Option D: Eczematous otitis externa

  • It is a false statement.

  • Eczematous external otitis (chronic itchy ears) is characterized by itching, redness, discharge, flaking, oozing, and fissuring.

  • These signs and symptoms suggest inflammation and include all forms of external ear canal skin hypersensitivity.

questions.text: A mother of a newborn noticed strange involuntary eye movement in his eyes after a few hours of birth. On further investigation, she is a known case of syphilis with VDRL+ve. What could be found in doing a fistula test on a child?
questions.solution:
Option C: False positive

Fistula Test–Hennebert sign

  • Fistula test positive without the presence of fistula- false +ve.
  • It is seen in cases of congenital syphilis and Meniere's disease.
  • In congenital syphilis, the stapes footplate is hypermobile, while in Meniere's disease, there is a fibrous band connecting the utricular macula to the stapes footplate.
  • In both these conditions, movements of stapes result in stimulation of utricular macula, which will cause nystagmus and vertigo leading to a false-positive fistula test. This is called as Hennebert sign.
  • This is an important clinical test to diagnose a fistula in the labyrinth (horizontal semicircular canal). Cholesteatoma may cause this fistula.
  • Procedure: The patient has explained the test, and the tragus is pressed repeatedly against the ear canal. Or pressure in the external auditory canal is alternately increased/decreased by siegalisation.
  • Interpretation: If a patient has a fistula in a horizontal semicircular canal, the air currents by repeated tragus pressure or siegalisation will stimulate the labyrinth, and the patient will experience giddiness, vertigo, nausea, or vomiting. This is a fistula test +ve. It indicates that surgical exploration of mastoids should be done at the earliest.
  • Fallacy
    • False -ve test: There can be a fistula without a fistula test positive. This happens in the dead labyrinth or when the fistula is temporarily blocked by cholesteatoma flakes.
    • False + test: There can be a fistula test positive without actually having a fistula. This happens when thinning of the bony labyrinth occurs. This may happen in syphilis and cholesteatoma.

Option A: True positive

  • A true positive test is the test result of an individual who turns positive for which he has been tested.
  • The patient is suffering from a fistula if the fistula test turns positive.

Option B: True negative

  • A true negative test is the test result of an individual who turns negative for which he has been tested.
  • A negative fistula test result means the patient is not suffering from a fistula.

Option D: False negative

  • False negative means the test result of an individual turns negative, but the individual has the condition for which he is tested.
  • There can be a fistula without a fistula test positive.
  • This happens in the dead labyrinth or when the fistula is temporarily blocked by cholesteatoma flakes.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of fever, pain, and fullness in the left ear. The mother states that he has repeatedly been rubbing his left ear since he woke up this morning. The patient has a history of atopic dermatitis, and his mother is concerned that the boy's ear pain may result from excessive scratching. Six months ago, he had an episode of urticaria following antibiotic treatment for pharyngitis. He takes no medications. His temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 110/min, respirations are 25/min, and blood pressure is 90/50 mm Hg. Otoscopy shown below image is depicted. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: ASOM

  • The tympanic membrane appears red and congested in ASOM (acute suppurative otitis media).
  • Since the vessels on the tympanic membrane run radially, this hyperaemic appearance is also known as the cartwheel appearance of the tympanic membrane.

Stages of ASOM:

Stage I: Stage of tubal occlusion

  • The eustachian tube's nasopharyngeal end (or) cartilaginous end is blocked.
  • Middle ear pressure decreases.
  • The tympanic membrane is pulled/retracted.
  • Pain, ↓ hearing, on examination - dull & luster less, non–shiny.
  • No cone of light.

Stage II: Stage of pre-suppuration

  • Sterile, serous, mucoid secretion
  • Tympanic membrane bulges out, and blood vessels become prominent → (cartwheel appearance).
  • Pain ↑, hearing ↓.

Stage III: Stage of suppuration

  • The infection reaches the middle ear.
  • Fluid → pus.
  • Severe pain + ve.
  • Tragus sign – ve.
  • Red congested bulging tympanic membrane ready to burst.

Stage IV: Stage of resolution

  • Tympanic membrane burst
  • Pus comes out, pain ↓.
  • Most common site of tympanic membrane perforation → anteroinferior quadrant of pars tensa.
  • After a few weeks, perforation heals within 3-6 weeks & hearing becomes normal.
  • A healed tympanic membrane→ dimeric [no fibrous layer].
  • Lighthouse sign → pus is coming out constantly.
  • Light is reflected back.

Treatment:

  • Stage I and II → Antibiotics, analgesics, nasal decongestant drops.
  • Stage III → Myringotomy (performed in the posteroinferior quadrant).
  • Stage IV → 90% → leave alone.

Option B: Glomus tumour

  • Otoscopy shows a red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane. A "Rising sun" appearance is seen when the tumour arises from the floor of the middle ear.
  • Sometimes, the tympanic membrane appears bluish and may be bulging.

Option C: OME (Otitis media with effusion)

  • Otitis media with effusion is the collection of non-infected fluid in the tympanic cavity.
  • It is caused by irritants, allergies, and respiratory infections.
  • It can also be caused due to eustachian tube dysfunction.
  • Eustachian tube dysfunction causes negative middle ear pressure > formation of transudate > eustachian tube dysfunction prevents drainage > accumulation of fluid.
  • It causes painless pressure sensation, conductive hearing loss, and speech impairment.
  • It can be treated by the replacement of a tympanostomy tube.

Option D: CSOM (chronic suppurative otitis media)

  • Chronic suppurative otitis media is the persistent drainage from the middle ear due to tympanic membrane rupture.
  • It is most common in less than 15 years of age.
  • It can be caused by a bacterial infection, which causes tympanic membrane rupture.
  • It can also be caused by acute otitis media, ventilation tube placement, or trauma.
  • It causes painless otorrhea, conducting hearing loss, and cholesteatoma.
  • It can be treated by aural toilet or tympanoplasty with autologous graft insertion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman neuro-fibromatosis II patient comes to the E.N.T. department with a 3-week history of intermittent episodes of dizziness. The episodes last for hours and are characterized by the sensation that the room is spinning. The patient also reports that she has started using her cell phone with her left ear because she hears better on that side. She has experienced intermittent ringing and fullness in her right ear. Her temperature is 37.1°C (98.8°F), pulse is 76/min, respiration is 18/min, and blood pressure is 130/76 mm Hg. Cardiopulmonary examination shows no abnormalities. There is horizontal nystagmus to the right. M.R.I. revealed the below image. Which of the following audio-metric test is a reliable indicator in this patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: B.E.R.A.

  • The above given is a case of vestibular schwannoma.
  • The best audiometric test for vestibular schwannoma is B.E.R.A.
  • Brainstem-evoked response audiometry (B.E.R.A.) is very useful in the diagnosis of retro-cochlear lesions. In the presence of the VIIIth nerve tumour, a delay of > 0.2 ms in wave V between two ears is significant.
  • Vestibular Schwannoma is a benign tumour of abnormally proliferative Schwann cells, which covers the lateral portion of the vestibular nerve in the internal acoustic meatus.
  • Earlier name - acoustic neuroma (obsolete now).
  • Most common benign tumour of the cerebellopontine angle. (C.P. angle)
  • Usually unilateral but bilateral in neurofibromatosis II.
  • Site of origin:
    • Inf. vestibular nerve in IAC (60-90%) → most common.
    • Sometimes sup vestibular nerve.
    • Rarely from the cochlear nerve.
    • Arises from Schwann cells in the myelin sheath.
  • Clinical features:
    • SNHL - slow & progressive (most common presentation).
    • Tinnitus.
    • Vertigo/dizziness (not prominent).
  • Signs:
    • Earliest: Loss of corneal reflex (due to 5th nerve involvement).
    • Hitzelberger sign: Loss of sensory supply by the facial nerve in the posterosuperior wall of the external auditory canal.
  • Diagnosis:
    • Gadolinium-enhanced MRI→ (initial investigation of choice).
    • The best test for acoustic neuroma is B.E.R.A.
    • The most diagnostic finding suggestive of acoustic neuroma on B.E.R.A. has increased interaural latency of wave V of > 0.2 ms.
  • Treatment:
    • Large tumour– surgical excision.
    • Small tumour
      • Old patient, slow-growing tumour - serial M.R.I. every 6M.
      • A young patient with a fast-growing tumour - gamma knife excision.
      • Approaches for surgical excision.
      • When there is no hearing present: Translabyrinthine approach.
      • If hearing present: Middle cranial fossa approach (limited access).
      • Retro sigmoid /suboccipital approach: The tumour is sent for histopathology after Sx excision.
        • Anatomy A cells: More common
        • Densely packed cells with small spindle-shaped nuclei.
        • Anatomy B cells: Loosely arranged, vacuolated pleomorphic cells.

Option A: Speech Audiometry

  • Speech audiometry shows poor speech discrimination, and this is disproportionate to pure tone hearing loss. Roll-over phenomenon, i.e., reduction of discrimination score when loudness is increased beyond a particular limit, is most commonly observed.

Option B: Age-wise hearing assessment

  • This test is usually done on children.
  • This test is done at the age starting from 6 months to 10 years.
  • Adults get their hearing test every 10 years until the age of 50 and then every 3 years after 50 years of age.

Option D: Pure tone audiometry

  • Pure tone audiometry will show sensorineural hearing loss, more marked in high frequencies.
  • It determines the type, degree, and configuration of hearing loss.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male was brought to the emergency department with an alleged history of RTA and sustained injury over the temporal area with leakage of blood from the nose. Which of the following bedside test is used to test the presence of CSF in the blood?
questions.solution:
Option A: Double Ring Sign

  • Double ring sign on a piece of filter paper (or Halo sign) or target sign.
  • Typical of traumatic CSF leak and is due to blood mixed with CSF. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.
  • It is a bedside test.

Option B: Beta-Transferrin test

  • Beta-2 transferrin is a protein seen in CSF and not in nasal discharge.
  • Its presence is a specific and sensitive test and requires only a few drops of CSF. The specimen of nasal discharge is tested for this protein.

Option C: MRI

  • T2-weighted image MRI is useful in depicting the site of the leak. It requires that the CSF leak is active at the time of the scan.
  • It is a noninvasive test. It is also indicated if encephalocele or intracranial pathology is suspected.

Option D: CT scan

  • High-resolution CT scan: cuts are taken at 1-2 mm.
  • Both coronal and axial cuts are important to see the bony defects.
  • Axial cuts show any defects of the frontal or sphenoid sinus.

questions.text: A 10-year-old male presented to the ENT outpatient department due to recurrent upper respiratory infections with denasal speech and was diagnosed as a case of chronic adenoid hypertrophy. The patient underwent adenoidectomy. He returns for the follow-up with the complaint of fluid leakage through the nose while eating. Which of the following complications is the most likely cause of this patient's presentation?
questions.solution:
Option C: Velopharyngeal Insufficiency

Complications of adenoidectomy:

  • Hemorrhage: seen in the immediate postoperative period.
  • Injury to eustachian tube opening.
  • Injury to pharyngeal musculature and vertebrae.
  • Grisel syndrome: neck pain and torticollis due to spasm of paraspinal muscles.
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency.
  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis.
  • Recurrence of adenoid hypertrophy.
  • Cock robin deformity.

Velopharyngeal Insufficiency:

  • Risk factors for velopharyngeal insufficiency after adenoidectomy:
    • Occult submucous cleft
    • Neuromuscular disorders (CNS)
    • History of nasopharyngeal regurgitation before surgery
  • Adenoidectomy causes transient velopharyngeal sphincter dysfunction in about 5% of cases. This can cause troublesome rhinolalia aperta.
  • Velopharyngeal insufficiency (VPI) can occur in children with a repaired cleft palate, those with a submucous cleft, and children without any obvious palatal abnormalities. It can also occur after adenoidectomy, with a clinically significant incidence between 1 in 1500 and 1 in 3000.
  • It is necessary to check for submucous cleft palate by inspection and palpation before removal of adenoids.
  • Velopharyngeal dysfunction (VPD) is a disorder of the velopharyngeal (VP) sphincter or valve, which separate the nasal and oral cavities during speech, swallowing, vomiting, blowing, and sucking.
  • When the soft palate and pharyngeal walls are unable to form an effective seal, an abnormal connection between the nasal and oral cavities leads to
    • Hypernasal speech
    • Increased nasal resonance
    • Nasal regurgitation
    • Nasal emission
    • Decreased intraoral pressure during speech.
  • The overall result is decreased speech intelligibility and significant functional and social impairment.
  • Nasopharyngeal regurgitation causes recurrent upper respiratory infections.

Option A: Grisel syndrome

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Grisel syndrome presents as neck pain and torticollis.
  • It is due to a spasm of paraspinal muscles or atlantoaxial dislocation.
  • It does not present with regurgitation of fluid from the nose.

Option B: Nasopharyngeal stenosis

It is an incorrect option because:

  • Nasopharyngeal stenosis occurs due to excess mucosal removal or scarring during an adenoidectomy.
  • It presents as mouth breathing, snoring, rhinorrhea, hyponasality, dysphagia, otalgia, loss of hearing, and anosmia.
  • It does not lead to regurgitation of fluid from the nose.

Option D: Cock robin deformity

questions.text: A 21-year-old female presents to the clinic with a complaint of hearing loss. Her general physical and systemic examinations were unremarkable. She has no associated symptoms, such as ear pain or discharge. There is no history of recent trauma or ear infection. She is not willing to take the upcoming college tests. A series of examinations revealed that the patient is malingering. Which one of the following tests would detect malingering?
questions.solution:
Option A: Stenger test

  • It can be done with a pair of identical tuning forks or a double-channel audiometer.
  • The principle involved is that if a tone of two intensities, one greater than the other, is delivered to two ears simultaneously, only the ear which receives a tone of greater intensity will hear it.
  • To do this test, take two tuning forks of equal frequency, strike, and keep them, say 25 cm from each ear. The patient will claim to hear it in the normal ear. Now bring the tuning fork on the side of feigned deafness to within 8 cm, keeping the tuning fork on the normal side at the same distance.
  • The patient will deny hearing anything even though the tuning fork on the normal side is where it could be heard earlier. A person with true deafness should continue to hear on the normal side.
  • The patient should be blindfolded during this test. This same test can be performed with a two-channel audiometer using pure tone or speech signals.
  • This test is used to detect malingering, which is an intentional production or feigning of physical or psychological symptoms or disabilities motivated by external stresses or incentives.

Tests to detect malingering:

  • Tuning Fork tests
    • Unilateral malingering: Stenger test & Chimani-Moos Test
    • Bilateral Malingering: Lombard test
  • Objective tests for malingering
    • Stapedial reflex
    • BERA (Best Test for malingering)
    • STENGER TEST

Option B: Bing Test

  • It is a false statement.
  • It is a test of bone conduction and examines the effect of occlusion of the ear canal on hearing. A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the mastoid while the examiner alternately closes and opens the ear canal by pressing on the tragus inwards.
  • A normal person or one with sensorineural hearing loss hears louder when the ear canal is occluded and softer when the canal is open (Bing positive)
  • A patient with conductive hearing loss will appreciate no change (Bing negative).

Option C: Weber test

  • It is a false statement.
  • In this test, a vibrating tuning fork is placed in the middle of the forehead or the vertex, and the patient is asked in which ear the sound is heard.
  •  Normally, it is heard equally in both ears. It is lateralized to the worse ear in conductive deafness and to the better ear in sensorineural deafness.
  • In the weber test, sound travels directly to the cochlea via bone. Lateralization of sound in the weber test with a tuning fork of 512 Hz implies a conductive loss of 15–25 dB in the ipsilateral ear or a sensorineural loss in the contralateral ear.

Option D: Rinne Test

  • It is a false statement.
  • In this test, air conduction of the ear is compared with its bone conduction.
  • A vibrating tuning fork is placed on the patient's mastoid, and when he stops hearing, it is brought beside the meatus. If he still hears, air conduction is more than bone conduction.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the hospital with difficulty swallowing for 3 weeks. He also complains of early satiety and regurgitation at night. On examination, he has bad breath. Following investigation was done for this patient. Which of the following does this X-ray demonstrate?
questions.solution:
Option A: Zenker's diverticulum

The X-ray in the image is a Barium swallow picture showing Zenker's Diverticulum/Pouch.

Zenker's diverticulum is a pulsion diverticulum where pharyngeal mucosa herniates through the Killian's dehiscence. Killian's dehiscence is a potential area of weakness between the two parts of the inferior constrictor muscle.

Option B: Foreign body throat

  • Foreign body throat presents with dysphagia and drooling of saliva. It can be identified by radiography or flexible endoscopy.

Option C: Stricture in the lower esophagus

  • Lower esophageal sphincter leads to a sense of obstruction during swallowing. It usually presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of food. Barium swallow study can identify esophageal stricture.

Option D: Post cricoid carcinoma

  • It is associated with Plummer-Vinson Syndrome, the classic triad of dysphagia, iron deficiency anemia, and hypopharyngeal webs.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presented to the eye OPD with nasal congestion, postnasal drip, dark blood-tinged or purulent rhinorrhea, fever, and malaise associated with the left eye for the last two months. Physical examinations performed by an ophthalmologist reveal a necrotic area with black eschar formation on the palate, nasal septum, and skin of the eyelid. The patient also had a history of uncontrolled type 2 DM for the last ten years. Which fungus is most possibly associated with orbital cellulitis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Mucormycosis:

  • Based on the symptoms of nasal congestion, postnasal drip, dark blood-tinged or purulent rhinorrhea, fever, and malaise associated with the left eye and the presence of necrotic area on examination; the patient is likely suffering from orbital cellulitis associated with Mucormycosis.
  • Orbital mucormycosis is more common in diabetic and immunocompromised patients.
  • It is characterized by pain, proptosis, and necrotic area with black eschar formation on the palate, nasal septum, turbinates and eyelid skin.
  • Mucormycosis is an aggressive, opportunistic fungal infection known as phycomycosis and zygomycosis.
  • It mainly affects people who are on immunosuppressant drugs.
  • When a fungus invades a paranasal sinus mucosa, it may spread directly to the orbital apex and, from there, gain intracerebral access.
  • The fungal hyphae invade blood vessels, producing tissue infarction and massive necrosis with bone destruction.

                      

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Candida:

  • Candida is an opportunistic pathogen causing fungal orbital cellulitis. 
  • Candida remains the most common etiological agent of ocular infections worldwide among yeasts.
  • Risk factors for ocular candidiasis include excessive corticosteroids and antibiotics, contact lens wear, and surgical procedures.

Option C - Aspergillus:

  • Acute invasive sino-orbital aspergillosis may present with signs of bacterial cellulitis with periorbital inflammation that progresses to an orbital apex syndrome, presenting with ptosis, proptosis, painful ophthalmoplegia, and optic neuropathy.

Option D - Fusarium:

  • Fusarium is a large part of a group often referred to as widely present in soil and associated with plants.
  • Most species are harmless and are relatively abundant members of the soil microbial community. Some species produce in cereal crops that can affect human and animal health if they enter the food chain.

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant presents to the ophthalmology OPD with bilateral white pupillary reflex since birth. On slit-lamp examination, a zone of opacity is observed around the fetal nucleus with spoke-like radial opacities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option C: Lamellar cataract

  • This infant with white pupillary reflex since birth has a congenital cataract.
  • Slit-lamp examination findings show the cataract to be of lamellar type according to the findings in the question.
  • A Zonular or lamellar cataract is the most common congenital cataract associated with diminished vision.
  • A zone in the fetal nucleus is usually affected along with radial opacities.

Option A: Blue dot cataract

  • It is a congenital cataract with dot-like opacities in the lens.
  • It is asymptomatic and does not lead to white pupillary reflex.

Option B: Nuclear cataract

  • It is a type of congenital cataract with nuclear sclerosis.
  • There are no radial opacities in this type of cataract.

Option D: Anterior polar cataract

  • The opacity is located at the anterior pole.
  • The nucleus is not affected by this type of cataract.
  • There are no radial opacities.

questions.text: A premature male infant is born at 28 weeks gestation with a birth weight of 1.7kg in a primary health center. He was diagnosed with respiratory distress syndrome and received continuous positive airway pressure (CPAP) treatment for 28 days. He was diagnosed with Stage 2 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) in both eyes at post-conceptional 33 weeks. What would be the next best step in treating and managing this infant?

choices.text: Laser photocoagulation in worsensed eye, and follow-up for the other eye
Urgent photocoagulation in both eyes to remove avascular peripheral retina

questions.solution:
In managing a premature infant with stage 2 retinopathy of prematurity (ROP), the next steps depend on the severity of the ROP and the extent of retinal involvement. Let's review the options:

Option A. Cryotherapy - This is an older treatment option for ROP but is now less commonly used. It involves freezing the peripheral avascular retina to slow down the progression of ROP. It's not typically used for stage 2 ROP.

Option B. Laser photocoagulation in worsened eye, and follow-up for the other eye - Laser photocoagulation is a common treatment for ROP. However, in stage 2 ROP, it's usually not necessary to treat the less severe eye immediately. Instead, close follow-up is indicated to monitor for progression.

Option C. Urgent photocoagulation in both eyes to remove avascular peripheral retina - This is not the standard approach for stage 2 ROP. The decision to treat both eyes urgently would depend on specific clinical findings and the severity of ROP, but it's not the typical approach.

Option D. Follow-up - For stage 2 ROP, the standard approach is close follow-up to monitor the progression of the disease. In this case, since the infant has stage 2 ROP in both eyes at post-conceptional 33 weeks, close follow-up by a pediatric ophthalmologist is essential. Treatment (such as laser photocoagulation) may be considered if the ROP progresses to a more severe stage.

So, the most appropriate next step in managing this infant with stage 2 ROP in both eyes would be Option D. Follow-up.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old female presents to the emergency department due to sudden visual disturbances in the left eye. It is not associated with pain, nausea, vomiting, or headache. She has had a history of hypertension for 20 years and type II diabetes mellitus for 10 years. She is not compliant with her medications, and her HbA1c is 10%. Computerised static perimetry shows altitudinal field defects. A fundoscopic examination of the left eye shows:



Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient based on the information provided is:

Option A. Arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AAION)

AAION is characterized by sudden, painless vision loss and is often associated with giant cell arteritis (temporal arteritis), which can cause altitudinal field defects. Given the patient's history of hypertension and diabetes, along with non-compliance with medications and a high HbA1c, AAION should be considered, especially since it's a medical emergency requiring prompt evaluation and treatment to prevent further vision loss and address potential systemic issues related to giant cell arteritis. However, a definitive diagnosis would require clinical evaluation by a healthcare professional.

Incorrect Options:

Option B. Lateral geniculate body lesion: A lesion in the lateral geniculate body is less likely to cause isolated altitudinal field defects without associated symptoms like pain or headache. AAION is a more common cause of sudden, painless vision loss in this scenario.

Option C. Optic nerve lesion: AAION is a type of optic nerve lesion, so this doesn't provide a specific diagnosis. It's more about the underlying cause of the optic nerve lesion.

Option D. Optic chiasm lesion: Lesions of the optic chiasm typically result in bitemporal hemianopia, not altitudinal field defects. Therefore, it's not the most likely diagnosis in this case.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to his family physician with complaints of vertical diplopia. He further explains that he feels unsure while descending stairs. He can eliminate the double vision by tilting his head toward the opposite side. The patient is otherwise vitally stable and other general physical examination reveals no abnormalities. Which of the following extraocular muscles is responsible for ocular malalignment in this case?
questions.solution:
Option D: Superior oblique

  • This is a case of superior oblique palsy in which the patient presents with complaints of vertical diplopia.
  • The patient further explains he feels unsure while descending stairs.
  • The superior oblique depresses, abducts, and intorts the eye.
  • Paralysis of this muscle results in extorsion and weakness of downward gaze.
  • Head tilting compensates for extorsion.
  • Chin depression would be seen in superior oblique palsy.

Option A: Inferior rectus

  • One of the seven extraocular muscles, the inferior rectus, is principally in charge of depressing the eye (downgaze).
  • One of the four rectus muscles is the inferior rectus.
  • Other rectus muscles are the superior rectus, medial rectus, and lateral rectus.

Option B: Inferior oblique

  • The inferior oblique causes the movements of extorsion, elevation, and abduction.
  • The only muscles that can lower or raise the eye when the eye moves in adduction are the superior and inferior oblique muscles due to their courses.

Option C: Lateral rectus

  • The flat-shaped anterior portion of the lateral rectus is wider than the rest of the muscle.
  • Along with the medial rectus, an adductor, the lateral rectus muscle moves the eye laterally and side to side.

questions.text: A sixty-year-old male presents to your clinic with the complaint of blurry vision in his right eye for the past month. About a year ago, the patient underwent phacoemulsification surgery for cataract removal of the same eye. The defective vision was gradual in onset and was not associated with pain, redness or watering. According to the patient, his cataract surgery was uncomplicated, and his vision was perfect after surgery. The most common cause of this patient’s condition is?
questions.solution:
Option A: Posterior capsular opacification

  • Posterior capsule opacification (PCO) is also called after cataract or secondary cataract.

  • It is the most common postoperative complication of cataract surgery.

  • The younger the age of the patient, the faster the occurrence.

  • In PCO, the posterior capsule becomes secondarily opacified due to the migration, proliferation, and differentiation of lens epithelial cells.

  • The symptoms are a slow, painless loss of vision following cataract surgery.

  • Types of PCO are:

    • Elschnig’s pearls (most common)

    • Soemmering's ring.

  • Treatment is done by ND: YAG laser. The wavelength of this laser is 1064 nm.

Option B: Neovascular glaucoma

  • Neovascular glaucoma is a type of secondary glaucoma.

  • The angle of the eye is closed due to the formation of new blood vessels.

  • Neovascular glaucoma typically develops in eyes with severe retinal vein blockage or severe diabetic eye disease.

  • The symptoms of neovascular glaucoma can include pain, redness, and decreased vision, although it is possible not to have any symptoms in the early stages of the disease.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

Option C: Chorioretinitis

  • Chorioretinitis is an inflammation of the choroid.

  • This inflammation can affect vision.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

Option D: Cystoid macular edema

  • Cystoid Macular edema (CME) is the thickening of the macula due to a disruption of the normal blood-retinal barrier.

  • Loss of vision occurs due to retinal thickening and fluid collection that disrupts the architecture of the photoreceptors.

  • This is not a complication of cataract surgery.

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents to the ophthalmology OPD with a complaint of gradual painless vision loss for the last 3 months. He is unable to read a newspaper, particularly in bright sunlight. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Posterior subcapsular cataract:

  • This patient, with a gradual loss of vision and difficulty reading a newspaper in bright light, likely has a posterior subcapsular cataract.
  • Reading a newspaper in bright sunlight requires visual accommodation; thus, miosis occurs.
  • This allows only central rays of light to pass through the lens. However, the presence of a posterior subcapsular cataract makes it difficult for these light rays to pass through the lens.
  • This results in decreased vision in bright light.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Nuclear cataract:

  • A nuclear cataract causes index myopia and increased refractive power of the lens.
  • This improves near vision but worsens far vision.
  • Reading a newspaper requires near vision, which would be good for a patient with a nuclear cataract.

Option B - Cortical cataract:

  • Cortical cataract causes problems in night vision as the pupil dilates at night, exposing the cataractous lens.
  • The rays of light cannot pass through the lens's peripheral part.
  • Cortical cataract is not associated with difficult vision in bright light.

Option D - Coronary Cataract:

  • Coronary cataract is an extremely common developmental cataract occurring during puberty.
  • It involves the adolescent nucleus or the deeper layer of the cortex.
  • Since the opacities are situated peripherally, vision is usually unaffected.
  • Sometimes, the associated large punctate opacities may marginally reduce the vision.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male presents to the physician within 6 weeks after sustaining a penetrating accidental injury to his left eye with a wooden stick. The patient has no other abnormalities. He gives no history of any chronic illness. He is vitally stable. On examination, there is a marked diminution of vision in the right eye associated with pain, redness and photophobia. Which of the following will be the first sign seen on the fundus examination of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Retrolental flare:

  • This is a case of sympathetic ophthalmitis in which the patient presents to the physician within 6 weeks after sustaining a penetrating accidental injury to his left eye with a wooden stick.
  • On examination of the patient, there is a marked diminution of vision in the right eye associated with pain, redness and photophobia.
  • The first sign that will be seen on fundus examination of the patient with sympathetic ophthalmitis is retrolental flare.
  • The retrolental flare is also known as a vitreous flare.
  • The sympathetic ophthalmitis is most commonly caused due to trauma to the eye.
  • The trauma to one eye will also cause abnormality in the other eye.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Circumcorneal congestion:

  • Circumcorneal congestion is a rare disease.
  • It is caused due to enlargement of episcleral vessels in the ciliary body region.

Option B - Hypopyon:

  • Hypopyon causes severe inflammation of the anterior intraocular segment.
  • It is characterized by layers of white blood cells within the anterior chamber.

Option D - Iris nodule:

  • An Iris nodule is an abnormal sign of uveitis.

questions.text: A 63-year-old male presents to the clinic for the evaluation of a lesion. He is a known case of hepatocellular carcinoma. On examination, the large, sharply defined circular patch is noted without any associated inflammatory changes. A diagnosis of pityriasis rotunda is made. Which of the following is true about this lesion?
questions.solution:
Option D: Disorder of keratinization

Pityriasis rotunda:

  • Pityriasis rotunda is a persistent, extensive, sharply defined circular patch of dry ichthyosiform scaling with no inflammatory changes.
  • It is characterized by hyperpigmented or hypopigmented, sharply defined, circular, or oval scaly plaques of variable size, which develop on the trunk and proximal parts of the limbs.
  • Uncommon acquired disorder of keratinization.
  • Fixed, annular, scaling, dry-skin change.
  • More often seen in the African and Asian races
  • Associated with neoplasia, particularly Hepatocellular carcinoma.

Option A: Fungal infection:

  • Pityriasis rotunda is not a fungal infection
  • Fungal infections includes dermatophytes infections which can lead to pruritis.

Option B: Bacterial infection

  • Pityriasis rotunda is not a bacterial infection
  • Rather bacterial infections includes cellulitis, erysipelas and skin abscesses
  • These usually results in the fever along with swelling and pus formation of the involved sites.

Option C: Pityriasis affecting the nail

This option is wrong because:

  • Pityriasis rotunda does not affect nails.
  • It is an acquired disorder of keratinization

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl with a 3-month history of worsening vision and behavioral problems at school. Her mother received no prenatal care and reports that the girl was delivered without complications at home. Physical examination reveals that the girl is in the 30th percentile for weight and the 35th percentile for height. Additional findings that are notable for nummular keratitis, prominent notching of her upper two incisors and molars, and outward bowing of the tibia bilaterally. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Option A: Congenital syphilis

  • Features in favor of congenital syphilis include
    • No prenatal care
    • “Wartlike” perioral maculopapular rash
    • Worsening vision and behavioral problems in school.
    • Nummular keratitis
    • Prominent notching of her upper two incisors and molars (Hutchinson's teeth)
    • Outward bowing of the tibia bilaterally (Saber shins)
    • Sensorineural hearing loss
  • Caused by spirochete, Treponema pallidum.
  • Syphilis is acquired by the fetus during the intra-uterine life from an infected mother.
  • Congenital syphilis can lead to hydrops fetalis, intra-uterine growth restriction, premature labor, or stillbirth.
  • Maternal screening for syphilis in early pregnancy is of prime importance in preventing congenital syphilis.

Option B: Congenital Toxoplasmosis

  • Classic triad
    • Chorioretinitis
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Diffuse intracranial calcifications (ring-enhancing lesions)
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)

Option C: Congenital Rubella

  • Cardiac manifestations, a “blueberry muffin” rash, and the maternal history strongly suggest congenital rubella syndrome (CRS).
  • Rubella virus is associated with an 85% risk of congenital defects if acquired in the first 12 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Other infections acquired in utero that can present with rash and ocular findings can be recalled with the TORCH acronym: Toxoplasmosis, Rubella, Cytomegalovirus infection, Herpes simplex, and syphilis.
  • Mucosal, periorificial, palmar, and plantar lesions are common in congenital syphilis.
  • Congenital rubella syndrome triad:
  • C: Cataract
  • H: Congenital heart defect
  • D: Deafness

Option D: Congenital Cytomegalovirus

  • Jaundice, hepatosplenomegaly
  • IUGR
  • Chorioretinitis
  • Sensorineural deafness
  • Periventricular calcifications
  • Petechiae and purpura (blueberry muffin rash)
  • Microcephaly
  • Seizures

questions.text: A 26-year-old man visits the clinic with a complaint of pruritic outgrowths on his genitals for the last three weeks. He has a history of HIV infection and has been non-compliant with his medications. He has been frequently involved in unprotected sexual practices as well. On examination, exophytic, cauliflower-like lesions are found over the genitals. Which of the following is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
Option A: Local 5-FU

  • Anogenital warts are characterized by pruritic, exophytic, and cauliflower-like outgrowths over the genitals
  • Risk factors include:
  • History of unprotected sexual relationships with multiple partners
  • Immunodeficient states such as AIDS.
  • HPV serotypes associated with anogenital warts include HPV 6, 11, 16, 34, and 35.
  • Diagnosis is made via visual inspection of the lesions
  • Management options include:
  • Local application of 5-FU, podophyllin, and trichloroacetic acid
  • Cryotherapy
  • Laser surgery
  • Curettage
  • Electrocoagulation

Option B: Ketoconazole

  • Ketoconazole can be used orally or applied locally in the form of creams and shampoo for the treatment of tinea versicolor. It has no role in the management of anogenital warts.

Option C: Clotrimazole

  • It is also used in the treatment of tinea versicolor.

Option D: Oral acyclovir

  • It is primarily used for the treatment of herpes simplex virus infection and has no role in the management of anogenital warts.

questions.text:
A 7-year-old boy presents to the clinic with the complaint of fever, runny nose, and cough for the past three days. The boy also has a rash over his body. The mother reports that the boy first developed a fever and runny nose a few days ago. Today she noticed a rash, as shown below:



Which of the following term best describes the skin findings in the patient?
questions.solution:
Option C: Morbilliform

  • This patient most likely has a morbilliform rash.
  • Exanthematous (maculopapular) drug eruption, also called morbilliform (measles-like) drug-induced exanthem, is the most common drug hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by a disseminated and occasionally generalized, symmetric eruption of erythematous macules and papules that occur approximately one to two weeks after initiating treatment with the causative drug or, in previously sensitized individuals, as early as 6 to 12 hours and up to three days after initiating treatment with the causative drug.
  • The exanthematous drug eruption should be differentiated from more severe forms of drug hypersensitivity, where the mucous membranes (oral, conjunctival, nasal, anogenital) and internal organs may be involved.

Differential Diagnosis of Morbilliform Reactions:

Common

  • Morbilliform drug eruptions - Common antibiotics can trigger a morbilliform drug eruption. These medications include penicillins, sulfonamides, thiazides, sulfonylureas, nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), aromatic anticonvulsants, and gold.
  • Morbilliform viral eruptions (many) - Measles, Rubella, Scarlet fever, HHV 6.

Uncommon

  • Severe drug hypersensitivity reaction
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Rickettsial infections
  • Serum sickness
  • Roseola vaccinatum
  • This eruption is usually self-limited and may last an average of 1-2 weeks

Option A: Herpetiform

  • It occurs in a grouped configuration with polycyclic margins. This patient most likely has morbilliform eruptions.

Option B: Lichenoid eruptions

  • These are violaceous to purple, polygonal lesions that resemble those seen in lichen planus. The best term for this patient’s lesions is morbilliform.

Option D: Milia

  • These are small, firm, white papules filled with keratin. This patient has morbilliform eruptions secondary to viral infection.
